216 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


August 15, 1991 Thursday


VFA dash revived


BYLINE: BARRETT D


LENGTH: 244 words


THE time-honored VFA half-time dash will be revived on Saturday at Coburg's City Oval.

Formerly known as the Dandy Dollar Dash, this year's series will be sponsored by Nike. 

Heats are to be held during the final two home-and-away matches and the first three weeks of the finals.

The 10 runners with the most points will take part in the final at Princes Park on grand final day on September 22.

President of the Victorian Runners and Trainers Association, John Evans, said the dash was a long-standing part of the VFA competition.

"It was a shame to see it go," Evans said.

"It's a prestigious race and one the pro runners really like to win." Evans had been seeking sponsorship for the race for much of the year after losing backing at the end of last season.

"Times are tough . . . the economy's tight," he said.

"We were pretty fortunate Nike came to the party."

He said the series would be a good stepping stone for the upcoming professional racing calendar.

Backmarker for the series will be Victorian hurdles champion Kevin Oakey.

The evergreen Doug Howey, a perennial finalist, is also competing.

Other runners of note include Chris Pegg, last season's Bendigo 5000 winner Tim Mason, and runner-up to Dean Capobianco in the 1990 Stawell Gift and the 1991 Melton Gift winner Perry Hannah.

Veteran NBL basketballer Al Green is a past winner of the VFA dash.

Bookmakers are expected to field on the final.

END OF STORY


LOAD-DATE: September 25, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Back in running . . . Nike representative George Lawlor (right) handsJohn Evans a sponsorship cheque for the reborn VFA dash yesterday.


JOURNAL-CODE: DHS


Copyright 1991 Nationwide News Pty Limited

 

217 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


Herald Sun


September 23, 1991 Monday


NIKE JUMPS, LA VANISHES


BYLINE: MCKENNA J


SECTION: HERALD BUSINESS; Pg. 54


LENGTH: 143 words


NIKE is in no mood for a marathon. The athletic footwear company - whose advertisements feature basketball superstar Michael Jordan - is sprinting to the lead in the earnings race in what has become a very lucrative market. 

 Nike h$as just reported a 15 per cent jump in second-quarter earnings to a record $US114.4 million.

US sales rose 5 per cent and Wall Street is bullish about the company's future.

But troubled rival LA Gear is fading fast as mounting financial troubles are complicated by shrinking credit.

After becoming the third largest shoemaker in the US in four years, the company has losses of over $US4 million and was recently bought by Stanley Gold, a shrewd Californian known for restoring troubled companies.

Nevertheless, there are whispers that the company may soon be known as LA Disappear.

END OF STORY


LOAD-DATE: September 25, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: DHS


Copyright 1991 Nationwide News Pty Limited

 

218 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


The Advertiser


January 16, 1991 Wednesday


A best foot forward can also be the cheapest


SOURCE: aap


LENGTH: 457 words


SYDNEY: Price is no guide to quality in the high-tech fashion stakes of the running-shoe market, according to the Australian Consumer Association Magazine, Choice.

The magazine said the cheapest shoes tested, selling for as little as $34, protected the feet from injury just as well as the $150 big-name brands like Adidas, Reebok, Puma and Nike.

And the cheapest shoes were the best casual runners by far. 

Choice asked Olympic pentathlete Alex Watson to put 12 pairs of running shoes, ranging in price from $34 to $160, through their paces over a 10km course, covering a variety of terrain.

The shoes were tested for comfort, moisture evaporation, shock absorption, stability, construction, terrain-riding ability and flexibility and springiness.

"All 12 pairs rated highly, even though prices varied so widely," the magazine said.

"Price was not a guide to features such as comfort, shock, absorption, stabilility or flexibility."

The magazine said the basic role of running shoes was to protect the foot from injury. But this role was obscured because of high-profile marketing and fashion hype which promoted expensive brands as the triumphs of the tracks.

Choice found the Adidas Torsion ZX 4000 C, which costs $150, topped the 12 shoes tested with an overall safety level of 96 per cent.

Another money-spinner, Nike Air Craft, selling for $140, ranked third in the list at 94 per cent.

But the miser's sports shoe, the Dunlop KT 26, at about $34, romped into ninth place at 84 per cent. This cheap shoe equalled the big names in the stability, shock absorption and moisture-evaporation stakes.

"At a third of the price of many other shoes, it is hard to beat as a shoe which provides all the necessary qualities for casual runners, particularly heavy ones, as it offers a very stable, wide base," the magazine said.

The magazine said running created a constant potential for injury.

The harder the surface and the heavier the runner, the greater the stress on joints at every step.

And, the test of a good running shoe is that it must be an effective shock absorber and it must keep the foot stable to prevent ankle injuries.

How the shoes rated for overall safety:

Adidas Torsion ZX 4000 C ($120-$150) 96 per cent; Puma-Trinomic 210 ($110-$160) 95; Nike Air Craft ($99-$140) 94; Brooks Rage HydroFlow ($75-$140) 92; Reebok Questor ERS ($108-$135) 89; Puma XR ($84-$100) 89; Saucony Freedom 1000 ($88-$120) 88; Asics Gel Runner TN 05 ($97-$130) 88; Hi-Tec Triathon ($71-$110) 85; Dunlop KT 26 ($34-$60) 84; New Balance M495 ($142-$149) 83; Adidas Quorum ($59-$80) 82.


LOAD-DATE: September 25, 2003


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


JOURNAL-CODE: ADV


Copyright 1991 Nationwide News Pty Limited

 

221 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


May 14, 1991, Tuesday, North Suncoast Edition


MARKET SLUGGISH


SECTION: BUSINESS; BUSINESS DIGEST; Pg. 1E


LENGTH: 906 words


 

MARKET SLUGGISH. The stock market ended mixed in light, lackluster trading Monday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 4.25 to close at 2,924.42. Advancing issues narrowly outpaced declining ones in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks.

 
   T-BILLS MIXED. Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities were mixed Monday as the government auctioned $ 9.22-billion of three-month Treasury bills and $ 9.23-billion of six-month bills. The average discount rate for the three-month bill was 5.50 percent, unchanged from last week, while the average discount rate for the six-month bill was 5.63 percent, up from 5.61 percent. The discount rate understates the return to investors a yield of 5.67 percent on three-month bills and 5.89 percent on six-month bills. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills rose to 6.13 percent last week, up from 6.11 percent the previous week. 
 Nation
Production up
in U.S. industries

 
   WASHINGTON Snapping a six-month decline, the nation's factories, mines and utilities raised production slightly in April as assemblies of trucks and automobiles rebounded, the Federal Reserve reported Monday.
 
    The increase of 0.1 percent, while neither large nor unexpected, was seen as indicating that the economy was approaching its low point and that a recovery might be imminent.
 
    Analysts were encouraged by the first rise in industrial output since September, but they added that more months of declining output might lie ahead before the economy was clearly seen to be on the mend.
First Executive Corp.
files for protection

 
   First Executive Corp., the troubled life insurance holding company facing billions of dollars in junk bond losses, said Monday that it filed for bankruptcy reorganization.
 
    The Chapter 11 filing in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Los Angeles comes after California regulators last month seized the ailing holding company's largest insurance unit, Executive Life, in what constituted the largest insurance failure in the nation's history.
 
    Any plan to reorganize the firm's companies under new ownership faces the likelihood that hundreds of millions of dollars owed to policyholders, holders of annuities and other securities will not be paid.
 
Executive Life had been permitted under conservatorship to continue payment of death claims, some medical claims and about 70 percent of certain periodic payments.
 
    No payments were being made on 307 pension plans that used First Executive guaranteed investment contracts, which were technically not insured. Monday's bankruptcy filing further clouds the picture for policyholders.
 
    Florida insurance officials said about 11,000 Floridians hold Executive Life insurance policies, but they do not know how many have annuities or 401(k) investments in the company.

 
   FED TO MEET. The Federal Reserve is facing renewed pressure from the Bush administration and corporate America to supply another round of interest rate cuts to get the country out of the recession. But most economists predicted the central bank will adopt a wait-and-see approach when Fed policymakers meet for a strategy session Tuesday. For that reason, these analysts said that consumer borrowing costs, including mortgage rates, are not likely to decline significantly anytime soon.

 
   NIKE ADS LAUDED. The shoemaker Nike Inc. nosed out fragrance maker Calvin Klein as the sponsor of the most popular print advertising campaign of 1990, according to a consumer survey. Earlier this year, Nike placed second in a similar survey on television commercials for 1990. Following Nike and Calvin Klein in the Video Storyboard survey were ads for Camel cigarettes, Revlon cosmetics, Absolut vodka, Infiniti cars, Marlboro cigarettes, Guess apparel, Ford automobiles and trucks and Maybelline cosmetics. Tampa Bay/State

 
   CAPITAL PROTEST PLANNED. Sixty Florida farmers will take their campaign against a proposed free trade agreement with Mexico to the lawn of the nation's capital on Wednesday. They will have two rigs loaded with Florida produce and some strong words about how the proposed agreement would harm Florida's $ 6.2-million agricultural industry. State Agriculture Commissioner Bob Crawford is trying to persuade the Bush administration to keep tariffs in place year-round for citrus and during the growing months of January and February, when Florida is head-to-head in produce production for U.S. markets.

 
   BOB EVANS CLOSES OUTLETS. Bob Evans Farms Inc. on Monday closed two of its 255 restaurants, one on U.S. 19 N at Drew Street in Clearwater and the other in the Chicago area. The stores, which were closed because they were unprofitable, will be sold, the Columbus, Ohio-based company said. The Clearwater store opened in 1987.

 
   NUTMEG EARNINGS. Tampa-based Nutmeg Industries Inc. on Monday reported a continued earnings rebound with first quarter profits of $ 155,000, or 3 cents a share, compared to a loss of $ 292,000 in the comparable quarter in 1990. Sales rose 85 percent to $ 17.1-million, up from $ 9.2-million.
 
     DOW       30 INDUSTRIALS   2924.42 +4.25
     DOLLAR    JAPANESE YEN     139.45   +0.75
     BONDS     30-YEAR U.S.     8.27%    -0.07


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Times Publishing Company

 

222 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


June 11, 1991, Tuesday, City Edition


STOCKS DECLINE.


SECTION: BUSINESS; BUSINESS DIGEST; Pg. 1E


LENGTH: 927 words


 

STOCKS DECLINE. The stock market drifted lower in slow trading Monday, still restrained by worries over rising interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 50.76 points last week, slipped 1.34 to 2,975.40.

 
   T-BILLS RISE. Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose Monday as the government auctioned $ 10-billion of three-month Treasury bills and $ 10.1-billion of six-month bills. The average discount rate for the three-month bill was 5.60 percent, up from 5.59 percent last week, while the average discount rate for the six-month bill was 5.78 percent, up from 5.71 percent. The discount rate understates the return to investors a yield of 5.78 percent on three-month bills and 6.05 percent on six-month bills. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills rose to 6.30 percent last week, up from 6.13 percent the previous week. 
 Nation
Ch. 13 parent gets
filing extension

 
   A federal bankruptcy judge in Denver has extended until June 25 the date that the parent company of WTVT-Ch. 13 has to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization.
 
    Three of the nation's largest financial companies are trying to force Gillett Holdings Inc., which also owns television stations in Baltimore and California and two Colorado ski resorts, into the reorganization.
 
    George Gillett, the Colorado executive who owns the junk-bond indebted Gillett Holdings, has been seeking to renegotiate the concern's debts out of court.
 
    Judge Sidney Brooks on Monday ruled Gillett cannot have any further extensions, but the company has until June 25 because the Gillett's talks with creditors haven't been successful.

 
   BANK BILL TARGETED. Rep. John D. Dingell, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, is trying to derail the Bush administration's proposed banking system overhaul from the legislative fast track. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., wants to move a comprehensive banking bill through the House before Congress recesses in early August. That likely would leave Dingell's panel with only a few weeks to review the legislation. In an 11-page letter to Foley released Monday, Dingell, D-Mich., argued he needed more time. Dingell is skeptical about key elements of the bill, including permitting commercial and industrial firms to own banks and allowing banks to affiliate with securities firms and insurance companies.

 
   INVENTOR SUES NIKE. An Arlington, Va., inventor is putting on a full-court press against one of Michael Jordan's biggest backers, Nike Inc. Charles Petrosky, a 73-year-old inventor who works out of a cluttered shop in his basement, claims in a federal suit in Alexandria, Va., that the manufacturing giant swiped his invention when it marketed the Air Jordan sneaker, named after the Chicago Bulls' star guard.

 
   GAS PRICES RISE. What do you get when you mix falling wholesale gasoline prices with a recession that has dampened demand? If you answered lower prices at the pump, you may be wrong. In one of those curiosities that seems peculiar to the oil business, motorists seem to be paying more and more for gasoline each week, even though some dealers are paying less. Critics say the major oil companies are once again exploiting consumers because summer driving season is here. The American Petroleum Institute said gasoline prices typically rise in the summer because of refining processes triggered by higher demand. The API also cited higher taxes and a higher per-barrel cost of crude oil.

 
   UNISYS NEARS SETTLEMENT. Unisys Corp. is nearing agreement with federal prosecutors to settle fraud charges stemming from schemes to obtain confidential bid information on defense contracts, government sources said Monday. The computer systems manufacturer, which has a plant in Oldsmar, could end up paying as much as $ 190-million to settle allegations arising from the Justice Department investigation known as "Operation Ill Wind," said government sources.

 
   FEDERATED BILLS CLIMBING. Legal fees are approaching $ 90-million in the 17 months since Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, a court trustee said. "We've tried to control the fees," said bankruptcy court trustee Conrad Morgenstern. The companies, headquartered in Cincinatti, operate such retail stores as Maas Brothers/Jordan Marsh and Burdines. Morgenstern said that if it takes $ 100-million in legal fees to bring a $ 10-billion company out of bankruptcy, that represents only 1 percent of the company's assets.
Corrections

 
    The Jacaranda chapter of the American Business Women's Association will meet at 6 p.m. Saturday at Las Fontanas Restaurant, 15481 49th St. N, Clearwater. Due to incorrect information provided to the Times, an item Monday gave a different address.
 
     Jasmine Shasteen, 6, was pictured in a photo Saturday. She was incorrectly identified.
 
     There is no longer a Bonwit Teller store in Kansas City's Country Club Plaza. A file photo and caption Sunday incorrectly described the store as a current merchant.

TYPE: DIGEST; CORRECTION


Times Publishing Company

 

223 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


July 3, 1991, Wednesday, City Edition


Pumped up


BYLINE: PATRICIA McLAUGHLIN


SECTION: FLORIDIAN; AFTER A FASHION; Pg. 3D


LENGTH: 513 words


 

While Michael, 11, tried on the Air Jordans his parents had promised him for basketball camp, his 8-year-old sister, Kate, fondled the little-girl-sized Reebok Pump from the display. It's her dream shoe, but at $ 80, her parents won't go for it.
 
  

What makes it so cool?
 
    "When you push the pump button," she explained, "it makes you, like, run faster, or it makes you, like, jump better. It helps you do aerobics. It feels like air is floating inside of your shoe." 
 
    Then, "when you don't want to run real fast or jump, you press the button" and the sneaker deflates.
 
    How does she know all this if she has never worn a pair?
 
    "Everybody knows about them," she said, clearly appalled that I'd had to ask. "Like, it's a popular shoe."
 
    One more child hornswoggled by advertising, you might think: but no. Reebok's ads don't claim the Pump which pumps air into bladders in the shoe's lining to create a closer fit makes you run faster or jump higher.
 
    Reebok's John Morgan admits right up front that it doesn't.
 
    And he's right. Zillions, the kidversion of Consumer Reports, proved it. They heard the same run-faster, jump-higher playground myth and decided to test it out. When they outfitted their kid testers in three kinds of shoes the Reebok Pump, the Nike Air Jordan and the Nike Quantum Force they found that the kids jumped to exactly the same heights in all three models, and actually ran a little bit slower in the Pumps, which were noticeably heavier than the other two. When the testers were told they could keep the shoes they liked best, nobody chose Pumps.
 
    According to Morgan, those results may need updating soon. Since Reebok introduced the first Pump, he says, they've streamlined its air-pump technology. The Pump they'll introduce in August, he says, weighs only 15 ounces per shoe, more than five ounces lighter than the model Zillions tested.
 
    It still won't make you run faster or jump higher. What it does do, Morgan says, is reduce ankle injuries. He says tests at the University of California at Berkeley matched 200 kids in low-tops against 200 kids in regular high-tops and 200 kids in Pumps and found that the Pump cut ankle injuries by 60 percent.
 
    So where did the run-faster, jump-higher rap come from? Morgan doesn't know, but it doesn't surprise him. Kids, he says, "have a tendency to build stories around shoes." For instance, a black high-top basketball shoe Reebok happened to introduce shortly after the death of University of Maryland basketball star Len Bias came to be known in the Washington, D.C., area as the Len Bias Memorial Shoe. And, on New England playgrounds, the black high-top Pump that the Boston Celtics' Dee Brown wears and that he so effectively called attention to during the NBA All Stars Slam-Dunk Contest last February by pumping and repumping before every try is known as the Deebok.
- Patricia McLaughlin has written for the Philadelphia Inquirer, Washington Post and Rolling Stone magazine.


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: BLACK AND WHITE PHOTO, Philadelphia Inquirer MICHAEL S. WIRTZ; Child wearing pair of Reeboks jumps


Times Publishing Company

 

224 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


 July 3, 1991


BYLINE: PATRICIA McLAUGHLIN


LENGTH: 513 words


 

While Michael, 11, tried on the Air Jordans his parents had promised him for basketball camp, his 8-year-old sister, Kate, fondled the little-girl-sized Reebok Pump from the display. It's her dream shoe, but at $ 80, her parents won't go for it.
 
  

What makes it so cool?
 
    "When you push the pump button," she explained, "it makes you, like, run faster, or it makes you, like, jump better. It helps you do aerobics. It feels like air is floating inside of your shoe." 
 
    Then, "when you don't want to run real fast or jump, you press the button" and the sneaker deflates.
 
    How does she know all this if she has never worn a pair?
 
    "Everybody knows about them," she said, clearly appalled that I'd had to ask. "Like, it's a popular shoe."
 
    One more child hornswoggled by advertising, you might think: but no. Reebok's ads don't claim the Pump which pumps air into bladders in the shoe's lining to create a closer fit makes you run faster or jump higher.
 
    Reebok's John Morgan admits right up front that it doesn't.
 
    And he's right. Zillions, the kidversion of Consumer Reports, proved it. They heard the same run-faster, jump-higher playground myth and decided to test it out. When they outfitted their kid testers in three kinds of shoes the Reebok Pump, the Nike Air Jordan and the Nike Quantum Force they found that the kids jumped to exactly the same heights in all three models, and actually ran a little bit slower in the Pumps, which were noticeably heavier than the other two. When the testers were told they could keep the shoes they liked best, nobody chose Pumps.
 
    According to Morgan, those results may need updating soon. Since Reebok introduced the first Pump, he says, they've streamlined its air-pump technology. The Pump they'll introduce in August, he says, weighs only 15 ounces per shoe, more than five ounces lighter than the model Zillions tested.
 
    It still won't make you run faster or jump higher. What it does do, Morgan says, is reduce ankle injuries. He says tests at the University of California at Berkeley matched 200 kids in low-tops against 200 kids in regular high-tops and 200 kids in Pumps and found that the Pump cut ankle injuries by 60 percent.
 
    So where did the run-faster, jump-higher rap come from? Morgan doesn't know, but it doesn't surprise him. Kids, he says, "have a tendency to build stories around shoes." For instance, a black high-top basketball shoe Reebok happened to introduce shortly after the death of University of Maryland basketball star Len Bias came to be known in the Washington, D.C., area as the Len Bias Memorial Shoe. And, on New England playgrounds, the black high-top Pump that the Boston Celtics' Dee Brown wears and that he so effectively called attention to during the NBA All Stars Slam-Dunk Contest last February by pumping and repumping before every try is known as the Deebok.
- Patricia McLaughlin has written for the Philadelphia Inquirer, Washington Post and Rolling Stone magazine.


LOAD-DATE: November 6, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Times Publishing Company

 

225 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


August 22, 1991, Thursday, City Edition


USF hires former top runner as assistant


BYLINE: BRIAN LANDMAN


SECTION: BRANDON TIMES; CROSS COUNTRY; Pg. 4


LENGTH: 411 words


DATELINE: TAMPA


 

Nancy Daniels, a former star runner and an exercise physiologist for the Nike competitive team, said Wednesday she has been hired as the University of South Florida's first full-time cross country and track assistant.
 
    "I'm really excited to be here; I used to run Division I and I'm excited to be back to Division I in a big way," Daniels said.
 
    Daniels had been informally assisting her husband, Jack, at Cortland State, N.Y., since 1986. The women's team there won the NCAA Division III cross-country championships in 1989 and 1990 and the indoor track title in 1990-91. 
 
    "We struggled with it for a week," Daniels said of leaving New York and her husband, who will retire from coaching at the end of this school year.
 
    USF coach Bob Braman, whohas run both the men's and women's programs over the years, echoed those sentiments.
 
    "She's got the credentials to really help us," he said. "Her teams were Division III, but they were good enough to be top 10 in Division I. She's going to be a strong draw for us and she's strong in areas I'm not."
 
    Daniels, 32, formerly Nancy Scardina, was one of the University of New Hampshire's best runners ever. She led the team to the NCAA cross-country championships in 1981 and to the NCAA outdoor track championships in 1982. In 1988, she qualified for the U.S. Olympic Trials in the marathon.
 
    She then worked physiologically and nutritionally with the nation's premier runners, including Mary Decker and Joan Benoit while at Nike's Athletes West from 1983-86. She also has published numerous papers on the exercise physiology of runners.
 
    "That's helped," she said. "I like giving people facts about running and see their eyes open. People don't like to believe you, but they can't dispute scientific facts and say, "That's not what my high school coach told me.' I really love working with the kids."
 
    The USF women's program, just four years old, won its first cross-country title of any kind, the Sun Belt Conference crown, last fall under part-time assistant Judy Bogenschutz. Bogenschutz chose not to return and to concentrate on her running career.
 
    This year, track will officially become a varsity sport at USF and the budget for men's and women's cross country and track will double, from $ 110,000 to $ 215,000. Scholarships will be increased from four to seven for the men and the women alike.


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


DISTRIBUTION: BRANDON TIMES; TAMPA


Times Publishing Company

 

226 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


November 27, 1991, Wednesday, City Edition


Burning calories to help hungry


BYLINE: JANET ROGERS


SECTION: CITY TIMES; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 568 words


DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG


 

If the prospect of Thanksgiving overindulgence leaves you feeling guilty, here's one way to ease a calorie-counting conscience and help others, too.
 
    On Thanksgiving morning, Tuff Stuff exercise coordinators Joan Kilpatrick and Susan Harrod will conduct a special bench workout at Shore Acres Community Center. A donation of one non-perishable food item gets you in the class. Bring four more and you'll be eligible for door prizes that include exercise tapes, massages, pastries, free Tuff Stuff classes and Nike sneakers. 
 
  If that's not enough, consider this: The food you bring will help fill the cupboards of the St. Petersburg Free Clinic Food Bank and feed those who won't have the same opportunities to indulge during the holiday season.
 
    "I think it will be particularly helpful this year because the need is so great," said Sister Margaret Freeman, executive director of St. Petersburg's Free Clinic. "They (Kilpatrick and Harrod) are doing a great job of creating interest."
 
     The workout began six years ago and has become a Shore Acres tradition. Last year, 102 participants brought so much food it took four cars to haul it away. Harrod said the class began as a way to get people exercising during the holidays. A food drive was added the following year.
 
    "We started going crazy (with activities)," Harrod said.
 
    The workout got bigger and busier every Thanksgiving.
 
    This year, the workout's door prizes are donated by radio stations, national exercise programs and local businesses. A chef will prepare strudels and Napoleons on site during the workout, then donate them as prizes. David Pittman will bring in a sound system for an added boost.
 
  "It's kind of exciting," Harrod said. "The person who donates the most canned goods we crown her the Can Queen. Last year, the Can Queen brought in something like 70 cans."
 
    Being crowned queen has benefits. This year's prize package includes a pair of Nikes, a leotard and three months of Tuff Stuff classes.
 
    But what happens if the person bringing the most cans is male?
 
    "He's still the Can Queen," Harrod said. "That's what the sash says."
 
     Despite the jovial atmosphere, Harrod and Kilpatrick are serious about their mission. Kilpatrick said she hopes participants will try to bring the foods needed most. Peanut butter, jelly, rice, soup, beans, powdered milk, dry cereal, canned meats and vegetables, dried or canned fruits, and boxed macaroni and cheese head the list. If possible, bring the food in large paper bags that can be reused when the food is distributed.
 
    Items with limited value are gourmet foods, such as caviar; foods that require added meat or have an expired freshness date; refrigerated products; and foods that must be prepared in a microwave. The Food Bank already has a good supply of baby food.
 
  If the past is any indication, the class should fill up quickly. Harrod said about 85 benches from community centers throughout St. Petersburg have been brought in for the step up/step down workout. Because each person needs a bench, the class size is limited to the number of benches.
 
    What makes the workout so popular? "I think it's just that there's nothing to do (on Thanksgiving morning)," Harrod said, "and plus, they feel guilty (about overeating)."


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


DISTRIBUTION: CITY TIMES; CLEARWATER TIMES


Times Publishing Company

 

227 of 1437 DOCUMENTS



The Globe and Mail (Canada)


June 27, 1991 Thursday


COLE-HAAN HERE"Specially designed shoe store opens Saturday on Bloor Decor a tribute to Canada


BYLINE: JOYCE CARTER; GAM


LENGTH: 489 words


BY JOYCE CARTER
The Globe and Mail
COLE-Haan, the giant international shoe and handbag concern, opens its
first Canadian store to the public Saturday at 101 Bloor West. 

To judge by the furnishings, attention to detail is foremost in the
minds of the principles. The ceilings have domed centres with hand-cast
bas-relief faces of foxes, mountain lions and the like. Display cases have
bands of other hand-carved animals.

"They were done as a tribute to Canada, to say thank you to Toronto for
welcoming us," explains Cathy Taylor, the firm's vice-president retail.
She was born and raised here and admits to a lingering fondness for her
home town, "so I've been looking at Toronto for the past five years," with
a view of just such a store.

"But the timing has to be right and you must have the right location,"
so they waited until the prime corner site became available. Only then did
Barton A. Forbes of Forbes Associates, Falmouth, Maine, get started on the
design, a task he's repeated a dozen times for flagship stores around the
world, including Beverly Hills, New York, Florence and Tokyo.

The company, which projects sales of $150-million U.S. in the coming
year, is based in Yarmouth, Maine. Shoes, handbags and accessories
(including cabin trunks for luxury liners) are produced in the United
States, Italy, England, Brazil and Spain.

Speaking of the shoes, Ms Taylor says "we are specialists in fitting,
we are very confident in our fit. Americans understand this, we use
different lasts than they do in Italy. Italian lasts are more tapered from
the ball of the foot to the toe, we make a fuller toe. Italian lasts are
shallow at the toe, ours are much higher for comfort."

That doesn't mean they sacrifice style. For all the firm has been owned
by Nike Inc. since 1988, there's no sign of the runners in the Cole-Haan
stores. "We operate as two separate companies. We do have a group of
products - Tensile Air - which puts Nike technology into a dress shoe."

The examples look just like any other street shoes but inside, they're
cushioned "they have the air built in, they will never deflate."

That's just one group among many: everything from classic American
country footwear to sleek Italian slip-ons. Many of the shoes, as well as
handbags, come in woven leather and the same technique is applied to satin
for the perfect tuxedo pumps.

Prices, she figures, will be about 17 per cent higher than in the
United States, to cover the difference in the dollar and the higher cost
of doing business here. Stock for their Canadian wholesale accounts will
be housed in the basement. ("No, I don't think that makes us competitors
with stores like Harry Rosen, we've been selling to him for years. It just
means greater recognition of our name.")
There are at present no plans to open other Canadian stores. "You've
got to have a starting point. You've got to do well before you go on. This
is the city we have confidence in now. We believe very strongly in
Canada."


LOAD-DATE: January 9, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

228 of 1437 DOCUMENTS



The Globe and Mail (Canada)


September 13, 1991 Friday


STOCK SCENE Investor's guide to coping with kids' shoes


BYLINE: EDWARD CLIFFORD; GAM


LENGTH: 543 words


By EDWARD CLIFFORD
SOONER or later, your rug rats will try to coerce you into buying $109
sneakers so that they can hold up their heads - and feet - with pride.

Before succumbing to the natural parental tendency to give Ashley or
Justin the best, pause. Wouldn't it be better to give them $23 K mart
footwear, invest the savings in shares of Reebok International Ltd. of
Stoughton, Mass., and let other parents pay for your kids' college
education?

It may sound cruel to a child with a two-week time horizon, but
investors with a longer view will benefit from an understanding of the
shoe industry. 

Leisure shoes are popular with all age groups. Even senior adults like
to have nifty, new-technology gear, apparently ignoring the adage,
"comfortable as an old shoe."

There's not much difference between shoes. If they fit and feel good,
who cares what name they carry? Lots of people obviously care a lot.

Reebok is suing other companies for copyright infringement. It claims
it is the sole owner of the "pump" technology. Put the shoe on, pump in
air for a tight fit, and win a gold medal.

In the mid-1950s, European ski boots that pioneered the technology were
available in North America - although we can remember one broken ankle
that they did not prevent.

The shoe business is basically an advertising game. The company with
the best marketing strategy wins, and right now Reebok is the leader.

Its shares trade at $30.75 (U.S.) in New York, an amazing recovery from
the 52-week low of $8.87. Can it go any higher?

Yes, says Value Line Inc. of New York. Reebok has introduced a product
known as Blacktop, a shoe for youngsters who play hockey, baseball,
football and basketball on driveways and roads.

Naturally, kids who love asphalt sports will play them, no matter what
they wear on their feet. Blacktop shoes should appeal to the ones who
don't, but pretend they do.

Reebok's competitors include the following:
L.A. Gear Inc. of Los Angeles. It was saved from bankruptcy this week
by selling $100-million worth of shares to Trefoil Capital Investors. Does
Trefoil have marketing smarts? Probably not, but L.A. Gear does have a
distribution system reaching into 100 countries, and has a cool image that
might serve it well in Eastern European markets.

Nike Inc. of Beaverton, Ore. Volatile stock, and has a problem with its
name. Is it Ny-kee? Knee-kee? Neeck? Or Nike, as in like? One basic rule
for investors is to stay away from shares of companies that have names
they cannot pronounce.

Stride Rite Corp. of Cambridge, Mass. This company makes the Keds line.
Your curtain-crawlers may hate them, but Keds sneakers work just as well
as Reeboks.

Wolverine World Wide Corp. of Rockford, Minn. Many upscale households
in North America have at least one pair of its products: Hush Puppies and
Brooks, for example. With quality brand names and licencing agreements in
the world's most prosperous markets, executives can farm out manufacturing
to low-cost countries and be home in time for dinner.

While many North American companies and their employees decry U.S.
efforts to create a Western Hemisphere free-trade zone, the shoe business
should benefit. Instead of out-sourcing manufacturing to Asia, it can be
brought closer to markets, and everybody, including Canadian investors and
consumers, wins.


LOAD-DATE: January 9, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 1991 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
All Rights Reserved

 

229 of 1437 DOCUMENTS



The Globe and Mail (Canada)


October 8, 1991 Tuesday


Bounce is gone from the fitness boom AEROBICS " Instructors are using reggae and tai chi as ways of luring aging baby boomers back, as a once-popular activity once again begins reinventing itself. Sports shoe makers hope it succeeds


BYLINE: SUEIN L. HWANG; WSJ


LENGTH: 887 words


DATELINE: New York NY


BY SUEIN L. HWANG
The Wall Street Journal
New York
FORGET leg lifts and abdominal crunches. Today's aerobics instructors are
turning to reggae, tai chi, hip hop and even prayer to lure aging baby
boomers back into the fold.

"You wouldn't believe the goofy stuff we've seen," says Gordie Nye,
marketing director for Reebok International Ltd., which is always on the
lookout for new fitness routines that it can promote. 

Ten years ago, it took little more than a slim figure, a loud voice and
a disco beat to get fat-obsessed yuppies to go for the burn. Aerobics
routines, the invention of a California housewife, began with the simple
marriage of music and calisthenics. Aerobics introduced a generation of
women to the world of fitness and created a $1-billion (U.S.) market.

Now, the recession, concern about possible injury and general boredom
with aerobics have led to a slide in participation. A recent survey in the
United States by the National Sporting Goods Association found that the
number of people performing aerobics more than once in the past year has
fallen 2.8 per cent since 1985 and sales of aerobics footwear in 1990
dropped to 9.8 million pairs from 10.8 million in 1986.

Many sports researchers believe the aerobics boom has come and gone.
Many of the women who started working out in aerobics classes have been
lured away by stair-climbing machines, Rollerblading and other forms of
exercise.

"There's a faddist group among active people and they've already gone
on to a third and fourth thing," says Thomas Doyle, research director at
the National Sporting Goods Association.

But even skeptics concede that the aerobics industry has succeeded in
maintaining a loyal following by reinventing itself when necessary.

Aerobics routines, at one time little more than a series of kicks and
jumps, have grown more sophisticated, integrating jazzier moves and safer
"low-impact" approaches.

Some ambitious entrepreneurs are promoting what they hope will be the
next successful incarnation of aerobics. Reebok succeeded in promoting
step aerobics - stepping on and off an elevated bench - and now it is
willing to invest millions of dollars on promotion if it can come up with
a promising new form of exercise that will help sell sportswear.

What does it take to gain attention? First, find a gimmick. Reebok, of
Canton, Mass., experimented with a California-born notion called
Kneedspeed, in which the exerciser makes skating motions on a piece of
linoleum in stocking feet. But the company finally abandoned the concept
because it didn't seem to have strong appeal.

In Washington, D.C., the Synergy Studio offers a "holistic" approach.
"There's a spiritual need for people to connect with their bodies," says
Roger Piantadosi, co-owner of the studio.

Classes begin with meditative quiet and are designed around five
natural elements, such as water. In one recent class, a group of mostly
affluent professionals in their 30s pounded their bare feet to the beat of
African drums and slapped their stomachs while emitting hoarse grunts.
"Around the fire and the Earth," commanded instructor Charmaine Schore as
the women shook convulsively while lying on their backs. "Draw the spirit
to you!"

Synergy Studio grossed $195,000 in 1990, up 30 per cent from the year
before, and it now has plans to develop videos and train more instructors.

Others take a celestial approach.

As instructor Jeannie Blocher leads a class at Body & Soul Ministries
Inc. in Germantown, Md., the words to a song blare out: "It won't be long
'til we see Jesus. It won't be long 'til He'll be here, yeah, yeah."

This non-profit program counts more than 200 aerobics teachers in its
non-denominational clergy. Ms. Blocher hopes to expand the program and
plans a video release. "I would like to see it spread and just continue as
the Lord wishes," says the 42-year-old mother of three. "We call ourselves
Body and Soul Missionaries."

Deferring to the aging of their target market, many programs have
eliminated difficult jumping or kicking moves while focusing on new ethnic
beats. Esther Gutierrez-Sloan, a Colombian immigrant and president of
Salsarobics Inc., hopes her Latin-styled aerobics will help her rumba
right past the competition.

The former computer consultant is looking for outside investors to
finance an ambitious business plan that includes franchises and a line of
workout wear. "The music's very unique and culturally educational," she
says. "And it makes women feel sensual."

Not everybody's convinced that new forms of aerobics will have much
effect on demand. "Yes, you're going to bring in different kinds of
people," says Kathie Davis, executive director of IDEA, an industry group.
"But you aren't going to have a massive effect on the numbers."

Rather than promote specialized aerobics routines, Reebok rival Nike
Inc. is focusing on the versatility of its aerobics shoes.

Nike, of Beaverton, Ore., says sales of its cross-training shoes are up
"very significantly" from past years and it has started a marketing
campaign featuring its Elite aerobic shoes in a variety of workouts.

"Women do many things in their lives and a step-aerobics shoe isn't
that uniquely different" from other aerobics shoes, says Nike's aerobics
apparel marketing manager. "We can't all own five pairs of shoes."
Reprinted with permission of The Wall Street Journal
1991 Dow Jones & Co. Inc., all rights reserved


LOAD-DATE: January 9, 2007


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 1991 The Globe and Mail, a division of CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc.
All Rights Reserved

 

230 of 1437 DOCUMENTS



The Globe and Mail (Canada)


November 7, 1991 Thursday


Rocket could be in countdown for blastoff to Los Angeles


BYLINE: MARTY YORK; GAM


LENGTH: 845 words


BY MARTY YORK
IS the Rocket on the verge of flying off to the National Football League?

Well, one of the premier football reporters in the United States is
telling his viewers and readers that he has definite and irrefutable
information that Raghib Ismail - otherwise known as the Rocket - will be
employed in the NFL by next season.

"And maybe even before the end of this NFL season," Fred Edelstein said
in a telephone interview yesterday. 

"Every piece of information I have indicates that the length of
Rocket's career with the Toronto Argonauts will be exactly one season.

"He's on his way to the Los Angeles Raiders. I wouldn't be surprised,
in fact, if the Raiders have him in a uniform by next month."

Edelstein's track record on football scoops is outstanding. Viewers of
his weekly program on ESPN and readers of the well-circulated Edelstein
Pro Football Letter can attest to that.

And Don Crump didn't do much to dispel Edelstein's information when I
spoke to him yesterday. In fact, the Canadian Football League commissioner
backed it up pretty well when he admitted that Argo governor Sue Waks
recently told him in an angry moment that club owner Bruce McNall was
considering the notion of sending Ismail to the Raiders.

"She said, 'Don't think Bruce won't send Rocket over to Al,' " Crump
said. "She meant Al, as in Al Davis (owner of the Raiders).

"Who knows? If the Rocket leaves, maybe it'll be the start of a trend
for the CFL. Maybe a lot of big-name players will come over for one season
and then go to the NFL."

Reached in Los Angeles yesterday, Waks denied making any threats about
Ismail to Crump. She also said Ismail has enjoyed his rookie season with
the Argos and that she would be "shocked" if he jumped to the Raiders
after the CFL season.

Beverly Ballard, whom Ismail employs as a public-relations aide, echoed
Waks's sentiments, saying that the Rocket intends to honour all four
seasons of his $18-million, Argonaut contract.

"But what you must understand," Edelstein said, "is that the NFL and
the CFL are leagues of denial. They deny everything. It's just a mode of
operation for them. The fact that they deny something doesn't mean
anything.

"If I were operating the Argos, or if I were the Rocket, I'd deny the
whole thing, too. What purpose would it serve to confirm that he's leaving
right before the playoffs?

"But you can be sure it's happening. The Rocket will end up with about
$6-million from McNall and will then accept a deal for a lot less from
Davis.

"Hey, if things were gangbusters in Toronto, if the Argos were selling
out the place and there was Argomania, it would be incumbent to continue
the deal. But being that none of this has happened, that the signing
really hasn't produced an outstanding television deal in the States,
McNall has a nice parachute. He can just hand the Rocket over to the
Raiders, and the Rocket won't mind, no matter what anyone else says
publicly."

In the latest edition of his publication, Edelstein wrote:
"We hear Ismail is definitely hot on joining the Raiders next year. Our
sources say he is having fun in Canada and that his relationship with
Bruce McNall is pretty good. But the CFL isn't the NFL and Rocket
apparently misses the United States and the bright lights."

Technically, players are not permitted to toil in the CFL and NFL in
the same year.

"But," Edelstein said, "when it becomes clear that Rocket's not coming
back to Toronto and that he can get out of his CFL deal and his personal
services contract with McNall, it might be possible for the Raiders to
make a strong argument for getting him before the end of this year.

"From what I'm hearing out of the Raiders and people who are close to
the Rocket, this is the way it's going. I won't say it's a done deal, but
understand that Al Davis is a shrewd man. He knows that the Rocket wants
to play in the NFL. He knows exactly to the dime how much McNall is
losing. And he has a friendship with McNall in Los Angeles. He knows about
the escape clauses in Rocket's deal. This would not be a hostile
situation.

"Look, McNall has taken a bit of a bath on this thing. He took a
courageous shot and it didn't really pay off the way he'd hoped. The
easiest way to get out of this is to let Rocket go to the Raiders.

"By selecting Rocket in the last NFL draft, Al Davis has him exactly
where he wants him. He's not going to bring in the Rocket and pay him $3-
million a year. He doesn't have to. If he pays him any more than $1.5-
million a year, I'd be shocked."

Edelstein, incidentally, also reported that the Rocket has fired his
agent, Ed Abrams, over a decision to turn down a Nike commercial.

"Remember the recent Nike commercial with Bo Jackson dancing in a
broadway show set?" Edelstein wrote. "Sources close to the Ismail
situation say that was supposed to be Rocket's commercial.

"The way we hear it, Rocket's mother was furious over the decision to
blow off Nike and that the Rocket fired Abrams at his mother's urging."

Preferred Management, a firm put together in part by former tennis star
Arthur Ashe, is now handling Ismail's finances. And the firm apparently
has close ties with Al Davis.

231 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


February 13, 1991, Wednesday


Bankruptcy petition filed against Hickok's


BYLINE: By - Sonia Murraybusiness; closings; courts; transactions; economy; conditions


SECTION: BUSINESS; SECTION B; PAGE 09


LENGTH: 150 words


After market conditions and financing problems forced Hickok's Sporting Goods to close seven of its eight stores last month, three major creditors have dealt another blow to the 32-year-old business: an involuntary bankruptcy petition.

Russell Corp., Nike Inc. and Reebok International filed the Chapter 7 petition against the Atlanta-based chain last Friday in the federal bankruptcy court for the northern district of Georgia. 

An involuntary Chapter 7 petition is a way creditors can force a business into bankruptcy, sell off its assets and get their money back. The petition states Hickok's and its parent firm, the Young Group Inc., owe the Russell Corp. $ 456,405, Nike $ 377,914 and Reebok International $ 891,491 for goods sold and delivered.

Hickok's can either agree to the filing or try to fight it. Officials of the company said they were not prepared to comment.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

232 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


February 14, 1991, Thursday


GAMES & FACES; Bo knows just how to rock the media if he's on a roll


BYLINE: Tom Whitfieldsports; personalities


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION G; PAGE 02


LENGTH: 765 words


Among the things Bo Jackson knows is how to give the media short rations. But it was a different story this week in Portland, Ore., where Nike Inc., one of Jackson's many employers, decided to hold a news conference for high school journalists.

With two of his own children watching from a balcony above, Jackson charmed the group with stories about his poor upbringing in rural Alabama and how he became rich and famous.

His description of himself: "A nappy-headed kid who threw rocks better than some people could shoot a gun."; Caddyshack update

Occasionally, Sheryl Calcavecchia serves as caddie for her husband Mark at PGA Tour events. Noting that caddies' salaries often involve a percentage of the player's earnings, Mark observed:

"She's the only one I know of who gets 100 percent."; The Doctor is out 

In his new book "Valvano: They Gave Me a Lifetime Contract, and Then They Declared Me Dead," former N.C. State basketball coach Jim Valvano explains why he's working as a TV announcer instead of a scout.

In the late 1960s, while coaching the freshman team at Rutgers for Bill Foster, Valvano was sent to Long Island to check out a 6-foot-3 center touted by his brother. Valvano wasn't impressed, and here's the rest of the story:

"Oh, the kid visited Rutgers on his own anyway and still seemed very interested, but I convinced Foster he couldn't play at our level and that we should go after another player named Alan Cotler.

"I lost Cotler to Penn. He's now a lawyer in Philadelphia. I lost track of the other kid. He was in Philly, too, but I think he became a doctor or something. You ever hear of him? Kid's name is Julius Erving."; A fresh start

Rudy Galindo is back at the U.S. Figure Skating Championships this year, but as a solo performer, rather than as a defending pairs champion, now that his former partner, Kristi Yamaguchi, has decided to concentrate on her solo career.

Galindo has made one more adjustment in returning to singles for the first time since 1988: The spelling of his first name.

"I had changed it from Rudy to Rudi to match with Kristi," he said. "I'm into a new life and wanted everything to be fresh. So I'm back to Rudy."

Galindo smiles, jokes and avoids saying anything that could be construed as sour grapes about the end of his pairing with Yamaguchi. But it's apparent he was hurt by the parting.

"It's kind of hard to be out there by yourself," Galindo said this week as he prepared for the start of the championships. "A few times, I went to grab Kristi's hand, and it was not there."; A K' for history

Mark it down for posterity: Reid Ryan, 19-year-old son of Nolan, struck out the first batter he faced as a freshman at the University of Texas. The victim was a friend, Shayne Currin of Texas-Arlington, who spends his summers as bullpen catcher for the Texas Rangers.

Reid Ryan's fastball was clocked in the 85 mph range, and his curveball was sharp as he pitched two innings, giving up one run.

His dad didn't make the 150-mile trip from Alvin to Austin for the debut. But they'll see each other April 2 as opposing pitchers in an exhibition game.; He's learning fast

From the Associated Press: When Wayne Gretzky turned 30 last month, Los Angeles Kings owner Bruce McNall gave him a horse they saw being born while they were at the Kentucky Derby.

Gretzky and McNall are partners in the racing business, so Gretzky gave half back to McNall.

"I kept the front half, because I have learned that is the one that crosses the finish line first," joked Gretzky.; For the record . . .

- Canada's Helen Kelesi rallied from a 3-0 deficit in the third set to upset third-seeded Jana Novotna 2-6, 7-6, 7-6 in the second round of the Virginia Slims of Chicago tennis tournament. No. 2 seed Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria won her match against Ann Grossman.

- Boris Becker beat Alexander Volkov 6-4, 3-6, 6-3 in the opening round of the Donnay Indoor Championship in Brussels, Belgium.

- MaliVai Washington beat No. 16 seed Patrick McEnroe 6-0, 6-3 to advance to the quarterfinals of the $ 1 million U.S. Pro Indoor Tennis Championship in Philadelphia. (Complete tennis results, G9).

- As many as 50 intramural male and female basketball teams from area colleges will meet in the Schick Super Hoops Regional Festival on Feb. 23 at Georgia State. The top male and female teams from the one-day tournament will play their championship games March 23 at The Omni as part of the Hawks-Miami game.

Got a tip for Games & Faces? Give us a call on the message line at 222-2034.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: photo: Jim Valvano Lost a legend photo: Bo Jackson Charming for Nike photo: Mark Calcavecchia Creative bookkeeping


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

233 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


February 22, 1991, Friday


Bo sells - even if he's hurt; Jackson attraction a hot market item


BYLINE: By Jeff Schultz Staff writeradvertising; baseball; football; personalities; atlanta; sports; equipment; meetings


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION H; PAGE 01


LENGTH: 533 words


The room was a blur of silk suits, highball glasses and eggrolls. The smell of merchandising was in the air.

"Ladies and gentlemen, it's my pleasure to introduce . . ."

Of course, everybody at the Diversified Products (DP) cocktail and elbow-rubbing party Thursday night already knew which advertising vehicle was about to glide into the room. They had just seen a 10-minute video of Bo making a running catch in the outfield, Bo running for a touchdown, Bo breaking a bat over his knee, Bo scoring for Auburn, Bo doing that Arsenio thing, Bo filming a Nike commercial, Bo chugging a sports drink, Bo pushing AT&T and Cheerios and Pepsi. 

. . . "Bo Jackson!" DP president Cal James, completing his introduction, said to his audience of some 300 buyers at the Westin Peachtree Plaza Hotel.

Jackson didn't so much glide into the room as he hobbled. He hobbled everywhere Thursday. The man of two sports and a zillion products was on crutches, the result of a hip injury last month in a Los Angeles Raiders playoff game. He will be on crutches for four weeks and may, according to a team doctor for his other employer, the Kansas City Royals, miss the season opener.

But that didn't stop the dominant sports figure from enhancing his dominant marketing presence. Jackson flew into Atlanta from Auburn about 1 p.m. and in the next eight hours: (1) posed for publicity pictures with a young boy for the March of Dimes, (2) held a fireside chat with top Nike executives and buyers in conjunction with the Super Show (he was not out for public or media display), (3) was introduced as the part owner and product spokesman for "Bo Med," a sports medicine line manufactured by Cramer Products, at a Georgia World Congress Center news conference, (4) was introduced in grand style at the Westin as part owner and chief spokesman for a new line of weightlifting equipment to be manufactured by DP.

And then? Bo hobbled into a waiting limo at about 9 p.m. and was whisked to the airport, where he caught a return flight to Auburn. Why the rush?

"He has a final exam to take tomorrow," said Susann McKee, who as an associate to Jackson's agent, Richard Woods, is charged with making sure Bo knows punctuality. "He's still working on his degree in child and family development."

Bo needs no courses on income development. He will earn nearly $ 4 million in the next baseball and football seasons from the Royals ($ 2.375 million) and the Raiders ($ 1.6175 million) - and that is dwarfed by his off-field(s) earnings. Bo also has become quite polished on speaking to business executives.

But he wouldn't discuss his injury Thursday. Royals trainer Steve Joyce said Jackson "isn't in the mild injury category." But when asked at the "Bo Med" gathering if he would be ready in time for the Royals season opener, Jackson said, "Man, I'm not here to talk about that."

However, when explaining the advantages of his "Bo Med" ankle brace, Jackson joked, "We need to make one of these for a hip injury."

More jokes flowed at the DP cocktail party. "I never knew DP made more weights than anybody in the country," Bo said. "See, that's something Bo doesn't know."


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

234 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


March 29, 1991, Friday


Is the Shark' ready to test NBA waters?


BYLINE: By Ailene Voisin Staff writersports; basketball; las/vegas; leaders; forecasts; profiles; personalities; records


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION G; PAGE 01


LENGTH: 1434 words


Jerry Tarkanian's friends are as diverse as they are loyal, their presence never more than a plane flight or phone call away. One owns a hair salon in Las Vegas. Another is the ex-husband of actress Diahann Carroll. Still another is a Nike executive who treads lightly anywhere near the NCAA. Others are more high profile - Bobby Knight and John Thompson, Dick Vitale, and a large number of coaches and scouts from the NBA.

Yet as Nevada-Las Vegas pursues its second consecutive national championship this weekend in Indianapolis, Tarkanian's friends join his foes in wondering whether the NCAA's pursuit of the embattled coach - and anticipated sanctions at season's end - finally will prompt either his retirement or a departure to the NBA.

Tark isn't telling.

Perhaps it's because he himself is uncertain. On a given day, he professes to be a college coaching lifer, best suited for 40 minutes of frenzy and 30-odd games in a community that is appreciative, if not always approving, of his methods. (He has his detractors in Las Vegas, too.) Yet, on another day, Tarkanian ponders life after Vegas. 

"Maybe I should go to the NBA," he offers, frowning. "I don't need all this."

At 60, Tarkanian clearly could rest on his coaching laurels. He has a career record of 811-145, is the second-winningest active Division I coach with 598 victories and has guided the Runnin' Rebels to 45 consecutive wins, one NCAA title and a second straight trip to the Final Four.

He earns $ 203,000 in salary, $ 200,000 for a shoe contract and approximately $ 250,000 in free tickets to UNLV games. But he also has received 19 years of intense scrutiny and an assortment of penalties levied by the NCAA. This year, for instance, the Rebels were banned from appearing on television in 1992 and from participating in the postseason tournament, sanctions levied for violations dating back to the 1970s. The Rebels also are confronting 29 new allegations pertaining to the recruitment of New York prep star Lloyd Daniel, and reportedly are being investigated again for the recruitment of Los Angeles area prep star Ed O'Bannon.

"There is no program in the country that receives one-tenth the scrutiny we do," said Tarkanian. "Every player who leaves our program, they are trying to find something on. Our kids don't deserve this."

But does Tarkanian? While his national image may be tarnished, he enjoys surprisingly strong support from unlikely sources, including Thompson, Knight, former UCLA coach John Wooden, former Cal coach Pete Newell, Seton Hall's P.J. Carlesimo and Utah's Rick Majerus. "I'm not anti-NCAA or anything," Majerus said recently, "but most of the coaches really like Tark. They think he's a good guy, a very decent person."

Accordingly, those close to him are alert for signs of trouble, for any indications that the pressure finally has worn him down. Yet they say none is visible. Tarkanian has no hair to lose (he shaves his head), is not a heavy drinker and remains in relatively good shape for his years. Even his warm and engaging personality, they maintain, has remained consistent, as has his professional persona.

While Tarkanian capitalizes on every opportunity to publicly flail the NCAA for its "McCarthyism" and plead his case to every reporter and for any interested publication, he responds to attacks on his program and his character with an amazing grace. For those who have yet to meet Tarkanian, the publicity staff schedules individual interviews like an all-comers' meet: You come to UNLV, you meet Tark. And even his most relentless critics relate how he continues to accept their phone calls, and often engages them in conversation.

"Jerry doesn't stay mad at anybody," said UNLV publicist Joe Hawk.

A former Las Vegas Review-Journal reporter who wrote a damaging article in December 1989 about the high-priced cars several of the Rebel players were driving around town, Hawk subsequently was hired as the school's sports information director without opposition from Tarkanian. "It was a little awkward at first," said Hawk, "but Jerry's been very good to me."

If anyone appears to have succumbed to the pressure, it would be a few of the players, though even this is arguable. After Hawk's story broke, Stacey Augmon and Larry Johnson initiated a team-wide ban on speaking to the media, though most of the Rebels relented during last year's postseason tournament. Augmon again refused to speak with reporters for most of this past season, despite encouragement to do so by Tarkanian.

To a player, the Rebels remain true to their coach and his cause. At times, Johnson said, the controversy served only to strengthen their resolve and unite an already close-knit group. Before the tip-off of each game during the NCAA Tournament, for instance, the players embrace quietly, seemingly for themselves rather than for effect.

Tarkanian, too, sees this, and it makes him wonder even further about the NBA. At UNLV, he rules not unlike Knight, Thompson, or any number of other major-college coaches. He controls. He dictates. He doesn't like a player, the player isn't around the following year. He doesn't like the schedule, the schedule is altered. He doesn't like the uniforms, new ones are on order.

Can he claim this power in the NBA? Not likely, and he knows it.

"I just don't see him leaving," Sonny Vaccaro, the Nike executive, said last weekend in Seattle. "He's got it made in Vegas. Why would he want to leave?"

What if the NCAA assesses a lengthy penalty based on various allegations involving Lloyd Daniels and others?

"I . . . still don't see him leaving," persisted Vaccaro.

Yet the speculation continues. Within the past few months, he has been rumored reuniting with former Long Beach State athletics director Fred Miller at San Diego State, although that possibility appears moot now that head coach Jim Brandenburg signed a one-year contract extension. Tarkanian's name also has been linked to a pair of the NBA's troubled franchises, the Denver Nuggets and Los Angeles Clippers.

One current NBA head coach - another friend of Tarkanian's - says that coaching in the NBA "would kill Tark. He could never accept all the losses." Atlanta Hawks general manager Pete Babcock notes that "coaches who have been very successful, and used to winning 90 percent of games, come into the league and you don't win 90 percent of your games. All of the ex-college coaches I've talked to acknowledge how shocked they are at how different and how demanding the game is."

As for Tarkanian, "He's definitely capable," continued Babcock. "He's an outstanding coach. If you look at his team, his team concept of defense is so impressive. He does a terrific job. But typically, a new NBA head coach goes to a struggling team. Would he want that?"; Runnin' Rebels trivia

The Runnin' Rebels' unblemished 27-0 regular-season record was the first in Division I since Alcorn State and Indiana State in 1979. Larry Bird's Indiana State team went 33-1, the sole defeat was against Magic Johnson's Michigan State club in the NCAA title game. The rest, as they say, is history.

- According to the 1990-91 media guide, reserve forward Chris Jeter of Morse High in San Diego was recruited by Georgia and lists his favorite player as the Atlanta Hawks' Cliff Levingston, who was his "Big Brother" during his childhood. Someone forgot to mention that Levingston changed teams in the offseason.

- Seldom-used guard David Rice made the only start of his career Feb. 23 against UC Irvine - on the annual Seniors Night. While the NBA will not come calling, law schools will. Rice was a Rhodes Scholar finalist with a 3.96 grade point average in business and political science.

- Besides improving his overall shooting percentage from .553 to .594 this season, Stacey Augmon bettered his 3-point accuracy from .320 to .458, further enhancing his prospects as an NBA lottery pick.

- Coach Jerry Tarkanian says that reserve center Elmore Spencer of Atlanta, a former Georgia Bulldog, has always excelled in practice, but struggled in games. "Poor Elmore," said Tarkanian. "One of these games he's going to play well, though." He did, being named Player of the Game against Utah.

- UNLV was limited to single-digits in offensive rebounding only three times this season, but twice against schools from New Jersey. The Rebels claimed a season-low four offensive rebounds against Princeton and nine against Rutgers. They also were held to five against New Mexico State.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: photo: Mug of Elmore Spencer - Former 'Dog is Rebels' backup center. photo: Mug of Cliff Levingston - He was Chris Jeter's "Big Brother". photo: Stacey Augmon - Enhanced 3-point average, NBA prospects. color photo: Mug of Jerry Tarkanian has the respect of many of his leading coaching peers. / Allsport / color chart: Final Four Spotlight: UNLV - If the Runnin' Rebels win the national championship, they will tie UCLA for the third-longest winning streak in NCAA history. Team ........... Years ........ Wins 1. UCLA ....... 1971-74 ......... 88 2. San Francisco 1955-57 ......... 60 3. UCLA ....... 1966-68 ......... 47 4. UNLV ....... 1989-91 ......... 45 5. Texas ...... 1913-17 ......... 44
