The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


February 4, 1991, Monday


CRIME SCENE; Apartment burglar goes for clothes, ignores the stereo


SECTION: EXTRA; SECTION J; PAGE 03


LENGTH: 398 words


A burglar broke into a unit at the Asbury Apartments on Jimmy Carter Boulevard Sunday morning and left with more than $ 3,000 in clothes and shoes, a Gwinnett County police report showed.

The resident returned to her unit to find the front door standing open and clothes and debris scattered inside, police said.

Items stolen included five men's sweaters, five pairs of men's pants, four pairs of shoes, six pairs of jeans, six dresses, three suits, a Nike sporting jacket and an AT&T cordless phone. 

An extensive home entertainment system in the living room was not touched.

Police said they have no suspects.

TRAFFIC STOP IS A BUST: Lilburn police arrested three people on drug charges during a traffic stop Sunday, jail records showed. All three are being held without bond in the Gwinnett County Jail in Lawrenceville.

Arrested were James Leonard Roland, 39, of 4074 Stergan Drive in Buford, charged with two counts of drug possession; Terry Ray Gillespie, 29, of 5320 Sycamore Drive in Lawrenceville, charged with one count of possession of methamphetamine and one count of marijuana possession; and Elise Doreen LaForgia, 41, of 1211 Daniel Lane in Lawrenceville, charged with one count each of violation of the Georgia Controlled Substances Act, DUI, failure to maintain lane and possession of methamphetamine.

Police stopped the car because the driver, Ms. LaForgia, was weaving, Sgt. Mike Puglise said. More than 15 grams of methamphetamine, packaged and ready for distribution, were confiscated, he said.

Police went to the woman's home, where they found more evidence of methamphetamine distribution, Sergeant Puglise said.

ARREST IN ABDUCTION CASE: A Snellville man was arrested Sunday and charged with kidnapping a Jonesboro woman after giving her a ride, jail records show.

Tony Clarence Parker, 35, of 3866 Lenora Church Road allegedly beat Jody Marie Kersey with a leather strap and then held her against her will, records show.

He also has been charged with aggravated assault, records show.

The alleged incident occurred about a month ago, according to GBI Agent Billy Shepherd. The GBI investigated the case at the request of Walton County because the alleged abduction began there, Agent Shepherd said.

The suspect was released later Sunday after posting $ 50,100 bail.

Staff writer Hollis R. Towns compiled this report.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

349 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


February 21, 1991, Thursday


BRAVES NOTEBOOK; Justice given record pay for a second-year player


BYLINE: By I.J. Rosenberg Staff writeratlanta/braves; baseball; personnel; salaries


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION G; PAGE 09


LENGTH: 307 words


WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. - The Atlanta Braves rewarded National League rookie of the year David Justice with a $ 195,000 raise Wednesday, signing the outfielder to a one-year contract worth $ 297,000. 

Justice's deal is the biggest in major-league history for a player entering his second season, according to his agent, Eric Goldschmidt.

"The most a player had gotten before, going into his second season, was Baltimore pitcher Gregg Olson," said Goldschmidt, a Los Angeles- based agent who also represents Eric Davis and Darryl Strawberry.

Olson, who won the American League Rookie of the Year Award in 1989, made $ 270,000 last year.

Justice, who made $ 102,000 in 1990, hit .282 with 29 home runs and 81 RBIs. H e blossomed after the trade of Dale Murphy, replacing him in right field and hitting 11 home runs during a 16-game span in August.

"This just goes along with everything else that is happening in baseball as far as the pay scale," said Braves general manager John Schuerholz. "But I'm not saying David doesn't deserve it, because he had a great season."

Justice also has become marketable off the field. His marketing agent, Mike DeSola of PrimeTime Sports Marketing in New York, said Justice has made $ 100,000 from endorsements and autograph shows.

"He's the hottest sport commodity in Atlanta," said DeSola. "He has a deal with Nike shoes and Easton batting gloves, and by the time he goes to spring training, we will have worked a glove deal with either Rawlings or Regent."

With the signing of Justice, the Braves now have 11 players on their 40-man roster not under contract: pitchers John Smoltz, Steve Avery, Tony Castillo, Kent Mercker and Paul Marak; catchers Greg Olson and Kelly Mann; infielders Jeff Blauser, Mark Lemke and Francisco Cabrera, and outfielder/first baseman Tommy Gregg


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

350 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


February 24, 1991, Sunday


IDEAS; Choosing best route to safety; Should teenagers be allowed to drive high-performance cars?


BYLINE: By Celia Sibley Staff writerSgt. T.L. HunterGeorge G. ThompsonCecil GoberRenee Crocker, volunteer,Renee S. UntermanNancy NealEmmett LawsonJanice WestBobbie DillonMarketta SmiddyCarole Hayspublic; opinion; teenagers; automotive; safety; accidents; gwinnett/county; deaths


SECTION: EXTRA; SECTION J; PAGE 11


LENGTH: 1126 words


A Nike tennis shoe in the roadway recently was grim evidence of a tragic accident that killed a mother, a Brookwood High School senior and a former student.

The teen driving one of the vehicles, a late-model Pontiac Bonneville SSE, was speeding up to 70 mph on a residential street when he lost control and crashed head-on into the woman's van, police said. The mother was heading to Brookwood to pick up her daughter.

"What caused that wreck is what I refer to as the testosterone level. The driver apparently couldn't resist using the power of his vehicle," George W. Black Jr., Gwinnett's director of transportation, said later. 

The Feb. 7 crash pushed the number of Brookwood classmates who have died in car wrecks in the last three years to 12.

Once again, parents, teens and other members of the community were jolted into re-examining the problem of teen driving habits, something a community task force has been doing since September.

The task force, composed of police, legislators, students, parents and teachers at Brookwood, has proposed more than 12 ideas for parents to help make their teens safer drivers.

They concluded parents should not help teens buy fast cars, should boost teen awareness of driving safety and should not let teens drive after midnight.

While the task force is committed to stemming the tide of teen driving deaths, many students seem fatalistic and unconvinced safety measures can help.

When asked what could stop the carnage, one Brookwood junior said too many teens are unsafe drivers but she didn't think anything could be done about it.

A senior noted all cars will go 70 mph or 80 mph - more than fast enough to kill someone.

Another senior said his driver's education class didn't spend much time on safety.

But school officials said safety is definitely a large portion of the course.

"What a student interprets as not being safety really might be safety," said Dan Chelko, Brookwood's community school director.

Do you think it would help if teens were not allowed to drive high- performance cars?; Don't lay the blame on car

I don't think you can blame the car unless it's an equipment malfunction. I think the drivers, they err in their judgment, and that's what causes the collision.

I haven't seen a car yet that won't go fast enough to kill you. We have teenagers killed in VW Beetles and in Bonnevilles. The car doesn't have a whole lot to do with it. They're going to show off no matter what they are driving. Just like a buck deer when they're in rut, they'll kick up their heels, they'll drop their guard. That's how hunters manage to kill them. Same with a kid. They are not thinking, and that's what kills them.

Traffic division supervisor, Gwinnett police; Help teens resist pressure

No. Such a prohibition should be part of a more comprehensive approach that includes helping teens and parents resist the social pressures that cause them to want such cars.

Gwinnett school superintendent; Kids shouldn't have cars

I don't think they should because they don't use good judgment.

If I had a car when I was that age, I might not have been living today. Because I was wild too. And the best way to hold a kid back at that age until they mature more is to not allow them to have those cars, those machines.

Former school board member; Driver's safety course first

If they can afford to pay for them and pay for the insurance and the gas, yes, and after they have taken a driver's safety course.

Hopkins Elementary School; Do what some colleges do

I don't know. I think one way a solution could be reached would be the same way they do it in college. In the university system, students are not allowed to drive if they are freshmen. I feel like if a high school system would implement that, let them reach their junior and senior years, then they could drive any kind of vehicle as long as they've proved their responsibility.

Gwinnett commissioner; Leave it up to teens, parents

I think that should be a parental and teen decision, not a legislative decision.

I don't think it would change the accident rate. Responsible driver education and more parental control over the car would reduce the accident rate.

I had a Mustang. My parents exercised extreme control. And I had no problem, no tickets, no accidents. Not only should teens be held responsible, parents should be responsible. And if they can't handle it, then teens should not be allowed to have the car.

Former president, Gwinnett Association of Educators; These autos made to speed

That was one of the recommendations that we published that we discourage parents from helping young people buy high-performance cars. One of the reasons is there is a tendency with high-performance vehicles to drive fast because that is basically what the cars are made for, high speed. We are concerned in many instances that driver skills do not correspond with the power under the hood, that they can't control it.

There is a lot of peer pressure. Parents, in order for their young persons to be popular, will just not use good common sense as far as parenting skills are concerned.

Brookwood High School principal; Vehicles don't kill, drivers do

I don't have a problem about that. My husband does. We are a very divided household. It was funny you're asking because we were talking about it last night, my son and I on one side and my husband on the other side of the fence. Basically, I feel like the person should have respect for whatever vehicle they're driving, whether it's a bicycle or Trans Am. You have to know your limitations and ability to control that vehicle. I don't see that the vehicle kills; it is the driver.

13th District director, Georgia PTA; They are too dangerous'

No. I feel they are too dangerous. I feel they are inexperienced to drive something that is high performance. I don't think they are responsible to be under control in all situations.

Peachtree Elementary and Norcross High parent; At this age, there's no fear

I don't believe that they should be. At this age they have no fear. I just don't think they are mature enough to handle a high-performance car. The reason they have so many of these high-performance cars is peer pressure, and I feel like the parents are responsible for giving in and allowing these children to have these cars.

Norcross High School parent; Bad for safety, insurance

I think for their own safety it's not a good idea, especially beginning drivers because they need to get more experience in a less powerful car. I think for economic reasons it wouldn't be a wise decision for a teenager to own one of those cars because of the high insurance.

Norcross High School parent

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


March 17, 1991, Sunday


Anderson up against Buckeye buddy


BYLINE: By Darryl Maxie Staff writergeorgia/tech; personalities; basketball; competition; colleges


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION E; PAGE 06


LENGTH: 410 words


DAYTON, Ohio - Because of unwanted calls, Georgia Tech guard Kenny Anderson has changed his telephone number four times this season. Ohio State's Jim Jackson has gotten it every time.

The only time Anderson hopes Jackson won't have his number is today at the University of Dayton Arena, when the Yellow Jackets (17-12) meet the Buckeyes (26-3) in the second round of the NCAA Midwest Regional (Channel 5, 12:20 p.m.). 

Anderson makes sure Jackson, the Buckeyes' leading scorer, has his phone number because the two are good friends. Still, the Ohio State forward has a score to settle with him dating to their high school days, when Anderson was at Archbishop Molloy in New York and Jackson was at Macomber in Toledo, Ohio.

Their paths crossed at a tournament in Myrtle Beach, S.C., during their junior years. Anderson's team won by 20, though neither says he can remember the exact score.

"We met at a Nike invitational camp at Princeton and I wanted to meet him because we came out rated the No. 1 and No. 2 players at the camp ," said Jackson, the No. 2. "We found out we were going to play at Myrtle Beach. They beat us by 20, but the friendship continued."

It was in full force Saturday, when they twice interrupted interviews with hordes of reporters to trade handshakes and their Dayton hotel phone numbers.

"We don't get into all that game stuff for Sunday, like I'm going to beat you,' " Anderson said. "Well, during the course of the game, I'll let him know. But I never thought it would come to this. Once I looked at the bracket and saw we were in their regional, I figured we probably will wind up playing each other."

Their versions of the last time they met differ slightly. Said Anderson, "He had 40 points and 20 rebounds, I had 40 points and two assists. It was really an exciting game, just battling it out."

Said Jackson, "I had 35 points, 20 rebounds and he had like 38. But this game Sunday is a little bit different. More's on the line right now. I want to win. If he scores 50 and we win, that's cool. If he scores 50 and we lose, that's a different story."

Tech's second-round game last year featured Anderson against another high-profile Jackson - Chris of LSU. As he did before that game, Anderson is shying away from the hype that today's contest will become a one-on- one affair.

"It's going to be Georgia Tech vs. Ohio State and I'm going to be ready for the challenge," Anderson said.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


March 19, 1991, Tuesday


EARNINGS REPORT; NATIONAL EARNINGS; R.H. Macy & Co.


SECTION: BUSINESS; SECTION C; PAGE 07


LENGTH: 279 words


R.H. Macy & Co. reported a loss of $ 7.3 million, or $ 9.12 per share, for the second quarter ended Feb. 2 before an extraordinary gain of $ 85.3 million, compared with a loss of $ 39 million, or $ 27.67 a share, for the same period a year ago.

The company reported net income of $ 78 million, or $ 43.10 per share, for the second quarter, after the gain, which involved the purchase of debt. Sales for the quarter were $ 2.2 billion, compared with $ 2.44 billion a year ago.

For the six-month period, the New York-based retailer - which has 10 stores in metro Atlanta - lost $ 74 million, or $ 53.87 a share, before a $ 95.5 million gain.

It lost $ 72.2 million, or $ 51.58 a share, in the same period a year ago. Net income was $ 21.5 million, or $ 4.58 a share, after the gain. Sales for the period were $ 3.74 billion, compared with $ 4.15 billion a year ago.; Other earnings:

Nike Inc., third quarter: Reported earnings of $ 70.67 million, or 93 cents per share, compared with $ 63.1 million, or 83 cents per share, a year ago.

Federal Express, third quarter: Reported a loss of $ 105.64 million, or $ 1.98 per share, compared with earnings of $ 5.21 million, or 10 cents per share, a year ago.; TAKING STOCK

L.A. Gear announced a new credit line with its banks Monday, eight weeks after the No. 3 sneaker maker disclosed that a quarterly loss would put it in technical default on its loan agreement.

The new agreement will cut L.A. Gear's available credit from $ 360 million to $ 300 million. It is subject to final documentation, which the company said was expected to be completed by the end of March.

- From staff and wire reports

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


March 20, 1991, Wednesday


When cheering stops


SECTION: EDITORIAL; SECTION A; PAGE 14


LENGTH: 187 words


His spectacular stardom as a major league outfielder and a National Football League running back defied the sportswriters, the color commentators and other assorted wags who said it couldn't be done. But now the conventional wisdom has apparently caught up with Bo Jackson. 

In an announcement as sudden and stunning as one of his mammoth home runs or 90-yard touchdowns, the Kansas City Royals baseball team said it was releasing Jackson because of a devastating hip injury he suffered playing football. His career with the NFL's Los Angeles Raiders may also be over.

Jackson vows to come back, and perhaps he will be able to do the unexpected again. But the man whose seemingly invincible athletic prowess was summed up by the Nike TV commercial's phrase "Bo knows" now seems destined to be another of those American stars whose careers, like comets, blaze brightly before dying out all too soon.

Bo Jackson had a $ 2,375,000 salary with the Royals. Because of his injury, the club is offering him to any team for $ 1. Young hero worshippers dreaming of sports glory should note the difference.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

354 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


March 23, 1991, Saturday


SPORTS BUSINESS


BYLINE: DAVID DAVIDSON; Total injury to Bo's pocketbook could be $ 100 million or moresports; business; baseball; football; earnings; health; cities; attempts


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION D; PAGE 09


LENGTH: 537 words


Bo Jackson has moved into the category of damaged goods, and his hip injury could cost the football/baseball all-star $ 100 million or more in long-term salary and endorsement revenue if he is unable to continue his professional career.

That's the opinion of Bob Hope, a former Atlanta Braves executive who now is executive vice president of the Burson-Marsteller public relations firm in New York.

Jackson's biggest loss of income would be from his Nike shoe/apparel contract, currently estimated at $ 2.8 million per year. His total endorsement income this year is estimated at $ 4 million. Nike has said it would not cancel its current contract with Jackson, but the company can drop him when the deal expires after 1993. 

Because he was waived by the Kansas City Royals, Jackson will draw only one-sixth of his $ 2.375 million salary this year, but he will get his full $ 1.6 million salary from the L.A. Raiders since NFL teams are prohibited from waiving players hurt while playing football.

Were Jackson, 28, able to play 10 more seasons, his income likely would have totaled more than $ 100 million, according to Hope.

Even if Jackson is able to play baseball later this season, watch for Nike to back off gradually and introduce a replacement, such as former Notre Dame wide receiver Rocket Ismail.

MEMPHIS MONEY: Just because Federal Express owner Fred Smith has withdrawn from the ownership picture in the Memphis bid for an NFL franchise doesn't mean the city has abandoned its effort. Smith, alarmed that no one had taken the lead in generating community support necessary for a city to land a franchise, decided to do it himself. That leaves two promising ownership candidates: Billy Donovant, owner of a cotton brokerage firm that does $ 1.2 billion of business annually, and Wall Street commodities broker Paul Tudor Jones, famous for making $ 37 million in one day after the 1989 stock market crash. . . . Preliminary results of an NFL study under way by economists at the University of South Florida indicate that the Super Bowl's economic impact to Tampa was between $ 50 millionand $ 65 million, a long way from the $ 125 million advance estimate. War in the Persian Gulf, economic recession and a one- week period between the conference championships and the Super Bowl were t

HEAD OF THE CLASS: As an assignment for a sports administration course he teaches at the University of California, Andy Dolich - executive vice president of the Oakland A's - had six groups of students make presentations on the six cities aspiring for a major league baseball franchise. The class then voted on the city it thought should get the first team. The winner was Miami. . . . Two sellout games between the Yankees and Orioles at Miami's Joe Robbie Stadium on Easter/Passover weekend - one of the toughest draw potentials of the year - show Miami's interest in a baseball franchise. . . . According to U.S. Olympic Committee executive director Harvey Schiller, the 22 companies that have put up nearly $ 22 million to be designated official USOC licensees through 1992 in support of the U.S. teams in Barcelona will generate some $ 400 million in retail sales.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


March 24, 1991, Sunday


WEST NOTEBOOK; Tark: UNLV appeals to the masses


BYLINE: By Ailene Voisin Staff writersports; basketball; personalities; competition; health; conditions; forecasts


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION E; PAGE 11


LENGTH: 432 words


SEATTLE - Because of what he terms "ongoing harassment" by the NCAA, UNLV coach Jerry Tarkanian believes the Runnin' Rebels have become symbols for the working class and the oppressed.

"I think all the guys that are truck drivers and construction workers all love the Rebels," he said. "Beer drinkers are Rebel fans. If you go in the inner city, I think they're Rebel fans. It just depends. I think probably if you went into Beverly Hills, they're UCLA fans. South Dallas is pulling for the Rebels. So is the inner city of Detroit, Pasadena and the westside of Vegas." 

JOHNSON MOST OUTSTANDING: UNLV forward Larry Johnson was named Most Outstanding Player of the West regional and was joined on the All- Tournament team by teammates Stacey Augmon and guard Greg Anthony and Seton Hall guard Terry Dehere and Arizona center Brian Williams.

WEST VS. WEST: The ongoing feud between Tarkanian and Arizona's Lute Olson, which can be traced back to Olson's recruiting of Tom Tolbert out of Cerritos College, apparently has influenced players on both teams. After the Rebels won the subregional in Tucson, the players left an autographed basketball - "UNLV No. 1" - in the Wildcats locker room. "It took a lot of gall for them to do that," said Arizona forward Brian Williams, adding that the Wildcats brought the ball with them to Seattle for motivation.

Well, so much for motivation. The Wildcats were run off by Seton Hall.

AROUND THE DOME: Seton Hall coach P.J. Carlesimo is moving slowly these days. He reportedly tore cartilage in his knee while jumping up and down at the Big East tournament and will require arthroscopic surgery . . . Nike executive Sonny Vaccaro - a close friend of both Tarkanian and Carlesimo - refuses to say with whom he's siding. But Vaccaro was less reluctant to take a shot at the NCAA, which, he says, complains about the company's sneaker deals with coaches but has never initiated a conversation. "If it bothers them that all that money goes to coaches, and they're so concerned with academics, why don't they come up with a proposal where 25 percent or so goes directly to tutorial programs for the players?" Vaccaro said.

LAZY BOYS? Utah coach Rick Majerus remained in Seattle to watch the UNLV-Seton Hall matchup and enjoy the "big time" for a few days. Among other things, Majerus proclaimed the chairs used for the interview sessions were of higher quality than those at the subregional in Tucson. "We were sitting on folding chairs in Arizona," he said. "What do they get at the Final Four, Lazy Boy recliners?"

May 7, 1991, Tuesday


SPORTS: NOTEBOOKS; Triathletes in top form


BYLINE: Stan Awtreysports; soccer; competition; results; gwinnett/county


SECTION: EXTRA; SECTION J; PAGE 19


LENGTH: 208 words


Gwinnett competitors dominated the Ironkids Triathlon at DeKalb College South Campus. Ryan Posener of Lilburn won the senior boys division and earned a trip to the national meet in Texas this summer. 

Posener won the 14-year-old division, and his time was best among those 11-14. Other local age-group winners were: Michael Eddy of Duluth, 11; Justin Stevenson of Lilburn, 12; Mark Olsen of Lawrenceville, 13; Christopher Eddy of Duluth, 7; and Emily Armond of Snellville, 8. . . .

The West Gwinnett Soccer Camp will be June 17-21 and Aug. 12-16 for boys and girls 4-16. Cost is $ 75. To register call 972-5630. . . .

The seventh annual Nike Tournament for under-19, and high school teams, will be May 25 at The Soccer Academy in Lilburn. . . . Tryouts for Team Atlanta gymnastics will be June 28-29 at Emory University. The goal is to place a local gymnast on the U.S. Olympic team in 1996. See your local gym coach for information or call 978-3924. . . . The Northeast Georgia Sports Festival of the Georgia State Games will be June 22-30 at Briscoe Park in Snellville. Winners in each division will play in the championships beginning July 19.

(To report youth sports information, call 222-2049 or fax to us at 263-3011.)

AREA SOFTBALL; Mr. Benz Players starting fast at Wilkerson Park


SECTION: EXTRA; SECTION K; PAGE 11


LENGTH: 245 words


WHO'S HOT: Mr. Benz Players of Atlanta is leading the Men's Industrial League at Wilkerson Mill Park in Fairburn with a 4-1 record. Leading the women's league are Mr. Video of Fairburn and Warehouse Grocery of College Park with 4-1 records. The men's league is led by Hot Springs of Riverdale with a 4-1 record. . . . Chamblee's D and S Packing Homeboys, led by Gary Davis and Kenny Trustee, finished third in the Men's C Division of the Appaloosa Stampede Softball Tournament held at the Softball Country Club. D and S Packing Homeboys finished the tournament with a 3-2 record and defeated The War Eagles-Gainesville 14- 8, Gwinnett Body and Paint 10-9 and Pizza Farm-Rockmart. . . . Stone Mountain's Metro Clean, led by Zae Green, finished fifth in the C Division after beating War Eagles 15-0 and Kings (McDonough) 18-15. . . . Stone Mountain's Village Upholstery finished second in the D Division. . . . DeKalb's Chicago White Sox, led by Theran Bond, lost to Hit Squad- Conyers 11-9 and defeated Slammers-Lawrenceville (9-4) in the Co-ed Divisi on. . . .

Area Softball; DeFayette leads Cheers to second-place finish


BYLINE: By Pierce W. Huffsports; competition; results; schools

WHO'S HOT: Atlanta's Cheers, led by Phil DeFayette, finished second in the D Division of the Appaloosa Stampede Softball Tournament at the Softball Country Club. Cheers defeated Good Old Days 7-0, Stone Mountain's Village Upholstery 7-1 and Gwinnett Crackers 10-4 before losing to Williams 13-10 in the championship. Village Upholstery, led by Ruble Whitlack, defeated Twelvemen 15-0 and finished eighth. . . . Homeboys finished the tournament 3-2, defeating the War Eagles-Gainesville 14-8, Gwinnett Body and Paint 10-9 and Pizza Farm-Rockmart. . . . May 10, 1991, Friday


Body of slain man found on path in S.W. Atlanta


SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; SECTION F; PAGE 05


LENGTH: 74 words


The body of an unidentified man, shot twice in the head, was found on a dirt path near 990 Hubbard St. S.W. about 7:30 a.m. Thursday, Atlanta police said. 

The victim is described as in his late 20s, black, about 5-foot-10 and weighing 165 pounds. He was wearing a Nike T-shirt and Adidas shoes. Anyone with information about the victim's identity can call the Fulton County medical examiner at 730-4400. Police have no suspects.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992

362 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


May 19, 1991, Sunday


The real effect of make-believe; Don't let filmmakers tell you they can't shape public opinion


BYLINE: By Randy Salzmanmovies; social; behavior; personal; reaction;


SECTION: PERSPECTIVE; SECTION D; PAGE 01


LENGTH: 919 words


Randy Salzman, a former newspaperman, TV producer and college journalism instructor, is a freelance writer living in Augusta.

"I DON'T THINK FILMMAKERS CAN INFLUENCE or affect anything. . . . Sometimes we can make a ripple, but, I mean, we're just a teaspoon in the ocean."

That's a quote from Barry Levinson, the director of "And Justice For All," "Rain Man," and "Good Morning, Vietnam," uttered in the midst of last fall's promotional campaign for his newest film, "Avalon."

The quote disturbs. It's a circle-the-wagon response to what should be a wide-open examination of how media affect the real world. 

It's akin to saying that "Uncle Tom's Cabin" had nothing to do with the Civil War or that William Randolph Hearst's reward of $ 50,000 to anyone proving the Spanish blew up the USS Maine wasn't a cause of the Spanish-American War.

Viewers simply cannot help but be "rippled" by the emotional, gut- wrenching influence of huge moving color images backed by Dolby stereo sound.

The riots accompanying "New Jack City" this year, or "The Warriors" five years ago, or even John Hinckley's rationale for shooting former President Reagan are the most disturbing examples.; Teaspoons' sell products

Those are, of course, dismissible as the actions of the maladjusted and the mentally ill - not mainstream America. But mainstream America is influenced, as well, by what we see - witness the thousands of young men and women who flocked to Navy recruiting stations after viewing "Top Gun."

Film's influence is most easily verified today by the fact that a Hollywood company exists to analyze scripts scene-by-scene to determine where and how Nike, Budweiser, Toyota, Pepsi and Kellog's products can best be plugged into feature films.

Does Mr. Levinson truly believe these films and the other multinationals purchasing American Film Promotion's services are throwing massive dollars after "teaspoons?"; Images shape opinions

Perhaps the director means that the films we see rarely destroy basic opinions or terminate lifelong value systems. In most cases, that's probably true.

But when the attempt is made to alter public opinion, filmmakers can be amazingly effective. If not, why did American audiences find themselves cheering German sailors in the subtitled version of "Das Boot," or the Viet Cong in 1989's "Iron Triangle?"

Visual imagery can be brilliantly effective in reinforcing established ideas or in shaping opinions where none exists, often with unintended consequences.

Shot after shot of missing children at the close of the television movie "Adam," for example, sent the nation into mass hysteria a few years ago, replete with milk cartons, missing posters, child finger-printings and "don't ever talk to anyone" lectures.

Parents all, very rationally, wanted to make certain their children were not among the 50,000 the movie told us disappeared every year.

The reactions were logical responses to an intensely emotional film. Even after the news media discovered that 48,500 of those kids were either proven runaways or were taken by the other parent in a divorce, the hysteria continues with milk cartons and ad fliers.; Living on the mean streets

Movies and television programs like this give us what one critic calls the "Mean World Syndrome." We are so sure that everyone out there is trying to rape, kill, hurt, con and rob us that we draw ourselves into individual cocoons, afraid of life. We buy extra locks, bulletproof book bags for our children, alarm systems for our boats, Mace packages for our cars, and guns, guns and more guns.

Until the Mean World Syndrome becomes the ultimate - and deadly - Catch 22.

Perhaps one or more of the police officers in Los Angeles with the all-too-ready nightsticks have what police call The Wyatt Earp Syndrome - a feeling that the cop's job is to save the world, even if it requires excessive violence.

No Los Angeles cop, obviously, has met Wyatt Earp. But they have met his counterpart in countless Friday nights at the theater and Tuesday nights in their living room. People around "Dirty Harry," remember, have a "nasty habit of getting killed."; Power to influence values

America is just now beginning to grope with the issue of media influence. That's what the boycott of "The Last Temptation of Christ," the trials of 2 Live Crew and Judas Priest, the Parents' Music Resource Center and congressional mandates concerning commercial minutes on children's television are all about. It's why there has been such an uproar over Andrew Dice Clay and Public Enemy, over sex and violence, over blatant commercialism.

To state it bluntly: If Hollywood, if the networks, if the record companies won't acknowledge their power to shape values, then Americans are more than willing to take power from them, to alter or bypass the First Amendment.

Although the Constitution's decree that Congress shall make no law" sounds absolute, the fact is that Congress, legislatures and the courts have routinely qualified freedom of speech. Examples abound from copyright and libel to recent obscenity rulings.

Today, when anti-media public opinion is at a fever pitch, society appears poised to attack again. To prevent it, the film industry and the media in general must quit pretending they create only teaspoons.

Each of those teaspoons, society feels, like the 27 men who died playing Russian roulette after viewing "The Deer Hunter," are ripples in a tidal wave.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Illustration: Movie projector with the front reel replaced by a globe./ John Amoss / Staff Photo: Riots broke out in Los Angeles when a theater oversold tickets to "New Jack City"/ File Photo: Tom Cruise in "Top Gun" inspired hundreds of young men to see their Navy recruiter./ File Photo:"Das Boot" the tense tale about heroism aboard a submarine during World War II, had Americans rooting for the Germans./ File


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

363 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


May 21, 1991, Tuesday


Students have field day with Olympics; Spirit of '96 fuels the desire to learn


BYLINE: By Linda Jacobson Staff writerschools; competition; olympics; gwinnett/county


SECTION: EXTRA; SECTION J; PAGE 07


LENGTH: 688 words


Many Gwinnett schools have decided not to wait until 1996 for the Olympics. Students are already experiencing the intense competition and international flavor of the Games.

Traditional springtime field day activities have been expanded into weeks of researching the customs and culture of foreign countries. Classes then compete as particular nations. 

"Some of the kids didn't know about other countries until they did this," said Marcia Nolan, a physical education teacher at Lilburn Middle School.

The school's Olympic Games included South Korea, Canada, Norway, Mexico and Italy. Students from the sixth through eighth grades were brought together to make up a country. "We tried to pull the school together," Ms. Nolan said.

Before the athletic events - such as the 440-yard relay, an obstacle course and a tug of war - the students made their countries' flags and some even painted their faces and arms with the colors of their countries.

"It really feels like you're in the Olympics," said 12-year-old Nhan Huynh, a Lilburn Middle student."You learn good sportsmanship."

While the concept of holding a school Olympics is not new, the fact that the Games will be coming to Atlanta in five years has added fuel to the Olympic fire and given teachers a new method of building student enthusiasm about history, geography, politics and even physical education.

Having a schoolwide Olympics is one example of how the county is moving toward an "interdisciplinary curriculum," said Glen Blankenship, social studies coordinator for Gwinnett public schools.

"Anything we can do that makes students see how subjects are related makes learning that much more real and that much more effective," Dr. Blankenship said, adding that studying the Olympics "gives students a better appreciation for other cultures."

Jesse Racine, a seventh-grader at Lilburn Middle School, said he enjoyed learning about his team's country, South Korea.

"We had to do research on the conflicts and the wars they've had," Jesse said, adding that during the course of his study he also discovered that Nike shoes and a wide range of electronic devices are made in South Korea. "I think it's a cool country."

Junior Spain, a physical education teacher at Dacula Middle School, which held its first Olympics last year, said he felt his school helped bring the 1996 Games to Atlanta.

"It made a good impression on the Olympic committee," Mr. Spain said. "It gave us an idea that we were doing a little part in being able to sway the committee to pick Atlanta."

The Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games (ACOG) is hoping to get students excited about the Olympics "so they can be good hosts when our guests come in 1996," said Sandy Jernigan, co-coordinator of the Olympic Day in the School program, which is primarily geared toward middle schools.

Four hundred of the 600 middle schools in Georgia now participate in the program, including all of Gwinnett's middle schools.

A program for the state's elementary and high schools will be developed over the next few years, Ms. Jernigan said.

Buford Elementary, however, already has the Olympic vision. Their program began April 17 and ran for a month. Throughout the last four weeks, the pupils have studied their countries and competed in athletic events in their physical education classes.

Margaret Hanson, a physical education teacher, began holding an Olympics four years ago, but this was the first year the athletics competition was combined with the school's social studies fair.

The project culminated last Friday with an international festival. With passports in hand, pupils traveled to different classrooms disguised as foreign countries.

The pupils' transworld experiences included mummifying a doll in Egypt, making maracas in Mexico, eating chocolate and cheese in Switzerland and playing golf in Puerto Rico.

"People are all the same," first-grade teacher Gail Cary told a class of pupils dressed in authentic Saudi Arabian garb. Ms. Cary's country was Botswana. "It's your culture that's different where you grow up."


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Color photo: A tug of nations: Pupils at Lilburn Middle School divide into teams representing various countries as the Olympic spirit catches on. Steve Deal / Staff


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

Miller leads Tucker in Truelove tourney


BYLINE: Pierce W. Huffbaseball; sports

LENGTH: 207 words


WHO'S HOT: Tucker's Stallions, led by Frank Miller, finished third in a men's class D tournament at Truelove Park. Stone Mountain's Dim Industries finished eighth. . . . Rehoboth Baptist Church went 2-2 to finish third in a men's class C tournament at Sugar Hill. Hairston Road Church of God was fifth. . . . Stone Mountain's Paranoid, led by Bobby Wood, finished eighth in class D at the Sugar Hill Park. Paranoid beat Jessie's Cabinet's of Lawrenceville and Spike's Softball of Norcross. Spike's, led by Steve Pahl, finished 11th. . . . DeKalb's Bruce Street Eagles finished third in the class C tournament at Truelove Park. It beat the Jonesboro Raiders and Riverside Cabinets. . . . Ricky West of Stone Mountain's Taps finshed the week with 35 runs scored and Tim Trowell had 30 RBI. . . .

Among some of the teams entered in class D are Stone Mountain's Village Upholstery led by Ruble Whitlock, Buford's Larson Jewelers led by John Patterson and Stone Mountain's Taps. Stone Mountain's R & W led by Harland Ragle and Appaloosa T-shirt led by Eric Ruben will be competing in class C. Call 299-3588 for information.

365 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


May 25, 1991, Saturday


Low-key pride in a high-flying hero; Tributes to Jordan are scarce in basketball star's hometown


BYLINE: By Joe Drape Staff writerpersonalities; roads; North/Carolina; basketball


SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; SECTION A; PAGE 03


LENGTH: 633 words


WILMINGTON, N.C. - This is his road, though the signs aren't up yet, the ones that will announce that this seven-mile stretch of salt air and interstate is Michael Jordan Road.

Talk about open court. Nothing but a smattering of road signs dot Michael's bit of Interstate 40, assuring pilgrims to his hometown that the Azalea Optimists and Cascade Realty are taking care of litter. And that Barstow, Calif., is 2,554 miles due west. 

And how about that Michael Jordan exhibit at the New Hanover County Museum? Do you know, do you know, do you know?

"Well that's misinformation that has caused us some problems recently," museum director Janet K. Seapker says.

Let curator Barbara Rowe clear this up:

"We have Michael's Olympic uniform and we borrowed his gold medal from his mother. And for a couple of years it was part of the Superstars of The Lower Cape Fear' exhibit. People loved it. We'll do it again."

You mean Michael shared the exhibit with former Harlem Globetrotter Meadowlark Lemon, Sammy Davis Sr. and country singer Charlie Daniels?

"And there's an actor in Atlanta from here, not very big, I think he's in the Senate or something," Ms. Rowe says. "Yeah, U.S. Rep. Ben Jones. Cooter. We've got the jeans, cap and the sleeveless shirt he wore on The Dukes of Hazzard.' That's really neat. He came here and opened the exhibit."

Oh, well. There are still some in this quiet, coastal community of 45,000 who say the Chicago Bulls superstar is their most favorite of sons.

And if state and city fathers have yet to master the marketing acumen to make Michael Jordan as synonymous with Wilmington as Nike has done with him and their athletic shoes, one place remains as mythical as Michael Jordan's basketball talents - Laney High School.

Namely, the scuffed hardwood in the crackerbox gymnasium, where a skinny teenager would practice alone at 7 a.m. before classes began. Then at night, he would dazzle the college scouts and basketball crazies, crammed to the rafters, with heretofore unseen acrobatics.

Nearly every day, visitors ask to see the gymnasium. They glimpse Michael's gold and blue high school jersey in the glass case in the foyer - the familiar No. 23 emblazoned below BUCS, the team's nickname. They see his name engraved on a plaque honoring the Buccaneers' 1980-81 championship team.

And if they're lucky enough to run into basketball coach Fred Lynch, they ask how was it Michael Jordan failed to make the varsity team as a 10th-grader. How, Coach, did arguably today's greatest player - a member of the University of North Carolina's 1982 NCAA championship team, a 1984 Olympic gold medal winner and the leader of a team seeking the 1991 NBA title - get cut?

Mr. Lynch, then an assistant coach, has answered that question often. How there was only room for one 10th-grader on the varsity. How Leroy Smith, a 6-foot, 7-inch post player, was kept over a then 5-foot, 10-inch Michael Jordan. How Michael never showed his disappointment at playing junior varsity.

By the time he was a 6-foot, 4-inch senior, he was All-Everything. Prep All-American in basketball. Top baseball pitcher. High jump champion. One of the nicest and most popular students ever at Laney.

"He showed that other people can make it if they try. That no one needs to act like they're special," says Jason Whitfield, graduating senior and basketball guard, who has heard this sports lore as gospel from his coach.

So until the North Carolina Board of Transportation mounts the first sign near the Cape Fear River (possibly this summer at a ceremony attended by Michael), or until the memorabilia of Sammy Sr., Meadowlark and Cooter are retrieved from mothballs, the most authentic tribute to a native son remains a small gymnasium.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Jordan


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

366 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


May 29, 1991, Wednesday


THE NEWSSTAND


BYLINE: By Kris Jensen; Time magazine examines hidden crime' of date rapepublications; personalities


SECTION: FEATURES; SECTION B; PAGE 03


LENGTH: 583 words


The alleged rape at the Kennedy compound in Palm Beach, Fla., has caught the public's attention, and Time uses it as a hook in its June 3 edition to examine the issue of date rape.

Writer Nancy Gibbs points out that deciding exactly what is rape is hard to determine in a society where some colleges define acquaintance rape as a spectrum "ranging from crimes legally defined as rape to verbal harassment and inappropriate innuendo."

She notes that women call it a hidden crime, while some men blame it on women "who live to tease." 

The seven-page report includes interviews with women and also with men who feel unjustly accused. And a poll of 500 U.S. adults taken by Time and CNN shows the differences on the issue. Among the results: 54 percent of the women and 69 percent of the men say that some women like to be talked into having sex.

WOMEN AND MEDICINE I: Another sort of abuse of women is examined in the June issue of Ms. In "Women as Wombs," Janice G. Raymond, professor of women's studies and medical ethics at the University of Massachusetts, questions the success of in vitro fertilization clinics. She says research has shown 90 percent to 95 percent of women who undergo IVF never take home babies. That finding is part of a wide-ranging report on the new reproductive technology.

WOMEN AND MEDICINE II: In the June 3 issue of People, actor Gene Wilder talks about wife Gilda Radner's losing battle with ovarian cancer and how doctors could have caught it sooner.

FACING UP TO PLASTIC SURGERY: Anyone considering a facelift or other plastic surgery may want to check out the June issue of Self. The piece, about top plastic surgeons, includes photos of a facelift in progress that are not for the squeamish.

GUYS JUST WANNA HAVE FUN: The June issue of GQ takes a look at a male institution in "The Last Hurrah: Can the bachelor party survive feminism, premarital sex, AIDS and couch dancing? Should it?" Writer Stephen Fried pulls together anecdotes of parties ranging from the tame to the raunchy. He also includes a rating scale to help guys determine how much trouble various last flings might cause.

SPIKE UP TO BAT: The cover photo on the May 27 issue of Sports Illustrated has some heavy hitters - Mickey Mantle and Roger Maris smiling broadly for a piece on the 1961 Yankees - but the real slugger isn't even promoted. Inside is a 10-page interview with filmmaker Spike Lee on topics ranging from being a superfan to his Nike commercials to why he's such an angry young man. The search for what drives Mr. Lee goes back to his roots in Atlanta, Alabama and Brooklyn. Mr. Lee takes a jab at Deion Sanders, calling him "another young brother who got some money and will have it spent before he knows he had it." The article is cleverly illustrated with photos of Mr. Lee in various baseball uniforms, including the Atlanta Braves.

AROUND THE SOUTH: The June issue of Atlanta magazine looks at the fall from grace of Emory University law school's Abe Ordover, who was accused of sexual misconduct. . . . The June issue of Southern Living offers a salute to national parks in the South as part of the National Park Service's 75th anniversary.

AT THE CHECKOUT: "Joan Kennedy: How Ted's antics in rape scandal drove her into drink clinic, then back on bottle" - The Star . . . "Kennedy Rape Drives Joan Into Booze Clinic" - The National Enquirer . . . "Bob Hope Cheated on Wife & Drove Lover to Suicide" - The Globe.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


June 1, 1991, Saturday


SPORTS BUSINESS DAVID DAVIDSON; Tyson-Ruddock fight will cost $ 30 at bars


BYLINE: By David Davidsonsports; boxing; baseball; football; personalities; health; conditions


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION D; PAGE 02


LENGTH: 505 words


Cover charges at Atlanta-area sports bars for the Mike Tyson-Razor Ruddock heavyweight fight June 28 are likely to cost about $ 30 and would soar to between $ 40 and $ 45 for an Evander Holyfield-Tyson championship bout.

That's the prediction of Atlanta attorney Bobby Ronick, who represents local pay-per-view TV marketing company Worldwide Satellites Ltd.

Covers at local sports bars for last month's Holyfield-George Foreman championship match ranged from $ 10 to $ 35, but the norm was $ 20. 

Most bars were at capacity, and that kind of demand will only push prices higher.

The in-home pay-per-view fees for Holyfield-Foreman ranged from a norm of $ 35.95 to $ 70, and those prices also are expected to be higher for Tyson-Ruddock or a Tyson-Holyfield matchup.

LOTTERY PLAN CUT: Faced with opposition from its senate's powerful majority leader, New York state has sacked a lottery proposal that would have been based on the NFL scores of Giants, Bills and Jets games.

The lottery would have operated much like many office football pools. Participants would have selected one of 100 squares that are randomly assigned two numbers from one to 10. Those whose two numbers matched the final digits of the score would win.

The NFL strongly opposes state lotteries linked to its games. The New York lottery was projected to raise $ 15 million a year.

HORSES LOSING GROUND: Horse racing, once the nation's most popular form of gambling entertainment, trailed lotteries in dollars wagered, $ 21 billion to $ 11 billion, in 1990. . . . The NCAA has expanded its disability insurance plan to include baseball players in addition to football and basketball athletes. Players deemed likely to be taken in the first two rounds of the major league draft are eligible to purchase up to $ 900,000 in disability coverage.

BYE-BYE, BO: With football/baseball star Bo Jackson sidelined at least temporarily with a hip injury, San Antonio Spurs center David Robinson may become a marketing superstar of similar magnitude. With a 25.6 points-per-game average with the Spurs and a mathematics degree from the Naval Academy, Robinson remains a lieutenant and civil engineer in the Navy Reserve and is an accomplished pianist - in short, the clean-cut role model corporations are finding more and more difficult to locate. Robinson already is in the fourth year of a $ 1 million endorsement contract with Nike, and signed deals with Casio watches and Franklin Sports Industries while serving a two-year stint in the Navy after graduation. However, experts predict it is unlikely Robinson will reach Jackson's estimated $ 5 million-per-year endorsement income. . . . Claiming patent infringement, Avia is suing Nike for unspecified damages in U.S. District Court in Portland, Ore. The suit claims Nike is using a cushioning system in its new Air 180 series - which sell for approximately $ 125 per pair - that is similar to Avia's "Cantilever" technology, protected by three patents dating to 1980.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


June 5, 1991, Wednesday


Breakers to see action in softball tourneys


BYLINE: By Scott Bernarde Staff writerbaseball; competition


SECTION: EXTRA; SECTION J; PAGE 04


LENGTH: 490 words


The Action Awards Breakers have picked up where they left off last season. Hitting a robust .600, the Snellville-based men's softball team has qualified for one national, one divisional and three state tournaments.

Last season's U.S. Slo-pitch Softball Association (USSSA) state Class C Team of the Year is 47-16 overall and is in the driver's seat to win the highly regarded Amateur Softball Association (ASA) state Bud Light Triple Crown series, which continues this weekend in Fort Valley, Ga. They won the first leg of the series three weeks ago. 

The series awards points based on a team's finish in three designated tournaments, with the points leader being declared the state champion. The champion also gets its room and board paid for in the national tournament later this summer in Steamboat Springs, Colo. The Breakers qualified for that tournament with the win three weeks ago.

"It's a pretty prestigious thing there in Colorado," coach Ric Jarvis said. "If we win the Triple Crown , we're probably talking a couple thousand dollars."

The Breakers' success in the ASA series is just part of the team's fast start. They've already earned berths for this summer's ASA, USSSA and National Softball Association (NSA) state tournaments, as well as for the USSSA Southeast Divisional. They've finished second in two highly competitive tournaments - the Nike Early Bird Tournament in Marietta and a USSSA divisional qualifier in Cartersville.

"We've been hitting the ball well, and our defense has been exceptional," said Jarvis, an original member of the team that was formed 10 years ago to play in a recreation league.

The Breakers have done most of their damage by coming through the loser's bracket of recent tournaments. In the first Triple Crown event, for instance, they lost their opening game, then won the next nine to take the championship.

"We've had to come back a number of times. That says a lot about our team right there," Jarvis said. "We've played in more games that a lot of other teams because we've had to come through the loser's bracket so many times."

The success is not new. Since becoming the Breakers in 1981, the team has gained statewide respect. Last year, four players - including Player of the Year Mike Jordan, Derrick Davis, Ron Ammnons and Roger Bailey - were named to the USSSA All-State team as the Breakers set a state record in Class C for points won in tournament play. By winning the state title, the Breakers moved up to play in USSSA's B classification this year.

"We're consistently one of the better teams in the state. People hate playing us," Jarvis said. "Through the years, we've really grown into a good team. It's been a longtime hobby for me."

Other team members are Terry Gomez, Tim Fuller, Phil Taylor, Mark Williamson, Bo Davenport, Steve Harrison, Kevin Gaines, Tim Gaines, Sam Crowe, Greg Jones, Mike Lahey and Mark Azar.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


June 6, 1991, Thursday


AREA SOFTBALL


BYLINE: Pierce W. Huffsports; competition; results


SECTION: EXTRA; SECTION A; PAGE 18


LENGTH: 216 words


WHO'S HOT: DeKalb's Larson & Jewel, coached by John Patterson, went 4-2 to finish seventh in Class D of the Champs Nike Classic at the Softball Country Club. Larson & Jewel defeated Williams Body Shop of Brennen, Ga., ranked No. 2 in the state by the USSSA, 6-4. It also defeated Mingeldorffs 16-10, Mother McCarthey's-Tallahassee, Fla. 12-4 and Tucker's L & S Saints 13-4. Patterson went 14-for-17 in the tournament. . . . Stone Mountain's Village Upholstery, led by Ruble Whitlock, went 2-2 and finished 33rd. Village Upholstery defeated Canton's Vicious Rumors 12-5 and Mother McCarthey's 13-6. . . . Electrical Distributors, coached by Jimmy Caviness, leads the Industrial B division at Blackburn Park with a 6-2 record. . . . Consolidated Contractors (8-0), coached by Richard Carini, is in first place in the B and C open division at Blackburn. The Oak Grove Barons (7-1), coached by Terry Sweatt, lead Tuesday Church C. Magnum (7-1), coached by J. B. Moreland Jr., is in first in Tuesday Open C. Longwoods (8-0), coached by Mitch Oliver, lead the Thursday Open C.

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


June 13, 1991, Thursday


GLENN SHEELEY'S SPORTSCENE; Georgia's Goff, Durham link up for 72-hole, 4-course day of golf


BYLINE: Glenn Sheeleysports; personalities; georgia; golf


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION G; PAGE 02


LENGTH: 689 words


Georgia basketball coach Hugh Durham and football coach Ray Goff never covered this much real estate on a recruiting trip.

How about this for a golf fantasy? They played 72 holes on four different courses on the same day. In fact, they even stopped for lunch and accomplished it all in just over 11 hours.

"We could have played another 18," Durham said. "We still had two hours of light left, but we couldn't find another course." 

The golf-a-thon started at 8 a.m. Monday at Athens Country Club, which Durham and Goff played in one hour, 45 minutes, with each man riding his own cart. From there, after a 45-minute drive to Lake Oconee, they played the Harbor Club course in about two hours.

After lunch at nearby Port Armor, which they played in two hours and 10 minutes, they drove a few miles down the road to Reynolds Plantation where, ironically, Georgia Tech's annual golf outing had just been completed. Playing their final course in just over two hours, Durham and Goff completed the 72 holes at 7:05 p.m.

Neither player wished to reveal the final scores, lest somebody remember them when filling out foursomes for all those handicap tournaments to which they regularly are invited, but Durham was the apparent winner.

"We both played pretty good," said Goff, "but I don't think I saw Hugh miss two or three fairways all day. I wouldn't have wanted to play him for money."

If you can believe it, though, Durham has spent busier days on a golf course. Last summer at singer Kenny Rogers's Beaver Dam Farms course, he played 100 holes in one day.

JUST WONDERING: When was the last time in this town that there were more people talking about the Braves than there were people talking about the NBA Finals? . . . The NFL and the Atlanta Falcons will conduct a free clinic at 9 a.m. Friday at Morehouse College sponsored by Pro Set and Nike. Expected are 12 Falcons players, including safety Scott Case, linebacker Michael Reid and former return man Billy "White Shoes" Johnson.

ON A MISSION: TNT sportscaster Ernie Johnson Jr. and wife Cheryl are in the process of adopting a Romanian child. Cheryl has been in Bucharest since May 16 with other hopeful parents from the Atlanta area and will bring home a 2 1/2-year-old boy who was abandoned at birth in a park and has lived in an orphanage with other undernourished children. "It's been quite an experience," said Ernie, whose children, Eric 6, and Maggie, 4, are eager to meet their brother. Aurel Mihia Johnson and his new mother will be home as soon as they obtain a visa. "We're going to call him Michael, which is what Mihia pretty much translates to," said Ernie, "but if he's got a real good fastball, we might stick with Aurel." . . . Part- time Channel 46 sportscaster Phil Van Horn was the producer of the ESPN special that ran Wednesday on Georgia quarterback Eric Zeier, the former Marietta High star. What the show didn't detail was the fact that the biggest challenge for the massively recruited Zeier, who graduated from high school early and enrolled in time for the Bulldogs' spring practices, was juggling appointments with the "escorts" he encountered at various schools within the recruiting period.

REMEMBER, THE ICEBERG'S OUT OF BOUNDS: Talk about taking advantage of good lighting! They're holding the Cross Creek Arctic Open golf tournament in Iceland, just 31 miles south of the Arctic Circle, to take advantage of June 21, the shortest night of the year. There will be enough light available to play 36 holes at the Akureyri Golf Club. . . . The price of going to the ballpark is getting out of hand. According to a Team Marketing Report survey done for Major League Baseball, the average family of four will spend $ 76.22 while watching their team play a single baseball game. The figure covers the cost of four tickets, two beers, four hot dogs, four soft drinks, two baseball caps, two programs and parking. In some cities, don't forget the cost of paying a kid to watch your car so it's there when you return.

(Seen or heard something for Sportscene? Call Sheeley at 526-5798.)


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

371 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


June 13, 1991, Thursday


As semi-shock waves settle over L.A., Jordan disappears


BYLINE: Ailene Voisinbasketball; results; reaction; chicago; los/angeles


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION G; PAGE 05


LENGTH: 712 words


INGLEWOOD, Calif. - L.A., a city of 3.5 million, is either too sophisticated or too vain to ever admit being in a state of shock. Siege, maybe. Not shock.

Shock is empty freeways. Clipper victories. Surfboard shortages. Thirty consecutive days of cloud cover and no rain. And no sun, either. 

But what happened inside the fabled Forum on Wednesday was, at the very least, an aftershock. The Chicago Bulls won the title . . . The Chicago Bulls won the title . . . The Chicago Bulls won the title . . . The Chicago Bulls won the title.

Four games. Four victories. Three wins in the Forum, and just like that - it was that easy - Michael Jordan no longer is the lonely Bull. No longer the lonely superstar. Now, he has plenty of friends.

Bird. Magic. Isiah. With this ring, he becomes wedded to Magic Johnson and Larry Bird, who formed an elite club back in the 1980s. Non- champions need not apply. Isiah Thomas finally broke down the door. Pounded on it twice, in fact. Now, Jordan.

How good does it feel? Jordan cried. He was so overcome that he hid from NBC. "Where's Jordan, where's Jordan?" a frantic Bob Costas yelled, as he looked around the champagne-drenched locker room.

Others came and went. The Rev. Jesse Jackson. Spike Lee. Ernie Banks. Johnny Kerr. Lakers GM Jerry West and assistant GM Mitch Kupchak. "Too crowded," West said, ending his search for Jordan.

Still, no Michael. But somewhere, by now, he was surely smiling. He had guided the Bulls to their first-ever championship in 25 years. A party in Chicago awaits.

L.A.? L.A. can mourn, can shake, can complain that it wasn't fair because James Worthy and Byron Scott were hurt and Magic Johnson too old and Elden Campbell too young, but it was eminently fair, and right, and America celebrates because the Good Guy doesn't always finish last.

This time the Good Guy won. Jordan ate his Wheaties and did all the right things, and when the time came, he came through. Blocked shots, steals, jumpers, passes, breakaway dunks, scoop shots, Michael being Michael.

For six years, he wondered if it was meant to be. Six long years. As a rookie, he was snubbed in the All-Star Game by some of the (Isiah) Thomas Gang for arriving in a Nike sweatsuit. His second year, he broke his foot and feuded with GM Jerry Krause because - get this - Jordan regained his health and wanted to finish out the season.

Krause said no.

Jordan said yes.

Guess who won that battle?

Jordan would win others, as well, including a race for MVP honors with his good friend Johnson. But that was nothing. Nothing like this.

Jordan and his teammates arrived at the Forum two hours before game time, eager to learn the condition of Worthy (ankle) and Scott (shoulder).

Worthy arrived soon after in street clothes, and remained in street clothes. Scott changed into his jersey and went out to the court to test the shoulder.

Some of the Laker faithful - and some non-partisans - suggested that L.A. had a better chance without Scott, who shot 27 percent in the first four games. Consider this exchange during the interview session on Monday at Inglewood High.

Horde of media jackals: "How is your shoulder?"

Scott: "Not good. I can't lift my arm. I can't shoot."

Horde of media jackals: "Ha, ha, ha."

Or, as Vlade Divac might say, "He make joke."

But this was no joke. Scott slowly walked off the court. No go. No Worthy. No Scott. No chance? The Bulls hoped not. During the two days between games, they were determined to retain their edge.

They resisted the lure of Hollywood, with Jordan even declining an invitation to appear on The Arsenio Hall Show, refused to become overconfident because of the injuries to Worthy and Scott, and the wounded ego of Magic, who dropped the Big One right here in the middle of the Forum on Tuesday. He might return for another season. He might not.

Jordan empathized, but refused to become distracted.

But would they win?

They win. When it is finally, mercifully over, Jordan bolts for his coach, Phil Jackson, and engages Paxson, the hero, in the longest of embraces.

As he enters the tunnel area, he is in tears. "I've never been this emotional in public before," he says, "but this is a great time to be emotional."


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

July 26, 1991, Friday


PRO FOOTBALL; FALCONS NOTEBOOK; Long-distance drills have $ 90,000 price tag


BYLINE: By Len Pasquarelli Staff writeratlanta/falcons; football; personnel; conditions


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION H; PAGE 06


LENGTH: 340 words


PORTLAND, Ore. - The Atlanta Falcons would still be in Suwanee tonight, not out west facing the Seattle Seahawks, if all of their expenses were not being picked up.

The cost for the Falcons' roundtrip charter alone, approximately $ 70,000, would make the cross-country trip prohibitive under any other circumstances. Falcons expenses have been budgeted at $ 90,000. 

Still, Portland State, the scrimmage's sponsor, hopes to net about $ 100,000 from an anticipated sellout crowd of 23,000 at Portland Civic Stadium. Ticket prices range from $ 7.50 to $ 25. Nike, located in nearby Beaverton, Ore., is helping pay some of the expenses.

"For a school our size, the profit we make from the scrimmage will have a substantial impact on our program," said Portland State sports information director Larry Sellers. "This is a major-league event for us in every way you can think of."

HOMECOMING: While many fans attending tonight's scrimmage will be coming to see former University of Oregon star Chris Miller, the quarterback most recognized in these parts may be Falcons assistant head coach/offense June Jones, who played at Portland State. A native of Portland who was instrumental in arranging the scrimmage, Jones passed for 3,518 yards and 25 touchdowns while operating the run-and-shoot offense as a senior at Portland State.

Falcons safety Tracey Eaton, a native of Medford, Ore., also played at Portland State. Free agent fullback Pat Chaffey, a native of North Marion, Ore., played at Oregon State.

BRIEFLY: The Falcons are close to a contract agreement with veteran defensive end Tim Green. . . . The three-year, $ 2.325 million contract signed Wednesday by first-round pick Mike Pritchard represents a 21 percent hike over that signed by last year's 13th overall pick, Kansas City Chiefs linebacker Percy Snow.. . . The Falcons resume camp workouts with a 3 p.m. practice Sunday.. . . Eight players did not make the trip to Portland because of injuries. Three who did are doubtful to participate.

July 29, 1991, Monday


NATIONAL SPORTSWIRE; Valvano to coach again in 10-day European tour


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION E; PAGE 02


LENGTH: 353 words


Former North Carolina State basketball coach Jim Valvano will return to coaching for the first time since his ouster 15 months ago when he coaches the Nike All-Star team for 10 days in Germany and France in September. Valvano, who worked as an analyst for ABC and ESPN after leaving N.C. State in the wake of violations by team members, said he was assured of at least one victory against the German national team. "I'll have NBA All-Stars Charles Barkley and David Robinson playing for me for that game," he said. But that will be their only appearance. The rest of the team will consist mainly of players who just finished college or with minor league pro experience.; Fly So Free wins Jim Dandy by 1 1/4 

Fly So Free, beaten twice this year by Strike the Gold, held off a late charge by the Kentucky Derby champion to win the Grade II Jim Dandy Stakes at Saratoga on Sunday. Fly So Free, the 2-year-old champion, swept wide in the stretch to finish 1 1/4 lengths ahead of Upon My Soul. Three lengths further back was Strike the Gold, in his first start since losing the Belmont Stakes by a head to Hansel.; Ben Johnson not wanted for race

Ben Johnson, once one of the biggest names in international track, is now being asked not to show up. Bengt Bendeus, organizer of an Aug. 5 meet in Malmo, Sweden, said that he canceled a contract worth a reported $ 160,000 for Johnson to race against Carl Lewis and world record holder Leroy Burrell. Johnson finished fourth in the 100 meters at the Canadian national championships Saturday in a disappointing time of 10.42 seconds.; Puerto Rico beats USBL stars 93-86

Jose Ortiz, formerly of the Utah Jazz, scored 26 points to lead Puerto Rico to a 93-86 victory over a team of USBL all-stars in the championship game of the Winston World Basketball Cup in San Juan, Puerto Rico. It was the first time a team of U.S. professionals played in a tournament sanctioned by the International Amateur Basketball Federation. Wes Matthews and Lanard Copeland, who played for the Atlanta Eagles this season, scored 12 and six points, respectively.

August 8, 1991, Thursday


BACK TO SCHOOL; After a fashion; Students' threads make statement


BYLINE: By Linda C. Rehkopf Staff writerschools; fashion; costs


SECTION: EXTRA; SECTION H; PAGE 01


LENGTH: 462 words


Kendrick Register knows what he wants to wear back to school. Shorts. Jeans that have been intentionally ripped in the knees. Nike Air Jordans.

Unfortunately for 8-year-old Kendrick, his mother has other ideas. Rita Register is buying her son "nice" pants - Dockers, Levi's 501 jeans, Duck Head khakis. 

Mrs. Register is still in that enviable position of having control over her son's wardrobe. She also follows the cardinal rule of shopping for back-to-school clothes:

Take the child with you. If you don't, what you buy may hang in the closet all year.

Another cardinal rule is:

Set a budget, and make sure your children know how much you intend to spend.

"Last year, I spent close to $ 300 on his clothes, but that was for everything, including a winter coat," Mrs. Register said. "The sneakers run us about $ 80, though. It depends on what the Jacksons - Michael or Bo - or Michael Jordan wear. That's what he wants."

Kendrick and his classmates at Powers Ferry Elementary School in Cobb County will be decked out in old favorite bluejeans and new, bright shirts and pants, according to Deborah Jacobs, the district manager for The Children's Place.

"Boys will be wearing activewear, fleece tops and bottoms, denim and color-block woven tops. Denim in a relaxed-fit' style is popular," she said.

"For girls, the No. 1 look is activewear, also," Ms. Jacobs said. "The big-over-small' look is big for girls, like mock turtlenecks over leggings or stirrup pants.

"No. 2 on the girls' list is denim, either blue or bright colors. Turtlenecks and sweaters with jeans are popular," she said.

Tennis shoes are the footwear of choice for many youngsters, said Stride Rite's Amy Dodge. Some manufacturers have developed a washable leather sneaker, which is a favorite of the parents.

"Moms love sneakers they can wash," Ms. Dodge said.

In dress shoes, durability and versatility are important. Saddle oxfords and camp mocs are popular sellers, Ms. Dodge said.

Before spending money on a new wardrobe, parents need to keep in mind their school system's dress code.

For example, tank tops are banned this year in the Marietta city schools, as are gang paraphernalia and pajama-like clothing. Students in Marietta will be sent home for baring their midriffs or for immodest dress.

Cobb schools determine their own standards for dress, according to school system spokeswoman Barbara Robison. "There are some things that are systemwide, but again, those are enforced locally by each school."

Principals in Atlanta schools make individual determinations as to what's app ropriate, according to a system spokeswoman.

Parents were advised to check with their local school or school system for changes to existing dress codes.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

August 8, 1991, Thursday


Jonesboro teenager beaten unconscious


BYLINE: By Rick Minterteenagers; assault; investigations; metropolitan


SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; SECTION D; PAGE 04


LENGTH: 177 words


A 16-year-old Jonesboro teenager is in stable condition at Southern Regional Medical Center today after being dropped off at his home beaten and unconscious Wednesday afternoon, according to hospital spokesperson Pam Whitten.

Clayton police said Karlos Brown, 16, of 78 Darwin Drive, was taken to his parents' home in the locked trunk of an automobile at 4 p.m. He had been beaten about the face and the front half of his head had been shaved, according to Clayton Police Lieutenant Doug Jewett. He was also missing his Nike tennis shoes and a baseball cap, the lieutenant said.

The teenager had apparently left home earlier in the day with the same four men who returned him to his home, Lieutenant Jewett said.

Roderick Reid, 20, and Jerrmie Roberson, 18, both of Jonesboro, two of the men who allegedly brought the teenager home, were arrested and charged with aggravated assault and false imprisonment, Lieutenant Jewett said.

Police have not established a motive and do not think the attack was gang-related, Lieutenant Jewett said.

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


October 2, 1991, Wednesday


COLLEGE ATHLETICS; Next Dominique' Strong commits to Dogs


BYLINE: By Scott M. Reid Staff writersports; competition; colleges; basketball; personalities


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION E; PAGE 09


LENGTH: 341 words


ATHENS - Georgia scored a basketball recruiting coup Tuesday when Cedar Shoals forward Carlos Strong, whose strong showing this summer propelled him among the nation's top college prospects, said he would enroll next year.

"This kid is the next Dominique Wilkins ," said Bob Gibbons, a recruiting analyst. "I saw Dominique play in high school, and I think Carlos at this stage is better than Dominique was. I think by the time we get to the end of the year, Carlos could be the very best player in the country." 

Strong, a 6-foot-8 preseason All-American, also considered Kentucky, Tennessee and Miami after earlier eliminating Nevada-Las Vegas, Georgetown and Syracuse. Verbal commitments are non-binding. High school players cannot sign national letters of intent until Nov. 13.

Strong, a first-team All-State Class AAAA player, averaged 15 points and eight rebounds last season. He was impressive at the prestigious Nike camp, a showcase of the country's top prep prospects, despite playing only two days after suffering a sprained ankle and broken tooth.

Strong is the second of the nation's top five players to stay close to home. Guard Jason Kidd of Oakland stunned Kentucky and Kansas by committing to California last week.

"I feel like if you're good, people are going to know you're good whether you're on television a lot or not," Strong said. "The main thing is to go somewhere where you're comfortable and I'm comfortable at Georgia."

Strong has met the NCAA's core curriculum standards but failed to achieve the minimum SAT score of 700 on his first try. He plans to retake the test later this month. Strong missed eight games last season because of academic problems.

Georgia also remains in the running for Strong's Cedar Shoals teammate Terrell Bell. The 6-10 Bell has visited Alabama and Kentucky and will visit Temple, Clemson and Georgia.

Former Griffin High All-American Darrin Hancock, now at Garden City (Kan.) Junior College, has narrowed his choices to Georgia, Kansas and Kentucky.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
