The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


October 3, 1991, Thursday


Will Memphis elect first black mayor?; Popular incumbent, strong challenger face voters today


BYLINE: By Joe Drape Staff writermemphis; politics; leaders; elections


SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; SECTION A; PAGE 02


LENGTH: 660 words


MEMPHIS - The word drops softly in a rich baritone, a towering double-breasted figure letting it go: Memphis. Willie Herenton tries to sell his mayoral candidacy with verse.

"We must build coalitions that cut across race and class. I grow weary. . . . We have an opportunity to send a message to the nation that Memphis," he says slowly, his opponent two feet away, "a city historically plagued by racial polarization, has made a sudden leap forward. Memphis . . ." 

The cadence evokes the late Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and is aimed beyond these 700 Rotarians, most of them white, gathered at The Peabody Hotel. It's aimed at the television cameras. The 6-foot-6 former Memphis school superintendent wants to be the first black mayor of this predominantly black city on the Mississippi.

Voters will decide today whether he unseats popular incumbent Dick Hackett, who offers the flip side of the New South coin: economic development.

Mr. Hackett, a 42-year-old business guru without a college degree, as a career politician has managed to transform Memphis into an attractive trading post. Eighty-five businesses, including such titans as Federal Express, International Paper and Nike, have expanded or relocated here in the past year.

Mr. Herenton, 51, grew up in a housing project 15 blocks from what is now a glimmering downtown. The same determination that made him a Golden Gloves boxing champion earned him a doctorate and made him the first black school superintendent.

It was a post he held with distinction from 1978 until June. Only once was he tempted to leave. In 1987, the Atlanta school board offered him its top job. He accepted, only to withdraw weeks later, after an impassioned plea from the community to stay in Memphis.

If ever there is a time for Memphis to elect a black mayor and join Atlanta, Birmingham and New Orleans, and five of the nation's top 10 cities, it is now. Timing, demographics and justice may be on its side.

Census figures show that 55 percent of Memphis's 610,000 residents are black. And the U.S. Justice Department filed a voting rights suit against the city to abolish at-large council seats and run-off elections.

Black leaders, who had never united behind a sole candidate for mayor despite only one black ever winning a citywide race, met during the summer to pick a consensus choice. That process ended up anything but unified when two coalitions warred over whose voice would be heeded: the traditional politicians led by U.S. Rep. Harold Ford or activists at a People's Convention. Mr. Herenton emerged as the candidate of both, but not without casualties. Mr. Ford waited until the final week to lend his presence to the campaign and apparently chose not to issue a traditional endorsement ballot on Mr. Herenton's behalf.

Charles Carpenter, Mr. Herenton's campaign manager, warns that no one should underestimate Mr. Herenton's appeal, which peaked after he decided to take the Atlanta job. "At that point it was clear to him, clear to the community, that Willie Herenton was a leader, a role model, and a mentor."

The incumbent has adopted the look of a winner, attending official functions, dropping in on shopping centers and making speeches only at private fund raisers.

Mayor Hackett says he is running on his nine-year City Hall record, one he claims is marked by sound management of services, no tax increases and a thriving economy.

Rarely does he mention Mr. Herenton by name, nor are race relations given much comment. Instead he points to six black top city directors - most appointed in the past two years - as examples of his administration of inclusion.

Campaign manager Bill Boyd says the mayor might get up to 15 percent of the black vote as a result of black dissension.

He also has nearly three times the campaign funds of Mr. Herenton, or $ 660,000, enabling him to barrage viewers this week with television ads.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: photo: Willie Herenton (left), Memphis's former school superintendent, is challenging Mayor Dick Hackett.

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


October 6, 1991, Sunday


METRO & GEORGIA IN BRIEF; Authorities trying to ID jogger hit by car


SECTION: LOCAL AND STATE NEWS; SECTION D; PAGE 11


LENGTH: 1206 words


Authorities were trying Saturday to identify a jogger who was lying unconscious at Piedmont Hospital after being struck by a car on West Paces Ferry Road.

"He's very clean-cut looking," said hospital spokeswoman Linda Tucker. "His clothes seem pretty expensive."

The victim is about 30 years old, white, 5-foot-8 and 170 pounds with a muscular build and dark brown wavy hair. He was wearing black running shorts, Nike tennis shoes and a black sports watch. He has three tattoos - a leprechaun on his right chin, a dragon on his left shoulder and an eagle on his right arm. 

"He has a very serious head injury," Ms. Tucker said. "Right now it's very grave. Doctors desperately need to talk to family to see if there are any other medical conditions they should be aware of."

Witnesses said the jogger was in the path of traffic when he was hit on Friday. No charges were filed against the driver.

PARENTS OF TEENAGE SHOOTING SUSPECT SUED: The parents of a 14-year- old who shot another youth during a basketball game are being sued for negligence because they allegedly left their son alone at home with access to a vehicle and a weapon. The $ 5.5 million lawsuit in Gwinnett State Court alleges that Edward and Denise Nestor "were aware of their son's dangerous propensities." Casey Brennan, 13, of Snellville was shot between the eyes on June 27. His parents, John and Pamela Brennan, say he has lost sight in one eye. Testimony indicated the Nestors' son, whose name is being withheld, drove his parents' van to a neighborhood basketball game and attempted to shoot Casey's brother, then shot Casey. A Gwinnett Juvenile Court judge ruled the youth committed aggravated battery. He faces a maximum sentence of 18 months in juvenile detention; sentencing is set for Oct. 15.

CLARKSTON MAN HELD IN SLAYING OF FEMALE IMPERSONATOR: A 29-year-old Clarkston man has been charged in the Sept. 26 slaying of a female impersonator in Knoxville. Investigators charged Samuel U. McDowell with murder in the strangulation death of Frank W. Wilson, 46, who was choked with a telephone cord at his house. Mr. McDowell was taken into custody Wednesday in DeKalb County after he made an abrupt turn in front of officers, police said. He was driving a car that belonged to Mr. Wilson, investigators said. Mr. Wilson, who used the stage name "Francine," performed part time at a Knoxville nightclub. He also had worked for several years at a finance company. Mr. McDowell also was charged with theft of a vehicle. He is being held in the Knox County Intake Center in lieu of $ 22,000 bond.

TWO HURT AS FIRE DESTROYS EAST POINT WAREHOUSE: An abandoned East Point cotton warehouse was destroyed Saturday morning in a blaze that sent two firefighters to the hospital with minor injuries. The fire in the two-story wood and brick warehouse at 1149 Central Ave. was reported at 12:46 a.m., and crews were still tending hotspots Saturday night, said East Point Fire Department Battalion Chief Ronnie Few. One firefighter was treated for smoke inhalation, and one slipped and fell on debris. Both were released from South Fulton Hospital. The cause of the fire had not been determined Saturday, but Chief Few said vagrants have been seen in the building.

TWO INDICTED IN DALTON SLAYING, INCLUDING VICTIM'S WIFE: A Whitfield County grand jury has returned murder indictments against a Dalton man and the wife of the victim. Debra Thomas, 33, of Hartford, Ky., and formerly of Dalton, was indicted on murder charges in the strangulation of her husband, Roger Dale Thomas, 31, in May. The grand jury also indicted Jeffery Sean Roberts, 34, of Dalton on a murder charge. Tammy Rochelle Carpenter, 20, of Dalton was indicted for concealing Mr. Thomas's death. His body was found May 13 alongside Lake Allatoona by a fisherman. He had been strangled with a small rope. Mrs. Thomas filed a missing persons report May 11, telling police she last saw her husband when she dropped him off at a Dalton lounge. Detectives have said no one at the lounge recalled seeing Mr. Thomas.

WATERING BAN LIFTED IN CHATSWORTH: Chatsworth residents now can water their lawns and wash their cars without guilt. The city water works lifted its monthlong ban on outside water use Friday after decreased industrial and residential demand boosted the supply. "If people still conserve and not be wasteful, I think we'll be OK," said water works superintendent Tom Martin.

CONVICTED COLUMBUS MURDERER WON'T GET THE CHAIR: Jerry Lee Everett of Columbus has escaped the death penalty by pleading guilty to a 1988 murder and armed robbery. Everett, 36, pleaded guilty Friday to the Oct. 2, 1988, fatal shooting of Rudolph E. Williams behind the Traffic Light Lounge. Mr. Williams was shot in the head five times. Muscogee Superior Court Judge William Smith sentenced Everett to two life terms for murder and armed robbery and five years for using a firearm during those crimes. The sentences will run concurrently. Assistant District Attorney Ed Berry said Everett's videotaped confession as well as his action in calling police and telling them he committed the crimes led to the offer to escape a possible death sentence.

MCINTOSH CLERK SUES COMMISSION OVER FIRING: A former McIntosh County tax commission clerk is suing county commissioners, claiming she was illegally fired after her arrest on forgery charges. Dotheria Robinson was arrested in February 1990 for cashing a check that was drawn by a third party and given to her husband. The charge was later dismissed on a technicality. Nine months after her arrest, the McIntosh commission voted to suspend Mrs. Robinson indefinitely. Her suit, filed in U.S. District Court in Brunswick, claims the commission usurped the authority of Mrs. Robinson's boss, the tax commissioner, and failed to follow county policy on firing employees. The suit says commissioners routinely ignore policy when firing black employees, like Mrs. Robinson. She is seeking unspecified back pay and damages, and reinstatement in her job.

FEDS ASK GROVETOWN TO RETURN EPA FUNDS: Federal environmental officials are asking the city of Grovetown to return $ 169,000 for failing to award a 1986 sewer plant contract to the lowest bidder. Mayor Dennis Trudeau said the Environmental Protection Agency provided a $ 2 million grant for the city's wastewater plant, which was built after three separate contracts were awarded for segments of the work. W.L. Carey Construction Co. was the low bidder on the first two contracts, but Beacon Industries Inc. was the low bidder on the third contract by about $ 269,000, Mayor Trudeau said. City officials gave the entire project to the Carey firm after it agreed to drop $ 100,000 off the price of each of the three contracts. Although the $ 300,000 discount on all three contracts made Carey the low overall bidder, EPA decided that Beacon should have been awarded the third contract. EPA has ordered the city to repay the $ 168,000 difference between the low bid and the Carey price on the third contract. Mayor Trudeau, who was not mayor at the time, said the

Compiled from staff and Associated Press reports


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


October 7, 1991, Monday


Jordan's image stained by Bush snub backwash


BYLINE: Ailene Voisinbasketball; personalities; presidents; politics


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION D; PAGE 01


LENGTH: 649 words


He is Wheaties. He is Nike. He is America. He would be the prototypical Republican if he weren't a Democrat.

Yet of late, Michael Jordan's halo is teetering, threatening to tilt, and all because of a Meet-the-President photo shoot last week in the Rose Garden. COME AS IS, the invitation urged. BRING CHICAGO BULLS. BRING TROPHY. MOST IMPORTANT, BRING MICHAEL. 

For a change, even George was there.

And Michael wasn't.

In the aftermath, Jordan's absence was added to the growing list of national crises. He was found guilty of a conspiracy of one, of (ye gads!) orchestrating a solo plot, a snub, against the Prez.

Children cried. Mothers cringed. Both suggested that Jordan be flogged with a bowl of wet Wheaties, or, at the least, be grounded by a pair of P.F. Flyers.

Others, including members of the Chicago media, deemed a verbal spanking more appropriate. Consider that Chicago columnist Jay Mariotti, echoing the very serious sentiments of many, called the snub, "about the most disturbing, irresponsible and irrational thing Jordan has done in public life."; Michael's virtues paling in comparison

Jordan must indeed be a man of few sins. Unless we missed it, he does not use drugs. He pays his bills on time. He loves his children. In general, he comports himself like a gentleman, the same which can not always be said of his brethren.

Larry Bird shoots his mouth off and often hits his own foot. Charles Barkley shoots his mouth off and hits both feet. Isiah Thomas, both feet and both ankles. Magic Johnson keeps mum. Much safer that way. Until recently, so did Jordan.

First he hinted that he might prefer golf to the Olympics. Amid a sizable uproar, he quickly reconsidered. Then he was blamed - unfairly - for Thomas's absence on the U.S. squad. Now he is perceived as sticking out his very famous tongue at Bush.

Hardly.

Were he more of an activist, Jordan's absence might have suggested that Bush tend to the weeds in the back of his other garden, the one that provides a less-than-rosy vision of America, featuring its homeless, the health-care crisis, unemployed workers, our illiterate children.

But Jordan's statement was personal and pragmatic, though impolitic as well. He simply chose to spend the final days of the offseason with his children, which, given the state of the American family, ought to be commended.; He owed fans answer, not justification

Bush most assuredly will recover more quickly than our economy. So will the Bulls, even those angered by a perceived double standard, and so will Jordan, though the MVP has gained new insights into the plight of the superstar.

The trouble with sports heroes is that they aren't angels. They may leap into the heavens but they eventually land, often with a thud. Even, the Michael Jordans.

In one sense, his timing is lousy. Bird had Magic. Magic had Bird. They were basketball's dueling duo of the 80s, enemies, then rivals, and ultimately friends, each one's actions measured by the other's. Together, they shared the glories and the burdens of superstardom.

"I would always say, What would Larry do?' " Magic once admitted, deep in thought. " How would he react?' Having him out there . . . well, we helped each other's careers in a lot of different ways. We understand each other."

But Jordan stands alone. He lacks the kinship of a Magic-Bird, and unlike his predecessors, veteran teammates with the stature of a McHale, Parish, DJ, Kareem, Wilkes, Worthy, Nixon. Jordan has only Jordan. Pippen? Not yet. Horace Grant? Just another good player. John Paxson? Right place at the right time.

If Jordan is to be chided, it is only for this: He owed his fans the answer to his whereabouts. Not a justification. An answer.

But irresponsible? Disturbing? Irrational? Nonsense. Jordan should simply tell the truth.

Just explain that he's a Democrat.


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

383 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


October 10, 1991, Thursday


LESSON PLAN; Taste of Chinese leaves pupils hungry for more; Periodically during the school year, DeKalb Extra will publish Lesson; Plan, a look at what's happening in one classroom in the county.; According to Mrs. Chu, the old way was the best way.


BYLINE: By Dena Smith STAFF WRITEReducation; language; profile; minorities


SECTION: EXTRA; SECTION A; PAGE 06


LENGTH: 468 words


Pauly Chu, a kindergarten teacher at Canby Lane Elementary School, structures her class in the normal fashion of most other kindergarten teachers.

They read some, do math, learn Chinese, take naps and have play time - yes, they have been learning Chinese.

Mrs. Chu, a Chinese-born American citizen, spends at least 30 minutes a day teaching the 5-year-olds numbers in Chinese, math on an abacus and Chinese characters. 

But she doesn't stop there. Some old Chinese culture is also incorporated into her classroom.

Because, according to Mrs. Chu, the old way was the best way.

"A long time ago in China, the teacher was more important than the parents," Mrs. Chu said. "Discipline and respect was incorporated in the school; the most important thing was respect to the teacher. But when I came to the United States, I saw that that's not always the case."

Bowing when thankful is natural for the 15 students who sometimes wear Chinese farmer hats made out of paper. Five-year-old Michael Witherspoon wishes everybody would do it.

"Learning Chinese makes me happy," Michael said. "I think everybody should bow and say thank you' because it's a really nice thing to do."

Exposure is also important to Mrs. Chu. She believes understanding different cultures makes for better relations in the future.

"My students can see that I'm different from them, they know that that difference is that I'm Chinese," Mrs. Chu said. "Sharing some of my culture with them helps them understand that difference is a way of life, that it could be good and there is no reason to feel threatened."

Brown-eyed Benjamin Carson credits Mrs. Chu with helping him make his career choice. The 5-year-old Stone Mountain resident said he wants to be a Chinese-speaking "rocketeer" when he grows up.

"They love her - both kids and parents," said Mary Dugett, the school's principal. "We have parents that come in wanting to see the teacher who teaches Chinese. After watching her, they inquire about getting their kid in her class."

"I couldn't learn Chinese at my old school," 5-year-old Desiree Hillman said. "But Mrs. Chu is a Chinese teacher, and I like her because she teaches Chinese."

Mrs. Chu said she's proud to have the opportunity to teach children another language.

"I really think Americans should learn more than one language," she said, "and I'm happy to be able to contribute towards that goal."

According to Mrs. Chu, the old way was the best way.

The School

Canby Lane Elementary Kindergarten

The teacher

Mrs. Pauly Chu

The class

Nike Amole

Kimberly Brown

Benjamin Carson

Shaka Dennison

Stacie Edwards

John R. Freeman

Harris Hall

Denai Henderson

Desiree Hillman

Branton Leonard

Ellis McCoy

Brandon Smith

Corynne Smith

Michael Witherspoon

Tiera Thompson

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


October 22, 1991, Tuesday


The truth in advertising is the bad-guy image sells; Agency taking guarded risks on marketability


BYLINE: By Raad Cawthon STAFF WRITERsports; personalities; advertising; earnings; ranking; lists


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION E; PAGE 01


LENGTH: 1439 words


They are the unsavory types you would not want around your children. If these guys came to dinner, chances are you would count the silverware upon their departure.

So why are some of the nasty boys of professional sports getting five-figure contracts to try and sell you on what deodorant you should put under your arms?

Hulk Hogan, recently implicated as a customer in a steroid distribution case, endorses Right Guard deodorant. So does Charles Barkley, the Philadelphia 76ers forward who spit on a girl at courtside and threw water on another fan last season. 

The Right Guard triumvirate is rounded out by Brian Bosworth, a former Seattle Seahawks linebacker whose mouth turned out to be larger than his talent and who is best remembered for being suspended from the Orange Bowl while playing for the University of Oklahoma after a positive steroid test.

So why would Gillette, the makers of Right Guard, spend money on these guys?

"We are playing off their bad boy image," says a spokesperson for N.W. Ayer, the New York ad agency that designed the ads. "It's the way the campaign is supposed to work."

"Brian's a bad boy, and I do think that sells," says Gary Wichard, Bosworth's agent.  So, in the topsy-turvy parlance of advertising, bad becomes good.

"To a certain degree, anybody is marketable," says David Falk, vice- chairman at Pro Serv Inc., a Washington, D.C. firm that represents a host of athletes, including the Atlanta Hawks' Dominique Wilkins. "But I've got to believe that the last five to 10 years there has been an increased awareness of behavior, off-court and on-court."

To that end, most advertisers now include morals clauses in contracts with athletes. Overstep the moral bounds and you are out.

But what are the bounds?

"You have to look at it on an athlete-by-athlete basis," says Bob Dorfman, a copywriter with Foote, Cone and Belding advertising in San Francisco. "With something like the Right Guard campaign, the right idea can overcome a lot of bad personality aspects."

Dorfman points to the Nike shoe commercial that ran after Barkley had his run-ins with the NBA and was heavily fined. In the commercial, David Robinson, the clean-imaged center for the San Antonio Spurs and another Nike endorser, asks Barkley, "Can you spell fine, Charles?"

Still, there is a line.

"For example, I don't think you could get by with making fun of  Philadelphia Phillies outfielder Lenny Dykstra's drunken driving charge," Dorfman says.

Athletics tie-ins with products is nothing new. Yankees catcher Yogi Berra said, "Me-hay for Yoo-Hoo. Fudge bars too-who" back in the 1950s. And the prize fights on Friday night television were the Gillette Friday Night Fights.

Today that connection is stronger than ever. Products from soft drinks to motor oil to headache powder to automobiles to wrist watches are being pitched by everyone from fastballer Nolan Ryan to race driver Richard Petty to tennis player Gabriela Sabatini.

And while Sabatini and Steffi Graf, both tennis players, rank among the top 10 athletes for outside endorsements internationally, it is largely a man's game in the United States.

"Tennis and golf both have international appeal," says Clive Chajet, chairman and chief executive officer of Lippincott and Margulies, an identity consulting firm. "But in the U.S. the hottest market right now are the men who play team sports, particularly players in the NBA.

"In the wider U.S. market, women athletes have a much more limited appeal as far as endorsements are concerned. Except for women who play tennis, nobody is all that interested in having a pair of shoes just because Monica Seles wears the same kind."

So lucrative are commercial endorsements that some highly paid athletes make more from their endorsement contracts than from the salaries their teams pay them.

Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls capped an NBA championship and a Most Valuable Player Award with a new endorsement contract. Gatorade is paying Jordan a reported $ 19 million over 10 years to try and get people to drink its product. Before setting that all-time high, Jordan's Nike contract went unrevealed but advertising executives suspect it was the single largest endorsement deal ever.

All told, Jordan's endorsement income alone has been estimated at $ 10 to $ 15 million yearly. His salary is $ 2.1 million annually.

"Michael transcends everything," says Chajet. "His image has redefined marketing."  Arnold Palmer, a leader on the endorsement list long after he dropped from the top of golf tournament leader boards, has pulled in at least $ 5 million annually in endorsement contracts over the last decade.

Jordan's image is of a squeaky clean, nice guy. And Palmer's image is of common man perfection.

"It is more than just athletic accomplishment that makes someone a sought-after endorser," says Nova Lanktree, executive director of Burns Sports Celebrity Service in Chicago. "There has got to be personality and a sense of acceptance of the person."

Despite the limited success of Bosworth and Hogan, other athletes have not been able to exploit off-the-field endorsements because their image is suspect. Two examples mentioned by advertising executives are former heavyweight boxing champion Mike Tyson and Oakland A's slugger Jose Canseco.

Canseco became the first baseball player to hit 40 home runs and steal 40 bases in a single season. But he also has had several run-ins with the law, including a charge of carrying a weapon while on probation for multiple traffic offenses. And after being a no-show at numerous public appearances, Canseco started his own call-in line so fans could hear his side of the story.

Tyson, who is scheduled to be tried for rape on Jan. 20, seems to cause even more consternation, though it took a rib injury to postpone his Nov. 8 championship fight with heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield.

"Tyson is the most unpredictable athlete out there," Dorfman says. "He's scary . . . You have to have some pleasantness about you."

A lack of "pleasantness" has hit Tyson in the pocketbook. In 1988 Pepsi agreed to pay him about $ 1 million to push its products, but the contract was not renewed in the wake of allegations by Tyson's former wife, Robin Givens, that he physically abused her.

"There are only so many dollars out there for the credible athletes," says Atlanta attorney Bruce Church, who represents former Brave Dale Murphy. "The involvement costs are too high to gamble with. The cost not only of getting the athlete involved but getting the message out in front of the public."

"It inherently holds that when you hitch your product image to a star, there is some degree of risk," Chajet says.

To most, the line is distinct: Law-breakers are taboo.

"On a very literal basis, when it starts to get into the area of legality and criminality, then it starts to backfire," says Lanktree. "Barkley is a kind of naughty boy but he is not seen as a bad person. And I think that in view of Hulk's previous clean reputation, he's going to be all right."

Lanktree contrasts Hogan's alleged use of steroids with that of sprinter Ben Johnson, who was stripped of his world and Olympic records after testing positive.

Though Johnson did not have a many lucrative endorsement contracts, the setting of the world sprint record could have opened up international possibilities for him, Lanktree says.

"Ben Johnson took prescription drugs," she says. "What he did was not illegal, but he totally lost all his value as a spokesperson .

"He was seen in the beginning as someone who was difficult, unapproachable. He was never likeable and his lapse into illegality cinched it."

Baseball's all-star balloting, where the fans elect the starters, is a barometer of an athlete's standing in his community, Lanktree says.

She notes that in 1990 Wade Boggs was voted by fans to start the All- Star Game despite a well-publicized extramarital affair.

"Whatever Boggs's attitudes was, he was not seen by the people of Boston as s aying, Screw you. I don't care what you think,' " she says. "On the other hand, Canseco was not elected to the All-Star team. I think that was very significant."

Everyone agrees the future will see more athletes endorsing products.

"The Jordan deal was monstrous," says Dorfman. "How much Gatorade will people have to drink for that much money to pay for itself? But I think what it says is that advertisers think the market is bottomless."

"More and more," says Lanktree. "I don't know that there is a limit."


LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


October 28, 1991, Monday


PEACH BUZZ


BYLINE: BY GLENN SHEELEY; Burger magnate offers a taste of his philosophypersonalities; atlanta; social; conditions; books


SECTION: FEATURES; SECTION C; PAGE 02


LENGTH: 432 words


Those TV commercials that Dave Thomas, founder of the Wendy's hamburger chain, has made famous are not to be confused with, say, a Bo Jackson production from Nike. But you still remember them, don't you?

"Dave's commercials are a lot like sausages," joke creators Paul Basile and Jim McKennan. "If you like them, you probably don't want to see them being made." 

Thomas will sign copies of his book, "Dave's Way," from 1 to 2:30 p.m. today at Oxford Book Store on Pharr Road. An adopted child, Thomas is President George Bush's national spokesperson on adoption.

Aspiring millionaires might heed "Dave's Plan for Making It if You're Young, Alone or on Your Own":

1. Get a job.

2. Don't be discouraged if an early job doesn't work out.

3. Look for things you like and learn what it takes to have them.

4. Try hard work.

5. Find people you can learn from.

6. Get an education.

7. Figure out what the bottom is.

Sounds like a few rules Bobby Cox followed in spring training.

HAVE I FORGOTTEN ANYTHING?: There was lawyer John Johnson at the World Series the other night, having a great time and entertaining clients, when he was paged in the third inning and told by wife Chris that their son Drew, 4, could not be found. She wanted Johnson to check for him in, of all places, his car, remembering that Drew had pleaded to go with his dad to the game.

When Johnson got to the parking lot, he saw several police officers encircling the car. They were talking to Drew, who had climbed into the back seat, fallen asleep and was now awake. Johnson took him home and returned to the game, missing two innings. "I'm not sure he's learned his lesson," Johnson said. "He thought he was a celebrity."

KNOWING THE AUDIENCE: Pity the person scheduling an event these past couple of weeks without taking Braves fever into account. Cartier sent mailgrams Fri day informing those planning to attend the gala opening of its Lenox Square store Sunday that TV monitors would be placed "so that no fan will have to worry about missing the game." . . . Santa Claus, scheduled to arrive at CNN Center today to initiate the local Toys for Tots drive, switched the trip to Nov. 18.

GOOD OBSERVATION: Members of a second-grade class at Fifth Avenue Elementary School in Decatur wondered why the World Series is being called "the Cinderella Series." The teacher read "Cinderella," then asked if they noticed any similarities between the story and the World Series. "Yes," said student Jamarco Williams. "They both get over at midnight."

Items? 526-5800; faxes 526-5509.

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


November 1, 1991, Friday


GRADE A INVESTORS; Students building portfolios' for lesson in high-stakes world of stocks


BYLINE: By Nancy Nethery STAFF WRITERinvestments; transactions; schools; competition; schools


SECTION: BUSINESS; SECTION H; PAGE 01


LENGTH: 581 words


Sometimes Father knows best. But other times you've got to make your own choices.

That's a lesson Greg Asman learned in last year's AT&T Collegiate Investment Challenge when he bought stock in his father's company, Schlumberger Industries - and lost money. 

"That's the last time I'm going to do that," said Greg, a junior at North Springs High School in Atlanta.

Luckily, he had stuffed his portfolio with other stocks, including NCR Corp., Nike Inc. and Walt Disney Co., so he still managed an imaginary four-month profit of about $ 200,000 on his $ 500,000 investment.

This year, about 12 students from North Springs's 70-member chapter of Future Business Leaders of America are playing in the contest's high school division. Each has paid $ 39.95 for a contest kit.

Between now and Feb. 28, their goal is to turn a fictional half- million-dollar investment into a money-making machine. They're competing against about 12,000 high school students nationwide.

Rules of the trade

Participants trade stocks by calling an 800 number during regular stock market hours. They can buy stocks on margin by borrowing from the "broker," Wall Street Portfolios, or sell stocks short. A commission is charged for each transaction. Each player is allowed 50 transactions.

The 10 students who can make their portfolios grow the most win the contest.

After making six-figure stock deals, the $ 1,000 prize may seem like chump change. It's a good thing they're not all in it for the money.

Joe Reynolds, a junior who is a novice in the world of high finance, is looking at the contest as a learning experience and expects "hard study" ahead.

That's encouraging to the business club's advisers, teachers Mary Henson and Cindy Greene. Ms. Henson says the contest is a "great opportunity for kids - lots better than anything we can simulate in class."

Stock preferences

Several students are using research from class to choose investments.

Sophomore Jay Carroll is considering investing in Pepsico, a company he researched for an economics class. He's also thinking about baseball card makers.

Greg is considering "stocks based in the South, just because I don't think the recession has hit as hard here." He also likes airline stocks, Disney and Microsoft Corp.

Despite Greg's experience last year, several students are investing in a parent's company.

Marc Seidband's father works for IBM Corp. "I'm putting my money in IBM and Hershey," said Marc, a senior.

His investment strategy: "Buy low, sell high. That's all you need to know."

Learning from pros

While that may be the key to winning AT&T's four-month-long contest, actual investors must look at things a little differently.

Phillip M. Larkins, director of investments for Bank South Corp., suggests remaining in the market at least three years, because in the short term, "you can be blindsided."

"The market is volatile, subject to major moves up and down," he said. So if you stay in stocks for a short period, "you're speculating, rather than investing."

Karl Dasher, a Georgia Tech student who was the top-placing national sophomore in last year's college division, agrees that real investors must have a long-term perspective.

Explaining why, he invoked the name of the legendary former manager of Fidelity Investments' high-flying Magellan Fund.

"You can't have one good three-month stint in the contest," Mr. Dasher said, "and think you'll be the next Peter Lynch."

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


November 16, 1991, Saturday


Golfers play through after man dies on green


BYLINE: By Norman Areysports; football; boxing


SECTION: SPORTS; SECTION D; PAGE 02


LENGTH: 727 words


Donald DeGreve, 65, playing golf recently with about 40 neighbors in Winter Haven, Fla., suffered a heart attack and died during his round. The body remained on the 16th green with a sheet over it more than two hours and, while his three partners abandoned their game, the rest of the group played around the green. "Life goes on," said one, "so we had to keep going."  ROMANTIC DEVIL: Romance is alive and well and running long distances. Joyce Hodges of Millen and Jim Hite of Statesboro will spend their honeymoon running the Atlanta Marathon and half-marathon on Thanksgiving. Both are ranked statewide in age-group (50-59) racing. Hodges coaches and teaches at Metter High while Hite does the same at Statesboro High.

BLACK SUNDAY: Alma Alta, the Soviet basketball team in town to play Georgia State today in an exhibition, asked to meet "the football coach in black," no doubt reminded of their own KGB. So the 17 Soviets watched the Falcons practice Friday and the man in black, Jerry Glanville, came up with 17 tickets for Sunday's game against Tampa Bay. 

HERE & THERE: Michael Jordan drew a $ 250 fine from coach Phil Jackson for sleeping through a practice. George Shirk of the San Francisco Chronicle computed the fine was equivalent to a $ 50,000-a-year person losing 60 cents. . . . The Bulls' Scottie Pippen has his name on a new Nike shoe that'll hit stores next month. The shoes will be called Air Flight Mid. . . . New Notre Dame coach John MacLeod has renamed the Irish basketball arena The Thunderdome. That's the nickname the school is using for a marketing campaign. MacLeod wants to enliven games with all the hoopla that surrounds NBA contests. . . . Louisville coach Denny Crum has a 75-acre horse ranch in Kentucky. Says Crum: "When I get out of coaching, I plan to train thoroughbreds I've raised on my own." Might be less stressful for him. Whoever heard of graduation rates for horses?

RIM SHOT: After Orlando rookie center Stanley Roberts shattered two backboards in practice, team GM Pat Williams came up with a way to raise money for charity. The club collected the shards, put them into bags and is selling them to fans for $ 10 a bag. At the first game - labeled as "Roberts' Rim Wreckage" - 34 were sold.

QUOTABLE: After a 7-0 loss to Minnesota, Maple Leafs coach Tom Watt said: "It's pretty tough to find anything positive in this one. We didn't tear the jerseys - I guess that's it." . . . FSU's Bobby Bowden says today's showdown vs. Miami will not be the biggest game he has ever coached: "I have a lifetime contract. The biggest games I ever coached were when I had a one-year contract." . . . Oiler defensive end Sean Jones, on the Cowboys: "The Cowboys are like a bunch of little maggots. Right when you get them off you, they keep coming back."

RIP RIPS DUKE: Former Georgia Tech assistant and current James Madison football coach Rip Scherer said he will withdraw his name from consideration for the Tulane job if David Duke wins Louisiana's gubernatorial election today. "It's a matter of principle. You'd be endorsing Duke's philosophy. I wouldn't want my name associated with anything of that kind."

HAPPENINGS: Quarterback Chris Miller and 15 Atlanta Falcons teammates will sign autographs for charity today from 1 to 3 p.m. at Baselines Sports Cards in Duluth. Autographs of all players can be received for a $ 10 donation, which goes to the Christian Council of Metro Atlanta Shelter for Women and Children.

WHO?: What a quarterback matchup - Steve Bono vs. Stan Gelbaugh. That's the 49ers vs. the Cardinals in case you don't recognize the names. How obscure are they? The 49ers couldn't find a scouting report on Gelbaugh. No wonder. He's been signed and released 20 times by eight teams in three leagues since 1986.

A GREAT GUY: Tampa Bay linebacker Broderick Thomas was named NFC defensive player of the week after 11 tackles and two sacks against the Lions. He immediately announced his desire to renegotiate the remaining two years of his five-year, $ 4.3 million contract.

NEW WORD: Before fighting Ray Mercer, heavyweight Tommy Morrison said: "Losing is not in my vocabulary." During the fight, says the Boston Globe's Ron Borges "Mercer made unconsciousness part of Morrison's vocabulary."

Items? Arey at 526-5798; faxes 526-5977

The Atlanta Journal and Constitution


December 17, 1991, Tuesday


THE MARKETS; Dow climbs 4.69 after late sell-off deflates a rally


BYLINE: By Tom Walker STAFF WRITERbusiness; investments; banking; finances; transactions


SECTION: BUSINESS; SECTION F; PAGE 04


LENGTH: 237 words


Investors pushed stock prices sharply higher for much of the day Monday, although a late sell-off deflated most of the gains.

The Dow Jones average of 30 blue chip industrial stocks, up as much as 19 points just 15 minutes before the market's regular close, ended the day with a gain of 4.69 points to 2,919.05 in fairly heavy trading. 

That was enough to keep alive the market's advance, which began last week. On Monday, the prospect of another interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve was enough to stimulate buying.

The Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee is expected to decide the issue when it meets in Washington today, although analysts said there is no guarantee a cut in rates would occur the same day.

Although the market is still cautious in light of the weak economy, some analysts interpreted the Dow's latest gains as further evidence that the worst of the market's monthlong slide may be over.

Robert S. Robbins, market strategist for Robinson-Humphrey, said the Dow's low of 2,844 last Wednesday may have been the start of the market's usual year-end rally.

In Monday's trading, two companies with improved earnings posted gains: Nike, up $ 2.62 1/2 to $ 64.50 after reporting second-quarter earnings of 80 cents a share against 77 cents a year ago, and Circuit City, up 12 1/2 cents to $ 23.25 after reporting earnings of 19 cents a share versus 5 cents a year earlier.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1992


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution

 

389 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


The Guardian (London)


September 11, 1991


Women: Selling my soul for a pair of trainers - Angela Neustatter on why she gave in to her son's demands for the very latest in footwear


BYLINE: By ANGELA NEUSTATTER


LENGTH: 620 words


 

'THEY kill for Reebok pumps. You only get mugged for Nike-Air - they're commoner.' So I was informed by my 11-year-old son, who had just returned from the first day at his new secondary school wearing the gleaming pair of Nike-Airs which had gobbled up most of the household fund the day before.

It was a remark going straight to the heart of a moral dilemma which, if the conversations I took part in during the last weeks of the holidays are anything to go by, has caught parents of children in our style-conscious society, where status currently resides in footwear, by the short and curlies. Should we succumb and fork out inordinate sums of money for shoes which, to the uninitiated, look much like those available at a fraction of the price, just because they carry the crucial name and have the attraction of added air? 

If common sense were the only guide, the answer should be a resounding no. But we are a child-centred generation of parents and we know only too well the depth of the anguish our young may feel if they cannot hold their own among their peer group. I still remember how mortified I felt when my mother adapted an ancient, baggy pair of her ski trousers for me, when everyone else on the school trip had the sleek, chic elasticated kind. For our kids, starting at new schools, there seemed to be a particular urgency to reach a decision.

But there was a practical side to the dilemma. In the US there have been cases of youngsters murdered for their expensive, ultra-fashionable shoes, and not long ago the son of a friend of mine was 'persuaded' by a couple of heavies at a north London bowling alley to accompany them to a quiet spot and part company with his new, modish trainers. What sort of parent is willingly going to put their kid to that kind of risk when a pair of cheapo, label-less shoes are risk-free?

Statistically, my son pointed out, this argument is thin - no more than half a dozen cases of nasty incidents concerning shoes have been reported and in our circle just two are known about. And, he asked in his most persuasive, hectoring manner, how many pairs of fashionable shoes are bought and worn by young people?

But let's get to the heart of the moral dilemma. How can we right-on parents, desperately trying to impart values which will challenge the superficial materialism of our age - a culture in which the adman rules and you are admired more for how you look than who you are - go out and buy our kids these absurdly over-priced shoes, thus confirming the idea that this is where their status lies?

The British Telecom lines crackled with the anguished sound of the older generation battling with its conscience as the start of the new term drew near.

My conclusion was that there are times, the first day at a new school being one of them, when my principles, my pious pride in being seen to provide the right ethical environment for my young, have to go hang. Watching Cato putting on his new purple and white shoes with enormous pride, seeing the boost they gave to his confidence as he set off to school, I was glad he had them. It might not be the most satisfactory or the most enduring way to build self-esteem but as a one-off it had real value.

He arrived home after the first couple of days happy with the school, pleased to be making new friends, excited even about his homework. I can't help feeling that if he had not felt so sure about his image, he might not have felt so positive about all these other things.

I was not, apparently, alone in my judgment. Walking into the entrance hall of my son's new school that first day, the most striking sight was a dazzling array of feet in state-of-the-art footwear.


LOAD-DATE: June 9, 2000


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 Guardian Newspapers Limited
