400 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


October 27, 1991, SUNDAY, THREE STAR Edition


BAD-BOY IMAGE CAN GET STARS ENDORSEMENTS


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 1D


LENGTH: 1420 words


 

They are the unsavory types you would not want around your children. If these guys came to dinner, chances are you would count the silverware upon their departure. So why are some of the nasty boys of professional sports getting five-figure contracts to try to sell you on what deodorant you should put under your arms? Hulk Hogan, recently implicated as a customer in a steroid distribution case, endorses Right Guard deodorant. So does Charles Barkley, the Philadelphia 76ers forward who spit on a girl at courtside and threw water on another fan last season. The Right Guard triumvirate is rounded out by Brian Bosworth, a former Seattle Seahawks linebacker whose mouth turned out to be larger than his talent and who is best remembered for being suspended from the Orange Bowl while playing for the University of Oklahoma after a positive steroid test. So why would Gillette, the maker of Right Guard, spend money on these guys? ''We are playing off their bad boy image,'' says a spokesperson for N.W. Ayer, the New York ad agency that designed the ads. ''It's the way the campaign is supposed to work.'' ''Brian's a bad boy, and I do think that sells,'' says Gary Wichard, Bosworth's agent. So, in the topsy-turvy parlance of advertising, bad becomes good. ''To a certain degree, anybody is marketable,'' says David Falk, vice-chairman at Pro Serv Inc., a Washington, D.C. firm that represents a host of athletes. ''But I've got to believe that the last five to 10 years there has been an increased awareness of behavior, off-court and on-court.'' To that end, most advertisers now include morals clauses in contracts with athletes. Overstep the moral bounds and you are out. But what are the bounds? ''You have to look at it on an athlete-by-athlete basis,'' says Bob Dorfman, a copywriter with Foote, Cone and Belding advertising in San Francisco. ''With something like the Right Guard campaign, the right idea can overcome a lot of bad personality aspects.'' Dorfman points to the Nike shoe commercial that ran after Barkley had his run-ins with the NBA and was heavily fined. In the commercial, David Robinson, the clean-imaged center for the San Antonio Spurs and another Nike endorser, asks Barkley, ''Can you spell fine, Charles?'' Still, there is a line. ''For example, I don't think you could get by with making fun of (Philadelphia Phillies outfielder Lenny Dykstra's drunken driving charge,'' Dorfman says. Athletics tie-ins with products is nothing new. Yankees catcher Yogi Berra said, ''Me-hay for Yoo-Hoo. Fudge bars too-who'' back in the 1950s. And the prize fights on Friday night television were the Gillette Friday Night Fights. Today that connection is stronger than ever. Products from soft drinks to motor oil to headache powder to automobiles to wrist watches are being pitched by everyone from fastballer Nolan Ryan to race driver Richard Petty to tennis player Gabriela Sabatini. And while Sabatini and Steffi Gr af, both tennis players, rank among the top 10 athletes for outside endorsements internationally, it is largely a man's game in the United States. ''Tennis and golf both have international appeal,'' says Clive Chajet, chairman and chief executive officer of Lippincott and Margulies, an identity consulting firm. ''But in the U.S. the hottest market right now are the men who play team sports, particularly players in the NBA. ''In the wider U.S. market, women (athletes have a much more limited appeal as far as endorsements are concerned. Except for women who play tennis, nobody is all that interested in having a pair of shoes just because Monica Seles wears the same kind.'' So lucrative are commercial endorsements that some highly paid athletes make more from their endorsement contracts than from the salaries their teams pay them. Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls capped an NBA championship and a Most Valuable Player Award with a new endorsement contract. Gatorade is paying Jordan a reported $19 million over 10 years to try and get people to drink its product. Before setting that all-time high, Jordan's Nike contract went unrevealed but advertising executives suspect it was the single largest endorsement deal ever. All told, Jordan's endorsement income alone has been estimated at $10 to $15 million yearly. His salary is $2.1 million annually. ''Michael transcends everything,'' says Chajet. ''His image has redefined marketing.'' Arnold Palmer, a leader on the endorsement list long after he dropped from the top of golf tournament leader boards, has pulled in at least $5 million annually in endorsement contracts over the last decade. Jordan's image is of a squeaky clean, nice guy. And Palmer's image is of common man perfection. ''It is more than just athletic accomplishment that makes someone a sought-after endorser,'' says Nova Lanktree, executive director of Burns Sports Celebrity Service in Chicago. ''There has got to be personality and a sense of acceptance of the person.'' Despite the limited success of Bosworth and Hogan, other athletes have not been able to exploit off-the-field endorsements because their image is suspect. Two examples mentioned by advertising executives are former heavyweight boxing champion Mike Tyson and Oakland A's slugger Jose Canseco. Canseco became the first baseball player to hit 40 home runs and steal 40 bases in a single season. But he also has had several run-ins with the law, including a charge of carrying a weapon while on probation for multiple traffic offenses. And after being a no-show at numerous public appearances, Canseco started his own call-in line so fans could hear his side of the story. Tyson, who is scheduled to be tried for rape on Jan. 20, seems to cause even more consternation, though it took a rib injury to postpone his Nov. 8 championship fight with heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield. ''Tyson is the most unpredictable athlete out there,'' Dorfman says. ''He's scary. You have to have some pleasantness about you.'' A lack of ''pleasantness'' has hit Tyson in the pocketbook. In 1988 Pepsi agreed to pay him about $1 million to push its products, but the contract was not renewed in the wake of allegations by Tyson's former wife, Robin Givens, that he physically abused her. ''There are only so many dollars out there for the credible athletes,'' says Atlanta attorney Bruce Church, who represents former Brave Dale Murphy. ''The involvement costs are too high to gamble with. The cost not only of getting the athlete involved but getting the message out in front of the public.'' ''It inherently holds that when you hitch your product image to a star, there is some degree of risk,'' Chajet says. To most, the line is distinct: Lawbreakers are taboo. ''On a very literal basis, when it starts to get into the area of legality and criminality, then it starts to backfire,'' says Lanktree. ''Barkley is a kind of naughty boy but he is not seen as a bad person. And I think that in view of Hulk's previous clean reputation, he's going to be all right.'' Lanktree contrasts Hogan's alleged use of steroids with that of sprinter Ben Johnson, who was stripped of his world and Olympic records after testing positive. Though Johnson did not have a many lucrative endorsement contracts, the setting of the world sprint record could have opened up international possibilities for him, Lanktree says. ''Ben Johnson took prescription drugs,'' she says. ''What he did was not illegal, but he totally lost all his value (as a spokesperson. ''He was seen in the beginning as someone who was difficult, unapproachable. He was never likeable and his lapse into illegality cinched it.'' Baseball's all-star balloting, where the fans elect the starters, is a barometer of an athlete's standing in his community, Lanktree says. She notes that in 1990 Wade Boggs was voted by fans to start the All-Star Game despite a well-publicized extramarital affair. ''Whatever Boggs's attitudes was, he was not seen by the people of Boston as s aying, 'I don't care what you think,' '' she says. ''On the other hand, Canseco was not elected to the All-Star team. I think that was very significant.'' Everyone agrees the future will see more athletes endorsing products. ''The Jordan deal was monstrous,'' says Dorfman. ''How much Gatorade will people have to drink for that much money to pay for itself? But I think what it says is that advertisers think the market is bottomless.'' ''More and more,'' says Lanktree, ''I don't know that there is a limit.''


LOAD-DATE: October 13, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


GRAPHIC: Photo; Photo (COLOR) by AP ... Philadelphia 76ers bad boy Charles Barkley, who has had a few run-ins with fans. Photo by AP ... Former Oklahoma and Seattle Seahawk football player Brian Bosworth's mouth turned out to be larger than his talent. Photo by File ... Wrestler Hulk Hogan was recently implicated as a customer in a steroid distribution case.


Copyright 1991 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.

 

401 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)


December 5, 1991, THURSDAY, FIVE STAR Edition


HOW TO SELECT ATHLETIC SHOES FOR YOUR SPORT


BYLINE: Scripps Howard News Service


SECTION: STYLE WEST; Pg. 6


LENGTH: 184 words


 

HERE ARE SOME tips on how to make sure your athletic shoes fit properly: (REST) Have both feet fitted while you are standing up. Make sure there is about a quarter-inch, about half a thumb, between the end of your longest toe and the end of the shoe. The heel area should be snug with no slip. The heel should appear square when viewed from the rear. A tapered heel invites instability. Pay particular attention to the width of the shoe. It should not be too snug, or feel sloppy. Check the arch area for fit. Is the arch high enough? Too high? Experienced fitters will check for pronation (foot rolls inward) and supination (foot rolls outward). Suggested for pronation are Nike's Air Anodyne and Asex Gel Epirus. Suggested for supinators are the Skylon model by Nike and the Saucony Azura. Check for personal comfort. Some runners, for instance, like cushioning shoes. Others prefer to feel the ground. Athletic shoes are available that are designed to fit every customer's preference. Ask about and try air-system fits. Also try less-expensive fits. Only you can decide which is best.


LOAD-DATE: October 13, 1993


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1991 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.

    NOTES TO THE ACCOUNTS . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .PG 12, 13,
                                                                      14, 15,
                                                                      16, 17
    1 ACCOUNTING POLICIES . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .PG 12

    12 TANGIBLE FIXED ASSETS . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . PG 14

    14 DEBTORS . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . PG 15
    15 CREDITORS: AMOUNTS FALLING DUE WITHIN ONE YEAR . . . . . . .PG 16
    16 PROVISIONS FOR LIABILITIES AND CHARGES . . . . . . . . . . .PG 16
    17 CALLED UP SHARE CAPITAL . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . PG 16
    18 SHARE PREMIUM ACCOUNT . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . PG 16
    19 PROFIT AND LOSS ACCOUNT . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . PG 16

UK SIC:
8380 Advertising
8395 Business services not elsewhere specified


INDUSTRY SEC CODES:

TEXT:
 [*1] 
CIA GROUP PLC - 1991 ANNUAL REPORT AND ACCOUNTS
 
ADVERTISING MEDIA SPECIALISTS
 
Successfully putting into practice the concept of 'Think Global -
Act Local.
 
Now more able than ever to provide clients with increased
accountability from their advertising.
 
An unbroken record of turnover, profit and EPS growth, underpinned
by an increasing asset base.
 
To deliver unparalleled media value for our clients consistently
through time and across all their markets.
 
FINANCIAL HIGHLIGHTS
 
"CIA bucks sector trend with 16% rise"
Financial Times, 13 March 1992
Thirteenth consecutive year of increased turnover and profits.
Pre-tax profits increased by 16% to L2.8 million (1990: L2.4m),
despite the harsh trading environment.
 
Earnings per share increased by 17% to 13.62p (1990 - 11.65p).
Dividend increased by 17% over last year to 3.75p per share.
TURNOVER  L(m)
Graph in original
 
PROFIT BEFORE TAX L(000)
Graph in original.
 
EARNINGS PER SHARE (p)
Graph in original.
 
DIVIDEND PER SHARE (p)
Graph in original.
GROUP SERVICES
 
We have developed an extensive range of specialist services to
provide tailor-made solutions to clients' media and wider
communications needs.
 
Media Planning and Buying
Media Research
Media Evaluation
Regional Media Unit
Direct Marketing
Centralised Planning and Buying
Market Assessment
Communications Management
International
Database Marketing
Media Sponsorship
GROUP STRUCTURE
 
CIA BILLETT - 100%
Comprehensive media services to consumer advertisers in the UK
market. Specialist units for research, consultancy and regional
media.
 
CIA DIRECT - 100%
Specialists in planning, buying, response analysis and prediction
for direct marketing clients.
 
CIA INTERNATIONAL - 100%
Specialists in the co-ordination and quality control of
multi-national advertising campaigns.
 
CIA COMMUNICATIONS MANAGEMENT - 100%
Planning, management and control of clients' marketing
communications.
 
WM MEDIA - 50%
Joint venture with advertising agency Woollams Moira Gaskin
O'Malley servicing the media requirements of their clients.
 
IDK MEDIA - 51%
Specialists in centralised planning and buying for major
multi-product advertisers.
 
MEDIA SOLUTIONS - 70%
UK's largest regional media planning and buying company, based in
Manchester.
 
20/20 Media - 50%
Joint venture with advertising agency Delaney Fletcher Slaymaker
Delaney and Bozell, servicing the media requirements of their
clients.
 
 [*2] 
CHAIRMAN'S STATEMENT
 
" Our main success was achieved outside the UK where a
determination to build a genuine European culture into our service
has won rapid recognition from multi-national advertisers."
 
Despite the very tough market conditions in the UK, I am delighted
to be able to announce record results once more.
 
The shift in our business to the second half of the year occurred
as predicted in the Interim Report and the final outcome for 1991
was that turnover edged ahead by 4% to L172m while profits were up
by 16% to L2.8m. Earnings per share increased by 17% to 13.62p.
 
1991 was our thirteenth consecutive year of increased turnover and
profits. We believe this to be an unrivalled growth record in our
sector. The Board is proposing that the final dividend is increased
to 2.60p per ordinary share payable on 5 May 1992 to shareholders
on the Register of Members at 2 April 1992. This gives a total
dividend for the year of 3.75p per ordinary share.
 
We finished the year the way we began it - with the country in deep
recession and with no clear signs of any improvement. Not
surprisingly, this was the most challenging year for CIA since we
started trading in 1976.
 
The latest Advertising Association estimate for 1991 is that media
spend in real terms was down by 10% following a 9% decline in 1990
but even in a depressed market there are always opportunities -
particularly for a company that is constantly searching out those
opportunities and which has the added advantage of strong cash
reserves.
 
Clearly we were not immune to client cut-backs in expenditure and
these continued almost to the end of the year. However, we
controlled costs well without damaging the quality of our service;
we converted more of our client remuneration to performance-
related payment; we benefited from emerging economies of scale; we
improved our terms with suppliers; we made good use of our cash
reserves; we invested heavily - and successfully - in our service
for multi-national advertisers and finally, we were more active
corporately.
 
The net effect of all these measures was that we improved our
margins slightly despite the pressures of the market-place.
 
ACQUISITIONS AND JOINT VENTURES
 
In October we acquired 70% of Manchester-based Media Solutions from
Bowden Dyble Hayes and Partners, part of Gold Greenlees Trott. Media
Solutions is the largest regional media independent in the UK and
at a cost of L700,000 provides us with a strong base and a
highly-respected company in the UK's second largest advertising
market.
 
A cautious but energetic approach to corporate growth, building on
established and tested relationships.
 
In December we set up a joint venture with the London advertising
agency DFSD Bozell. This new company, 20/20 Media, which commenced
trading in January 1992, will provide a highly comprehensive media
service for DFSD Bozell's clients drawing upon the resources of
the CIA Group. It is anticipated that these two ventures will
account for some L40m of additional turnover for the Group in 1992.
NEW BUSINESS
 
In some areas our new business record was not as buoyant as we have
come to expect although overall the annualised value of net new
business gains amounted to a satisfactory L51m compared with L35m
in 1990. Our main success was achieved internationally by CIA
International working in tandem with our overseas affiliates - each
of them amongst the very best media professionals in their
respective markets. Through this we have built a genuine European
culture into our service which has won rapid recognition from
multinational advertisers.
 
A significant number of international accounts are also being won
as a result of clients' satisfaction with the service provided by
our UK companies. The 'cross-fertilisation' of business between
companies is thus now starting to become a reality in the Group and
bodes well for the future.
 
 [*3] 
CHAIRMAN'S STATEMENT CONTINUED
 
OUR PEOPLE
 
Our Group now consists of eight operating companies and the
likelihood is that this number will continue to grow, particularly
as we expand internationally. We have found that the concept of
small, highly accountable companies sharing central resources is
particularly attractive in a people business and we have proved
this to be a winning formula.
 
As always our people are the key: people at all levels. They are
our talent base. We have been very fortunate to have a team that
has worked extremely hard in such a tough year. Reductions in
clients' budgets allied with short-term decision-taking increase
the workload considerably.
 
The onus is on us to continue to develop our team. This is not only
about training people and giving them the opportunity to develop
but also ensuring that our 'casting' is right so that people are as
often as possible in positions, or promoted to positions, that suit
their skills and experience. Beyond that we need to continue to
inject new blood into the Group as new skills are required to
complement and build on the success of our existing team.
 
Managing change is the challenge and in this respect it has become
impractical for one board to deal with the many important issues
which arise in a growing group of our size. We have therefore
restructured our senior management into two companies. A UK holding
company will be responsible for UK operations to ensure that we not
only maintain but also continue to improve our service to clients
in this highly competitive market. This will leave CIA Group PLC to
concentrate upon corporate development, strategic and policy issues
and financial control from a Group perspective.
 
CIA INTERNATIONAL NETWORK

                             World

 [*4] 
CHAIRMAN'S STATEMENT CONTINUED
 
1992
 
Although the Advertising Association is forecasting growth in
advertising spend in real terms of 5% over 1991, there are
currently no clear signs of the recession lifting. However, it is
also true to say that we have yet to see any signs of the feared
'double-dip' in the advertising industry. Consequently, clients'
budgets appear relatively stable and we are anticipating that there
may he a very small rate of growth from 1991's low base.
 
Clients are continuing to release their budgets at relatively short
notice, increasing both work pressures and the level of uncertainty
among media owners. The UK TV market is particularly unsettled
following the TV franchise awards, with ITV contractors facing an
expanding BSkyB and the prospect of Channel 4 selling its airtime
competitively in 1993. It is not only with television that there
are substantial changes - there are new radio stations, both local
and national, and the recession is having a dramatic effect on
circulations - both upwards and downwards - among newspapers and
magazines as consumers are forced to re-evaluate their priorities.
 
This all adds to the complexity of the market and requires ever
more resource to measure and assess the effect on reaching
prospective purchasers of advertisers' products and services. Such
a climate may be highly demanding but it is ideal for the media
specialist. However, now we are in the third year of a recession,
competitive pressure is intense and we will need to be both
resilient and resourceful to continue our strong progress. Indeed
CIA plans to be increasingly innovative in 1992. The year has
started promisingly with some good new business wins.
 
CIA International has got off to a particularly strong start and we
are expecting our international billings to more than double in
1992, with the majority of business in Europe. In 1992 the Group
will also benefit from a full year's contribution from Media
Solutions and 20/20 Media. As our business base grows in the UK we
can expect to see increasing economies of scale.
 
In February we started a new venture, CIA Communications
Management. This will take us into the broader field of advising
clients in the total area of advertising and marketing
communications. However, unlike conventionally-structured full
service agencies, we will not be building a heavy infrastructure
but will have a small team of advisors and coordinators at the
centre, placing all creative and other services with the most
appropriate supplier. The service will be truly independent in its
advice, highly flexible and offer extremely good value; qualities
that we believe are most appropriate to the nineties.
 
Also in February we took a substantial minority stake in a new
company specialising in the buying of poster campaigns, Outdoor
Focus. Two major agencies, Omnicom UK and FCB are also backing this
venture. Outdoor Focus enables us to enter the well-established
sub-sector of outdoor media specialists where we have not
previously been represented Although the Group is now regarded as a
major player, we have less than 10% of the highly fragmented UK
media market and less than 1% of multi-national clients'
advertising budgets worldwide. So there is still plenty of scope
for all our companies to grow organically. However acquisitions,
joint ventures and alliances are also likely to play an important
role in our developement over the next few years.
 
In the UK, we shall continue to seek opportunities to add to our
existing operations where this can be achieved on the basis of
justifiable criteria. The continuing recession may add short-term
opportunities in this area. It remains our objective to retain a
position amongst the top buying points in the UK.
 
TOP TEN UK MEDIA BUYERS            Lm
 
1      Zenith Media             470.5
 
2      JWT                      240.5
 
3      CIA Group                211.0
 
4      Initiative Media         178.6
 
5      Media Centre             171.9
 
6      O&M                      169.1
 
7      BMP DDB Needham          166.8
 
8      TMD Holdings             153.2
 
9      McCann Erickson          148.1
 
10     Lowe Howard-Spink        145.4
 
Source: Media Register - MEAL Y/E December 1991
Mainland Europe is a priority although we believe that the historic
British practice of seeking 100% control of companies may not
always be the most appropriate solution in building a high quality
international service, particularly in Europe, if we wish to have
senior management committed to and involved with their clients on a
day-to-day basis.
 
We continue to regard the USA also as an important area for growth
as it represents nearly 50% of the world's advertising market and
media specialists have only a small but fastgrowing share.
However, we are well aware that the USA historically has provided
some uncomfortable experiences for many marketing services
companies and we would only consider buying high quality companies
that we know well and which would not overstretch either our
management resource or our balance sheet.
 
In summary, we enter 1992 in our strongest cash position ever and
continue to explore opportunities for corporate growth
energetically albeit on a highly selective basis. Despite the
rigours of the market, we are in a confident mood to face the
challenges and opportunities of a changing industry.
 
Chris Ingram
Chairman
 
 
 [*5] 
SENIOR MANAGEMENT
 
CIA BILLETT
 
Ian Rogers
John Billett
 
CIA DIRECT
 
Ian Payne
Ian Prager
 
CIA INTERNATIONAL
 
Rick Sheldon
Mike Morris
 
CIA COMMUNICATIONS MANAGEMENT
 
Brian Haworth
John Terris
 
IDK MEDIA
 
John Duggan
Tony Kenyon
 
MEDIA SOLUTIONS
 
Ray Sale
WM Media
Robert Norman
 
20/20 MEDIA
 
Paul Woolmington
 
CIA GROUP
 
Tony Richardson
Ashley Martin
Peter Toynton
Our eight autonomous operating companies are structured to provide
maximum client focus through the development of areas of real
expertise. It is this philosophy that has helped to generate growth
unrivalled in our sector over the last five years.
 
REVIEW OF OPERATIONS
 
CIA Group is now the largest media independent in the UK and is
among the top three buyers of media in the country. To give a
simple indication of the scale of our activity, in 1991 our 120
media executives made over 155,000 bookings on TV and radio, in
newspapers and magazines as well as on posters and in cinemas. The
number of different media owners with whom we were dealing on
behalf of our 260 clients was more than 3,000: another sign of the
increasing complexity of the business in which we operate.
 
CIA BILLETT
 
The Group's core company suffered a small decrease in billings in
1991 although client losses were largely offset by the addition of
Gateway Foodmarkets in February 1991 and TSB in January 1992. The
latter account, billing L18m, was CIA Billett's largest-ever win.
 
The company was restructured in January 1992 into four integrated,
multi-media groups giving a stronger client focus and making it
better able to deal with an ever more complex media environment.
CIA Billett's clients are increasingly using CIA's services
internationally e.g. DHL, Wrigley and Wrangler.
 
The company is steadily increasing its investment in new planning
systems to enhance its understanding of consumers and their media
usage. The cumulative investment in technology puts the company at
the forefront of the industry in this field and ensures that all
executives have instant access to all relevant planning and buying
data.
 
Virtually all employees are now electronically linked by computer
network.
 
In February 1992 the company was appointed to advise the new
national radio station, Classic FM, and also by BSkyB to handle
"Tune-in" promotions. This increases the company's already strong
portfolio of media owner clients including IPC and Thames TV and
confirms CIA Billett's position as "The Surgeons' Surgeon".
 
As the Group's largest company, CIA Billett is active on an
industry basis, usually working with the Association of Media
Independents, where issues may impinge on the Group's fortunes.
Recently these have included the Newspaper Publishers Association's
planned introduction of new terms and conditions and the possible
arrival of media broking in the UK. CIA Billett performed strongly
in Media Week's Media Planning Awards winning 10 citations in the
Business Press Awards in June and a further 10 in October in the
Consumer Press Awards. The company is now the leading media
independent in these awards.
 
 [*6] 
REVIEW OF OPERATIONS CONTINUED
 
CIA DIRECT
 
1991 was a year of consolidation with two important wins - National
Westminster Bank (non-broadcast) and Bonus Print. The company is
also now handling all media planning and buying for Brann Direct
Marketing - one of the country's leading direct marketing
agencies.
 
The company is continuing to invest in the development of CARCIA -
the response analysis and prediction system - supported by the
Group's information technology department. At the same time CIA
Direct has been involved in a significant move by certain of its
clients into television as a direct response medium with TimeLife
Books, Encyclopaedia Britannica and Franklin Mint advertising on
television for the first time.
 
Important promotions were announced during the year - Ian Payne to
Deputy Chairman, Ian Prager to Managing Director and Andy Sloan as
the company's fifth board director. 1992 has started well with the
winning of Apricot Computers.
 
CIA INTERNATIONAL
 
Growth has continued apace with turnover trebled in 1991 and
expected to more than double in 1992.
 
CIA Group companies work for over thirty of 'The Times' Top 100
listed companies.
 
The company now has 17 executives of whom 13 are non-British
ensuring a truly multi-national, multi-lingual culture. This is the
largest multinational media quality control and co-ordination
operation in Europe. Equally important, the company has strong,
developing relationships with overseas affiliates all of whom have
been hand-picked on the basis of the quality of their services.
 
The advantages of this structure are that not only can we
communicate effectively with the local media and the clients'
local offices but that we also start with a strong understanding of
each country's culture.
 
In April the successful launch of the service with creative agency
Bartle Bogle Hegarty led to the winning of Dunhill and Shell
(Corporate) in 1991. Separately, other client wins included Honda
Europe, BT International, DHL and additional work from Franklin
Mint, Calvin Klein, Nike and Wrigley.
 
The company has also negotiated the first ever pan-European
magazine deals with Cosmopolitan a countries and subsequently with
Marie Claire - in both cases the advertiser was Nike.
 
Strong growth has led to important appointments - Rick Sheldon
joined as Deputy Chairman, Mike Morris was promoted to Managing
Director and Steve Black to director. Additionally, Christine James
and Juan Plata were promoted to associate directors.
 
CIA's joint ventures and affiliations reflect the trend towards
concentration of media buying power.
 
In the Media and Marketing Europe Awards CIA International won first
prize for Best Pan-European Television Campaign for its work on
Nike.
 
IDK MEDIA
 
IDK continues to occupy a unique position in the market-place with
its specialised, centralised planning and buying service for major,
multibrand advertisers.
 
The main client base remained stable with the addition of Cellnet
and Allied Breweries' Burton Ale although in overall terms
billings were down due to the effects of recession.
 
A more aggressive new business initiative has been introduced in
1992 and two new directors appointed - Nigel Allmond and Edward
Lloyd Barnes.
 
WM MEDIA
 
This joint venture with advertising agency Woollams Moira Gaskin
O'Malley experienced reduced billings in the first half of 1991 due
to client cut-backs in the recession. However' a strong run of new
business wins in the fourth quarter brought Legal and General,
Jordans Cereals, S4C (Channel 4 in Wales) as clients together with
a further assignment from Freemans PLC.
 
The company has an increasingly important role in helping to win
and develop business for the expanding WMGO Group of marketing and
advertising services companies.
 
WM Media enters 1992 with a broader and more substantial client
base and with good development prospects.
 
MEDIA SOLUTIONS
 
In October the Group acquired 70% of Media Solutions from Bowden
Dyble Hayes and Partners. Media Solutions' billing is split
approximately 50/50 between BDHP clients and the company's own
direct clients.
 
In general terms 1991 was a difficult trading year in the North
West with little prospect of recovery in 1992. Notwithstanding
this, Media Solutions is forecasting substantial growth through
major new business gains in 1991 including Magnet Trade, OKI
Printers and BNFL (Sellafield Visitor Centre). In December the
company won NORWEB (North Western Electricity Board) - Media
Solutions' biggest ever win and one of the most prestigious
accounts in the North West.
 
The recession has highlighted the importance to clients and
suppliers alike of our sound financial management and strong
balance sheet when dealing with the scale of cash flows involved in
media advertising.
 
 [*7] 
DIRECTORS' REPORT
 
For the year ended 31 December 1991
The directors present their report and the audited financial
statements for the year ended 31 December 1991.
 
PRINCIPAL ACTIVITY
 
The Group operates as advertising media specialists providing
services related to the planning of advertising campaigns and the
buying of time and space primarily in broadcast and published
media.
 
RESULTS, REVIEW OF THE YEAR AND FUTURE PROSPECTS
 
The Group's results are set out on page 22. A review of the year
and of future prospects is contained in the Chairman's Statement
on pages 6 to 9.
 
DIVIDENDS
 
An interim dividend of 1.15p per share was paid on 4 October 1991.
The directors now recommend the payment of a final dividend of
2.60p per share. Subject to approval by members, the final dividend
will be paid on 5 May 1992 to ordinary shareholders on the register
on 2 April 1992.
 
FIXED ASSETS
 
A summary of changes in the Group's tangible fixed assets during
the year is given in note 12 to the financial statements.
 
DIRECTORS
 
The directors of the Company who served during the year are listed
below. Messrs Billett, Payne and Terris resigned from the board on
12 March 1992 to join the CIA (UK) Holdings board.
 
Mr P S Gummer will retire at the forthcoming Annual General Meeting
in accordance with the Articles of Association and, being eligible,
offers himself for re-election. He does not have a service contract
with the Company. Peter Gummer, aged 49, who was first appointed a
non-executive director on 5 February 1990, is Chairman of Shandwick
PLC. He is a member of the Arts Council of Great Britain, the
National Health Service Policy Board and the London Board of the
Halifax Building Society.
 
Our other non-executive director, Mr B R Matthews, aged 66, was
first appointed to the board on 16 October 1989. He was previously
managing director of News International plc and has wide experience
of the media market. Having also served as a non-executive director
of News Corporation Limited, Bruce Matthews currently holds a range
of other non-executive directorships, including British Transport
Advertising Limited and Satellite Information Services Limited,
being Chairman of both.
 
No contracts of significance with any director, other than service
contracts, have existed during the year ended 31 December 1991 nor
have any been entered into since that date by the Company or any of
its subsidiary undertakings.
 
 [*8] 
DIRECTORS' REPORT CONTINUED
 
DIRECTORS' SHARE INTERESTS
 
Beneficial interests of the  directors  in the share capital of the
Company  were as set out in the table below  and  the  notes  which
follow:
 
                   Ordinary shares          Options over
                      of 5p each          ordinary shares
 
                 31 Dec       1 Jan      31 Dec       1 Jan
                   1991        1991        1991        1991
 
C J Ingram    4,100,436   4,100,436      10,137       7,024
 
J M Billett     503,369     553,369      10,137       7,024
 
I T Payne       941,245     941,245           -           -
 
J M Terris      324,531     152,085           -     324,446
 
P A Toynton     227,632     113,619      10,137     157,537
 
P S Gummer        9,800       9,800           -           -
 
B R Matthews      5,000       5,000           -           -
Mr I T Payne also had a non-beneficial interest in 1,500 (1 January
1991-1,500) ordinary shares of the Company and disposed of a
beneficial interest in 300,000 shares on 9 January 1992.
 
A wholly owned subsidiary undertaking of the Company, The CIA Trust
Company (1990) Limited, held in its capacity as sole trustee of the
CIA Group 1990 Employee Benefit Trust, 155,000 ordinary shares in
the capital of the Company as at 31 December 1991 (1 January 1991 -
nil) and has subsequently acquired, in that capacity, a further
75,000 such shares.
 
As the directors of the Company are amongst the potential
beneficiaries of the Trust, each is deemed to have a potential
interest in the share held by it, although none has received any
benefit under the Trust.
 
Furthermore, as Messrs Gummer, Ingram, Matthews and Toynton are
amongst the directors of the trustee company each is deemed to have
a non-beneficial interest in such shares. Apart from the foregoing
there were no other changes in directors' share interests between
31 December 1991 and 11 March 1992.

substantial share interests at 11 March 1992 in addition to entries
relating to those persons who were directors of the  Company at the
year end.

 [*9] 
DIRECTORS' REPORT CONTINUED
 
NOTICE OF ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING
 
At the Annual General Meeting of the Company held on 26 April 1991
shareholders gave the Company qualified authority to (i) allot
shares; (ii) issue a limited number of shares without the
application of preemption rights in favour of existing
shareholders; and (iii) purchase up to 1 million of its own shares.
Whilst a number of shares have been allotted for cash under the
Company's share option schemes the Company has not otherwise
utilised these authorities since their grant and the directors have
no present intention of so doing. However these authorities expire
on the day of the forthcoming Annual General Meeting and the
directors consider it prudent to seek similar authorities for the
period to the 1993 Annual General Meeting.
 
If approved, Resolution 5, an Ordinary Resolution, would give the
directors authority to allot shares within numeric limits;
Resolution 6, a Special Resolution, to issue a number of equity
securities not exceeding 5 per cent of the Company's issued share
capital; and Resolution 7, a Special Resolution, to purchase up to
1 million of the Company's shares, subject in each case to the
constraints and limits set out in the resolutions. Pursuant to
resolutions dated 16 October 1989 the Company introduced both a
Performance Related Executive Share Option Scheme ("the 1989
Executive Scheme") and a Savings Related Share Option Scheme ("the
1989 SAYE Scheme").
 
The directors now wish to amend the rules of these schemes ("the
Scheme Rules") to take advantage of legislative changes, ease
administration and clarify and improve the drafting of the Scheme
Rules.
 
The proposed amendments to the rules of the 1989 Executive Scheme
would alter the procedure for the grant of options so that options
are granted subject to the grantee's right to renounce the option
in whole or part within the 14 days following grant. It is also
proposed to enable the directors to grant options under the 1989
Executive Scheme at an option price up to 15% below the market
price of the Company's shares on the date of grant. However, the
option will only be exercisable at that price if the Company's
share price over a 5 year period between grant and exercise
out-performs the RPI by an average of 2% per annum. Such option
could also be granted on terms such that it would be exercisable at
such market price between 3 and 10 years from the date of grant.
 
Amendments are also proposed to the rules of the 1989 Executive
Scheme which would clarify the rights of option holders on a change
in control of the Company and make administrative revisions to the
existing rules.
 
The proposed amendments to the 1989 SAYE Scheme would increase to
L250 the maximum monthly savings an individual may make under the
scheme and would provide that, in calculating the maximum number of
shares over which options may be granted under the 1989 SAYE
Scheme, options granted over shares which were issued at the time
of their grant would be ignored.
 
The proposed amendments to the Scheme Rules, which, in order to
preserve the approved status of the schemes are subject to Inland
Revenue approval, will ensure that both schemes comply with the
guidelines set down by the Association of British Insurers.
 
Copies of the full texts of the Scheme Rules and the proposed
amendments to both the 1989 SAYE Scheme and the 1989 Executive
Scheme may be inspected at the registered office of the Company and
at the offices of Alsop Wilkinson 6 Dowgate Hill London EC4R 2SS at
any time during normal business hours on weekdays (Saturday and
public holidays excepted) up to and including the day of the Annual
General Meeting and at the meeting.
 
CHARITABLE DONATIONS
 
During the year the Group made charitable donations of L24,000. No
political donations were made.
 
TAXATION STATUS
 
The Company is a close company as defined by the Income and
Corporation Taxes Act 1988.
 
AUDITORS
 
Stoy Hayward have expressed their willingness to continue in office
and a resolution to re-appoint them and to authorise the directors
to fix their remuneration will be proposed at the Annual General
Meeting.
 
On behalf of the board
P A Toynton
Director
12 March 1992

 [*12] 
NOTES TO THE ACCOUNTS
 
1 ACCOUNTING POLICIES
 
The principal accounting policies, all of which have been applied
consistently throughout the year and the preceding year, are:-
 
(A) BASIS OF ACCOUNTING
 
The accounts have been prepared under the historical cost
convention and to comply in all material respects with applicable
accounting standards.
 
(B) BASIS OF CONSOLIDATION
 
The Group accounts consolidate the accounts of CIA Group PLC and
all its subsidiary undertakings up to the balance sheet date. The
results of subsidiary undertakings acquired or disposed of in the
year are included in the consolidated profit and loss account from
the date of acquisition or up to the date of disposal.
 
(C) GROSS BILLINGS, TURNOVER AND RECOGNITION OF INCOME
 
Gross billings represent the cost of advertising placed, after
negotiated discounts and excluding VAT, calculated in line with the
Association of Media Independents' recommended formula.
 
Turnover comprises the net value of amounts invoiced to clients,
excluding VAT, for services in the normal course of business and
reflects the cost of advertising expenditure of the Group's
clients and the related commissions and fees charged. Commissions
are recognised as income when the related advertisement appears.
Fees are recognised as income when they are billed in accordance
with the agreements with clients.
 
(D) TANGIBLE FIXED ASSETS
 
Fixed assets are shown at cost less accumulated depreciation.
Depreciation is provided at rates calculated to write off the
cost, less estimated residual value, of each asset on a
straight-line basis over its estimated useful life as follows:
 
Leasehold improvements                -  10%  per  annum
Office machinery                      -  20%  per  annum
Motor vehicles                        -  25%  per  annum
Furniture, fixtures and fittings      -  10%  per  annum
Tangible fixed assets owned by third parties and leased to the
Group under terms which transfer substantially all the risks and
rewards of ownership are recorded in the balance sheet as assets.
Obligations for future lease payments are included in creditors.
Depreciation is provided to write off these assets at the same
rates as for tangible fixed assets owned by the Group. A finance
charge is made to the profit and loss account each year so as to
provide a constant periodic rate of charge.
 
(E) TAXATION
 
Corporation tax payable is provided on taxable profits at the
current rates. Deferred taxation (which arises from differences in
the timing of the recognition of items in the accounts and by the
tax authorities) has been calculated by the liability method.
Deferred tax is provided at current rates of taxation on timing
differences to the extent that a tax liability is expected to arise
in the foreseeable future.
 
(F) ASSOCIATED UNDERTAKINGS
 
The consolidated financial statements include the appropriate share
of the results of associated undertakings. An associated
undertaking is one in which a substantial equity shareholding is
held on a long term basis and there is participation in commercial
and financial policy decisions.
 
(G) FOREIGN CURRENCY
 
Transactions denominated in foreign currencies are recorded at
actual exchange rates at the date of the transaction. Monetary
assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies are
reported at the rates of exchange prevailing at the balance sheet
date. Any gain or loss subsequent to the date of the transaction is
dealt with in the profit and loss account.
 
 [*13]

within the UK.

PRINCIPAL SUBSIDIARY UNDERTAKINGS:
                                                     Description
                       County of                     & proportion
                    registration  Principal          proportion of
                   and operation  activity           shares held
 
CIA Billett & Company
Limited                  England  Media specialists  100%   Ord.
 
CIA International        England  International
Limited                           media specialists  100%   Ord.
 
CIA Direct Limited       England  Direct marketing
                                  specialists        100%   Ord.
 
Media Solutions Limited  England  Media specialists   70%   Ord.
 
I.D.K. Media Limited     England  Media specialists   51%   Ord.
 
W M Media Limited        England  Media specialists   50%   Ord.
 
20/20 Media Limited      England  Media specialists   50%   Ord.
On 17 October 1991 the Company acquired 70% of the issued share
capital of Media Solutions Limited, a Manchester-based media
specialist, for a consideration of L700,000 (net of expenses).
Media Solutions Limited contributed L46,000 to the 1991 group
pre-tax profit since the date of acquisition. The last reported
results of Media Solutions Limited were for the year to 30 April
1991 which showed a pre-tax profit of L215,000.
 
The minority shareholders in I.D.K. Media Limited have an option to
require the Company to purchase, at any time, their shares for a
consideration based on the level of profit of I.D.K. Media Limited.
WM Media Limited, in which the Company has a participating
interest, is managed on a unified basis with the Company and
accordingly its results are consolidated within these accounts.
WMGO Group Limited (being the other shareholder of WM Media
Limited) has an option to purchase, at any time, the shares held by
the Company in WM Media Limited. If the option is exercised, the
price is to be based on the level of profit of WM Media Limited.
 
20/20 Media Limited was incorporated on 11 December 1991 and
commenced trading on 2 January 1992.

AUDITORS' REPORT
 
To the Members of CIA Group PLC
We have audited the financial statements on pages 22 to 33 in
accordance with Auditing Standards.
 
In our opinion the financial statements give a true and fair view
of the state of affairs of the Company and the Group at 31 December
1991 and of the profit and cash flows of the Group for the year
ended on that date and have been properly prepared in accordance
with the Companies Act 1985.
 
Stoy Hayward
Chartered Accountants & Registered Auditor
8 Baker Street
London W1M 1DA
12 March 1992
 
 
 [*19] 
NOTICE OF ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING
 
Notice is hereby given that the 11th Annual General Meeting of the
Company will be held at 1 Paris Garden London SE1 8NU on Monday 27
April 1992 at 12 noon for the purpose of transacting the following
business:
 
ORDINARY BUSINESS
 
1 To receive and adopt the report of the directors and audited
accounts for the year ended 31 December 1991.
 
2 To declare a final dividend.
3 To re-elect Mr P S Gummer as a director of the Company.
4 To re-appoint Stoy Hayward as auditors and to authorise the
directors to fix their remuneration.
 
SPECIAL BUSINESS
 
To consider and if thought fit to pass the following Resolution as
an Ordinary Resolution:
 
5 THAT the directors be and are hereby generally and
unconditionally authorised for the purposes of Section 80 of the
Companies Act 1985 ("the Act") to exercise all the powers of the
Company to allot relevant securities (within the meaning of Section
80(2) of the Act) up to an aggregate nominal amount of L167,000
provided that this authority shall expire at the conclusion of the
next Annual General Meeting of the Company after the passing of
this Resolution except that the Company may before the expiry of
such authority make an offer or agreement which would or might
require relevant securities to be allotted after the expiry of such
authority and the directors may allot relevant securities in
pursuance of any such offer or agreement as if the authority
conferred hereby had not expired, this authority to replace any
existing like authority which is hereby revoked with immediate
effect.
 
To consider and if thought fit to pass the following Resolutions as
Special Resolutions:
 
6 THAT subject to the passing of Resolution 5 above the directors
be and are hereby authorised pursuant to Section 95 of the
Companies Act 1985 ("the Act") to allot equity securities (as
defined in Section 94 of the Act) of the Company as if Section
89(1) of the Act did not apply to such allotment PROVIDED THAT if
the allotment is for cash otherwise than pursuant to a rights issue
it shall not exceed five per cent of the present nominal value of
the issued ordinary share capital of the Company such authority
expiring at the conclusion of the next Annual General Meeting of
the Company, except that the directors may before such expiry make
an offer or agreement which would or might require equity
securities to be allotted after such expiry and the directors may
allot equity securities in pursuance of such offer or agreement as
if the authority conferred hereby had not expired.
 
7 THAT the Company be and is hereby generally and unconditionally
authorised in accordance with its Articles of Association and
Chapter VII of the Companies Act 1985 ("the Act") to make market
purchases (within the meaning of Section 163(3) of the Act) of up
to an aggregate of 1,000,000 ordinary shares of 5p each in its
capital at a price not lower than the nominal value of such shares
and not higher than 105% of the price at which business is done in
the Company's shares in the Unlisted Securities Market (as derived
from the USM Appendix to The Stock Exchange Daily Official List) on
the ten business days immediately preceding the day on which such
ordinary shares are contracted to be purchased (in each case
exclusive of expenses) PROVIDED THAT this authority will only be
exercised if so to do will result in an increase in earnings per
share and is in the best interests of the shareholders generally
such authority expiring at the conclusion of the next Annual
General Meeting of the Company, except that the Company may
purchase shares at any later date where such purchase is pursuant
to any contract made by the Company before expiry of this
authority.
 
To consider and if thought fit to pass the following Resolutions as
Ordinary Resolutions-

December 1991.

rules of the CIA 1989 Savings Related Share Option Scheme in the
manner described on page 20 of the Report of the Directors of the
Company in respect of the year ended 31 December 1991.

need not be a member.

ordinary shareholder from attending and voting in person if they
subsequently choose to do so.

407 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


January 15, 1991, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


SPORTS BUSINESS;
Even reputations can be insured


BYLINE: Michael Hiestand


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 364 words


''Image insurance'' isn't for everybody. But for companies launching products or ad campaigns centered on pro athletes, it's a hedge against the frailty of endorsers' personal reputations.

Ted Dipple, president of Woburn, Mass.-based American Specialty Underwriters, says premiums for the new policies can cost 1% to 3% of the total revenues involved. Payoffs come if an athlete-endorser is involved in the ''commission of a criminal act, offense against public taste or decency, an occurrence tending to degrade, scorn or ridicule a large section of the community.'' 

The new policies aren't big sellers, says Dipple, ''because not many companies know they're available.''
 
HIGH TECH: This week, Nike begins shooting its Super Bowl TV commercial - using Los Angeles as a backdrop. Nike will project images of some of its famous athlete-endorsers such as John McEnroe on buildings - creating likenesses as tall as 17 stories. The ad, for new Nike shoes called Air 180, will star triathlete Mark Allen. ... Fans will be able to hear the race track's public address announcer at the Mickey Thompson Off-Road Gran Prix in Anaheim, Calif., Saturday, thanks to a limited range radio signal that fans can pick up on transistor radios. ... The government of the Caribbean nation of St. Vincent has put out an official NFL licensed product: 25,000 postage stamps meant to commemorate this year's Super Bowl. One set of the new stamps will picture action shots from previous Super Bowls.
 
BALTIC-BALL: A sports footnote to the current Soviet crackdown in the Baltic Republic of Lithuania: the ambitions of Enrico Kesayev of Vilnius, Lithuania. In a letter to The Wall Street Journal's Brussels bureau, Kesayev says he asked sports officials in Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia to help start a league for U.S.-style football. But ''nobody would bother with us as there were no stadiums with artificial covering, no sports costumes, no economic base.''

Though Kesayev says he could locate only six balls and no rule books in the Baltic republics, he started a team.

''Here only one conclusion should be made,'' says Kesayev. ''American football is a child of a market economy.''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


TYPE: Sportstalk


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

408 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


February 15, 1991, Friday, FINAL EDITION


Cleaning up on stocks' rally;
Among the biggest winners


BYLINE: Donna Rosato; Michelle Osborn


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 2B


LENGTH: 570 words


The current stock market rally has sprinkled gold dust on the feet of many shareholders, but none more than Bill Gates of Microsoft. Microsoft stock has more than doubled from a low of $ 47 last February, and he's added almost three-quarters of a billion dollars to his net worth since the stock market rally began last month.

Gates might be one of the rally's biggest winners, but he's not the only one. A random selection of some of the USA's richest shows how these multimillionaires have piled up their paper wealth. The data are 

based on the values of their   holdings Jan. 16, just before the rally

 

began, and closing prices Thursday:

- William Henry Gates III, 35, founder of Microsoft Corp. in Seattle. He held about 39.7 million common shares as of Jan. 30. The shares Jan. 16 were worth $ 3.26 billion at $ 82.25 a share. At $ 100 3/4 a share Thursday, their value has swollen to nearly $ 4 billion, a gain of $ 733.5 million, or 23%.

- Leon C. Hirsch , 63, chairman of U.S. Surgical Corp. in Norwalk, Conn. This maker of sutures and other surgical products has been one of the New York Stock Exchange's hottest stocks, nearly tripling in value since hitting a low of $ 25 1/2 last February. Hirsch, who owns 1.6 million shares, chalked up a gain of $ 33.3 million just between Jan. 16 and Thursday. The stock has soared 20 5/8 points in that time.

- Donald G. Fisher , 62, chairman and CEO of The Gap, has reaped big profits from the shares he owns in the specialty-clothing stores he co- founded. Gap stock has been seemingly untouched by the hard times hitting many other retail ers and has more than doubled in value since hitting its low of $ 22 last fall. Fisher owns 18.6 million Gap shares, which have leaped 6 1/4 points since Jan. 16 to $ 44 3/4, giving him a $ 116.2 million gain.

- Leslie H. Wexner , 54, founder of The Limited Inc. in Columbus, Ohio. Wexner, whose specialty-retail chain is one of the nation's largest, holds about 95 million shares of his company. Those shares have climbed $ 3 3/8 since the rally began for a net gain of $ 321.6 million, or 20%.
-

- Philip H. Knight , 52, CEO of Nike Inc. in Beaverton, Ore. The booming athletic-shoe market has endowed his almost 13 million shares with a $ 108.2 million net gain. Nike stock has jumped $ 8 3/8 a share since Jan. 16, or 32%.

- Bennett Dorrance, 44, and John T. Dorrance III, 45, of Philadelphia, heirs to the Campbell Soup Co. fortune their grandfather built. Each of the Dorrances directly owns 13.2 million Campbell shares. The shares have risen $ 13 since Jan. 16 for paper profits of $ 172.1 million for each Dorrance.

- Robert Edward ''Ted'' Turner , 52, of Turner Broadcasting System in Atlanta, owner of red-hot Cable News Network. Turner won't have any trouble paying for the opal and diamond engagement ring he gave Jane Fonda. He owns 32 million Class B shares and 55 million Class A shares in his company, and they've risen nearly $ 2 each. That gives Turner a $ 162.5 million gain.

- James D. Robinson III , 55, CEO of American Express Co. since 1977, and Sanford I. Weill, 57, CEO since 1989 of Primerica Corp. are two more beneficiaries of the rally. AmEx has jumped $ 6 3/8, netting Robinson a gain of $ 3.3 million. He holds 513,663 shares. Weill made $ 3.4 million on his 462,797 Primerica shares. The stock has climbed $ 7 1/4 since Jan. 16.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO; b/w (3)
 
CUTLINE: TURNER: A paper gain of $ 162.5 million. CUTLINE: KNIGHT: Worth $ 108.2 million more, on paper. CUTLINE: HIRSCH: Racked up paper profit of $ 33.3 million.


TYPE: Insiders


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

409 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


April 3, 1991, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION


White Sox, Bo near deal;
Nike says news could come today


BYLINE: Ben Brown; Rudy Martzke


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 1C


LENGTH: 242 words


''It's a deal for Bo with the White Sox,'' Nike spokeswoman Liz Dolan said Tuesday night, confirming speculation that Bo Jackson and the Chicago White Sox have all but agreed on a multiyear baseball contract.

The deal could be announced as early as today. The White Sox have scheduled a 10 a.m. EST news conference in Sarasota, Fla., their spring training headquarters.

''There will be doctors on the scene who will have good news about his condition,'' said Dolan, whose company prominently displays Jackson in multimillion-dollar shoe ads. ''It seems he'll be back sooner than expected.''

The Kansas City Royals, convinced that a football hip injury had put Jackson's baseball career in jeopardy, released him two weeks ago.

The White Sox apparently agree with Jackson's doctor, who has suggested that Jackson might be able to play baseball as early as mid-July. The contract is likely to reflect a sharing of the risk.

''This is great for Bo to get signed by a team that wants him,'' said Dolan.

Clemens' fine upheld by American League

Roger Clemens' $ 10,000 fine and five-game suspension were upheld by the American League Wednesday, setting the stage for an appeal to Commissioner Fay Vincent.

Clemens' attorney, Randy Hendricks, said AL President Dr. Bobby Brown's decision will be appealed to Vincent. The AL office said the penalties will be stayed until Vincent decides. Clemens could then pitch Boston's opener Monday.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

410 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


April 15, 1991, Monday, FINAL EDITION


Insiders at rally-riding medical firms sell too soon


BYLINE: Nancy Miller


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 4B


LENGTH: 581 words


After a long rally in medical stocks, insiders took profits last month - too early.

Leading the pack: Samuel Maslak, president of Acuson Corp., who sold 100,000 shares (5.7% of his stake) for $ 3.68 million, or $ 36.78 a share. He sold March 1-4. He owns 1.6 million shares worth $ 60 million at Friday's close of $ 37 1/2. 

Lifeline Systems Inc. Chief Executive Officer Arthur R. Phipps sold 60,000 shares, his entire stake, for about $ 1 million March 7. Average price per share: $ 17.38. Friday's close: $ 19. A spokeswoman for the Watertown, Mass., company said Phipps is using the money to build a house.

Ballard Medical Products Chairman Dale Ballard sold 77,500 shares (9% of his stake) March 5 for $ 30 each, or $ 2.3 million. Friday's close: $ 37 1/4. He still owns 776,268 shares worth $ 28.9 million. Amgen

executive Daryl Hill   also sold before a sharp rise. He sold 3,000

 

shares for $ 97 each, or $ 291,000, March 4. Friday's close: $ 133 1/2, which makes his remaining 40,000 shares worth $ 5.3 million.

Other insider selling took place at Medical Care International Inc., Cambridge Biotech Corp., Pacificare Health Systems Inc., Biomet Inc., Diagnostic Products Corp.

Retail sales: Leslie Wexner, chairman of Columbus, Ohio-based retailer Limited Inc., sold 600,000 shares March 1 at $ 23.63 each, or $ 14.2 million. Wexner still owns 89.5 million shares worth $ 2.7 billion at Friday's close of $ 29 3/4. Philip Knight, chairman of Nike Inc., sold 200,000 shares Feb. 5 at $ 47.63 each, or $ 9.5 million. Knight owns 25.6 million shares worth $ 1.1 billion. Friday's close: $ 43 7/8.

Ante up: Circus Circus Enterprises Inc. Chairman William Bennett sold 1.5 million shares for $ 63.25 each, or $ 94.88 million March 21. In February, Bennett said he would sell stock in the Las Vegas-based casino before retiring. Bennett still owns 2.6 million shares worth $ 176.5 million at Friday's close of $ 67 7/8.

Copy cat: David Kearns, chairman of Xerox, sold his 9,250 Class B shares for $ 57.63 each, or $ 533,077, March 4. Kearns will leave Xerox to be U.S. undersecretary of Education. Kearns now holds 32,671 Xerox

shares worth $ 1.9 million Friday.    Xerox common shares closed at $ 58

 

Friday.

Defense moves: Insiders at defense contractors may have been thinking the rally in their companies' shares was over when the gulf war ended. It wasn't.

Four insiders at aircraft and missile maker Northrop Corp. sold a total of 20,125 shares for $ 528,765 the first week of March. They got $ 26 to $ 27 a share. Northrop shares closed Friday at $ 28 1/4.

Rudolph E. Lang Jr. sold 1,236 shares in electronics maker Litton Industries Inc. March 27 for $ 83 each, or $ 102,588. The vice president still holds 2,020 shares worth $ 179,275 based on Friday's close of $ 88 3/4.

James H. Miller, president of nerve-gas antidote maker Survival Technology Inc., sold 6,000 shares March 5 to March 25 for $ 17.46 each, or $ 104,760. He now holds 15,904 shares worth $ 318,080 based on Friday's close of $ 20.

Briefly: Biggest purchase: Viacom Inc. Chairman Sumner M. Redstone bought 81,400 common shares March 5 to March 28, at an average $ 24.45 each, or $ 1.99 million. The stock closed Friday at $ 30 3/4.
Contributing: Rhonda Richards

Information for this column is provided by Invest/Net, a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., firm specializing in tracking and analyzing Securities and Exchange Commission filings.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTOS; b/w (2)
 
CUTLINE: KNIGHT: Nike chief's stake worth $ 1.1 billion. CUTLINE: KEARNS: Departing chairman holds $ 1.9M in Xerox shares.


TYPE: Insider Trading


Copyright 1991 Gannett Company Inc.

 

411 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


April 30, 1991, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION


Lucrative roles;
Celebrities double up endorsements;
Critics claim multiple deals risk saturation


BYLINE: Stuart Elliott


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 1B


LENGTH: 1149 words


These days, when you see ads starring Leslie Nielsen, Paula Abdul, Isiah Thomas or Michael Jordan, you're seeing double. And triple. And even more.

Those celebrities are part of an increasingly popular though highly controversial trend: Stars are being signed by a variety of national marketers to appear in two, three or more ad campaigns at once. 

Take Nielsen, for instance. The actor's career got a new lease on life in the 1980s after he turned to comedy. His ad career is reborn, too. In funny TV commercials, he plays off his riotous shtick as a deadpan doctor in Airplane! and as an off-the-mark police officer in The Naked Gun and a sequel opening June 28, The Naked Gun II 1.2: The Smell of Fear.

Nielsen's first ad work, for Coors Light beer, has been airing since 1989. In January, he appeared as a clueless detective in ads for Diet Coke's ''Crack the code'' contest. And last week, Nielsen returned to the Tarmac in new ads for Dollar Rent A Car Systems Inc. themed, ''Right on the money. Right on the airport.''

Already, Nielsen is ahead of multi-endorser Abdul, who is appearing in national ads for Diet Coke and L.A. Gear.Nielsen is close behind multi- endorser Thomas, who is featured in national ads for MTV, Minute Maid Orange Soda, Toyota and ASICS Corp. athletic shoes.

Still, Nielsen has a long way to go to match the Chicago Bulls' Jordan. The basketball superstar now pitches for an astonishingly long list of blue- chip national marketers. Among them: McDonald's Corp., Coca-Cola Co., General Motors Corp. (Chevrolet), General Mills Inc. (Wheaties), Nike Inc., Sara Lee Corp. (Hanes) and CBS/Fox Video.

Multiple endorsements are lucrative for celebrities. Generally, a major marketer can pay anywhere from $ 50,000 to $ 500,000 to lure a star into its ads. Other considerations can send the fees even higher: if the deal runs for several years or if the marketer wants the celebrity to make personal appearances at trade shows or dealer meetings.

Yet few issues in advertising raise the hackles of industry critics more than the phenomenon of multi-endorser stars.

The critics see red when the same short list of famous faces appears in ad after ad after ad. In recent years, that list has included Bill Cosby, Bo Jackson, John Madden and Willard Scott. Among newer additions: rock star Little Richard (Nike, Taco Bell) and rap star M.C. Hammer (Pepsi-Cola, Taco Bell and British Knights).

The main complaint is that multiple exposure ''confuses the hell out of people,'' says George Lois, chairman of the Lois/GGK ad agency. The reason: The more ads a celebrity does, the less likely a consumer might be to recall the product being pitched in any one ad.

Plus, there's a danger that multiple ads will ''make (the star) more famous than the product,'' Lois says. He should know - he admits that ''I like to think I use celebrities more than anyone in the history of advertising.'' Among Lois' star-filled campaigns are ads for Reebok Pump athletic shoes, MTV and USA TODAY featuring celebs like Scott, Boomer Esiason and Tip O'Neill.

Anyone who stars in more than four simultaneous national campaigns has ''reached the saturation point. It begins to be a negative,'' says David Burns, president of Burns Sports Celebrity Service, a clearinghouse for sports talent. ''I do see (advertisers) pulling back on some of these people who have that many commercials.''

Yet those involved in signing celebrities to appear in multiple ad campaigns - as well as those who advise the celebrities to sign - say the practice is unavoidable.

''There are a lot of celebrities. There are not a lot of Michael Jordans. There are not a lot of Leslie Nielsens,'' says Dan Fox, executive vice president of Foote, Cone & Belding, the ad agency that recommended signing Nielsen for the delightfully silly Coors Light campaign. As long as Nielsen's new Dollar Rent A Car ads ''use him to his best advantage, they will do nothing to diminish Leslie Nielsen'' as a Coors Light ad property, Fox says.

Marketers and agencies insist using multi-endorsers is smart business. As evidence, they cite the extensive consumer research they do whenever considering whether to associate themselves with a star.

''Ten years ago, endorsements may have been signed (with stars) because a top-level manager was a fan,'' says John Caponigro, president of Sports Management Network and the attorney for Detroit Pistons star Thomas. ''That doesn't happen anymore. Today, all the figuring out whether the celebrity appeals to the target audience is key.''

Dollar's ad agency tested the idea of Nielsen as an ad star. The results: ''We found him instantly recognizable by the broad target group that rents cars,'' says Ray Roschmann, executive vice president of AC&R Advertising Inc. ''And his persona, his type of humor, was very much a positive influence on the communication value of the commercial.''

The crucial factor is ''the right use of the celebrity,'' says Manny Perez, executive vice president of the Young & Rubicam Inc. ad agency. ''It works if he's there for a reason.'' Perez is using Magic Johnson in new ads for Kentucky Fried Chicken's skinless Light 'n Crispy line. The KFC ads follow the Los Angeles Lakers star's appearances in campaigns for other products such as Slice Mandarin Orange soft drinks and Converse athletic shoes.

Still, marketers and their agencies are sensitive to charges that using multi-endorsers reveals them to be copycats trying to duplicate someone else's celebrity success story - and fraidy-cats, fearful of taking a chance on signing a celebrity who isn't already hawking other products.

So steps are being taken to minimize the problems associated with multi- endorsers. Sometimes, star endorsers must agree to exclusivity clauses in their contracts, guaranteeing they will not peddle more products in other ads.

The most common of these clauses call for what's known as category exclusivity. They require the star to agree to appear in ads for only one product type. For example, a fast-food chain might insist that its spokesstar not sign to do ads for a convenience-store chain that also sells food to go.

In Nielsen's case, the strategy is to avoid having him appear in any ad as a spokesman or pitchstar. ''He's not saying, 'Go to Dollar Rent A Car' or 'Drink Coors Light,' '' says Curry Walls, president of the Sutter/Walls Associates talent agency and Nielsen's agent for ad endorsements.

Instead, the idea is for Nielsen to play a character in his ads. Those advertisers who don't agree - and there have been many, Walls says - get turned down.

And Caponigro's criterion in signing ad agreements for Thomas is not the quantity, but the quality.

''You want to make sure, as he delivers the message, that it's consistent with his personality and his image,'' he says. ''As long as you do that, everything's all right.''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTOS; color (3); PHOTO; color, Eileen Blass, USA TODAY

412 of 1437 DOCUMENTS


USA TODAY


May 13, 1991, Monday, FINAL EDITION


Jennings sets world mark but misses bonus money


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 11C


LENGTH: 1012 words


Lynn Jennings missed $ 25,000 by three seconds Sunday - and was able to smile about it.

''When you set a world record, how can you be disappointed?'' Jennings said. ''I don't race for money.''

Jennings outran 3,000 others to win the Nike Women's Race 8K (4.97 miles) at Washington, D.C., in 25: 02, one second better than Grete Waitz's world record, five seconds better than Jennings' U.S. record and 12 seconds ahead of runner-up Susan Sirma of Kenya. 

Had Jennings, who earned $ 5,000 in prize money and about $ 4,000 in Nike bonuses, broken 25 minutes, she would have received $ 25,000 from Clairol.

''I came here to win the race, not for any other reason,'' said Jennings, 30, two-time defending world cross-country champion.

''I had no idea we were so close to 25. When I saw the 2-mile split (10: 10), I thought the record was out the window. I hope Clairol puts up the money next year. Maybe not, I came so close.''

Jennings credited Sirma, who races all distances all over the world, with an assist for the record in mid-70 degree temperatures. Sirma, 24, who won a 10K in Indonesia last month and raced a half-marathon in London last week, held a seven-second lead at 3 miles, ahead of a pack that included Jennings and defending champion Judi St. Hilaire.

''I thought Judi would go after her at three,'' said Jennings. ''When she didn't, I said, 'I'm outta here.' ''

By 3 1/2 miles, Jennings caught Sirma, who surged repeatedly until Jennings passed her in the final 200 meters.

Because Jennings wants to peak for the 10,000 meters at the World Track & Field Championships in August, she has been racing sparingly. ''I'm fit, but not race-sharp, so this (record) is heartening news,'' she said.

Said her coach, John Babington: ''I think Lynn is going to run

24:02 some day.''    - Dick Patrick

 

TRACK AND FIELD: A South African sports association has inquired whether former Olympian Zola Budd-
Pieterse, 24, and some other South Africans can compete in the World University Games this summer in Sheffield, England. A decision would have to be made by the International Federation of University Sports, whose next meeting is Friday in Sicily. South Africa has been banned from most international sports for two decades because of its apartheid system of racial segregation.

Kamy Keshmiri, the 1990 NCAA champion, won the discus (199-5) and fellow U.S. athlete Tim Bright won the pole vault (18-0 1/2) Sunday at the Mito International in Tokyo.
 
COLLEGES: Penn State (14-3) defeated Lafayette 11-9 Saturday in the first round of the NCAA women's lacrosse championship, earning a berth opposite Virginia (15-1) in Saturday's semifinals. New Hampshire (11-1) defeated Harvard 11-10, earning a semifinal spot against Maryland (13-2). Maryland's Chris Macko and Kim Terhorst, starting juniors, were declared ineligible. They modeled clothing from two College Park, Md., stores in a fashion supplement to the student newspaper, violations of the NCAA's regulation prohibiting athletes from promoting commercial products or services. Maryland reported the infraction to the NCAA, declared the players ineligible and then appealed.

In the NCAA men's lacrosse championship, No. 1 North Carolina (13-0), No. 2 Brown (13-0), No. 3 Princeton (12-2) and No. 4 Johns Hopkins (8-3) are the top four seeds, earning first-round byes and the right to host quarterfinal games next Sunday. Wednesday's first round: Loyola (Md.)-Massachusetts; Syracuse-Michigan State; Virginia-Towson State; Maryland-Rutgers.

Also: Temple beat Georgetown by a boat length Saturday in Philadelphia to win the men's varsity heavyweight eights in the Dad Vail Regatta for the third consecutive year, covering the 2,000-meter course in 6 minutes, 29.16 seconds. In the women's varsity heavyweight eight, Virginia won in 7: 32.44, defeating Tufts (Mass.) by 1 1/2 lengths.
 
BOXING: Terrence Alli dominated the final round Sunday to earn a split decision against Charles Murray for the United States Boxing Association junior welterweight championship at Rochester, N.Y.
 
ELSEWHERE: Igor Grachev scored a game-high 23 points as the Soviet National Junior basketball team defeated the Iowa AAU Select team 127-87 Sunday in Iowa City. ... Jockey Patrick Valenzuela, returning to racing Sunday after a six-month suspension, found the riding rough as his first mount bolted and crashed through a fence at Hollywood Park in Inglewood, Calif. Valenzuela wasn't hurt . ... Former New York Jet Mark Gastineau is being sought by Nassau (N.Y.) County police, who want to interview him about a fight Sunday in a Long Island bar. ... Top-seeded Sinjin Smith and Randy Stoklos defeated Tim Hovland and Kent Steffes 15-11 for their 101st career volleyball win and the championship of the $ 65,000 Miller Lite Open at Fresno, Calif. ... Karolyn Kirby and Angela Rock, both of San Diego, defeated Elaine Roque (Malibu, Calif.) and Janice Opalinski-Harrer (Honolulu) 15-3, to win the Flamingo Hilton Women's Pro Beach Volleyball Tour's 1991 Jag Hermosa Beach (Calif.) Open. ... Colombian Fabio Parra drove up a slippery, snow- lined mountain road to win the 14th leg of the Tour of Spain cycling race Sunday in Valdezcaray. Spain's Melchor Mauri retained the overall lead in the 21-stage event by finishing sixth. ... Michael Doohan of Australia won the 500cc class race in the Spanish Motorcycling Grand Prix Sunday in Jerez. The victory, his first this season, moved Doohan to the top of the world standings, ahead of defending champion Wayne Rainey of the USA. ... U.S.-bred trotter Peace Corps, driven by Sweden's Stig Johansson, led all the way in winning the Oslo (Norway) Grand Prix harness race Sunday.

QUOTE OF THE DAY
''It hurt taking Toronto's paychecks, but it felt better when I cashed them.'' - Bill Caudill, former major league pitcher, whose career ended prematurely because of a torn rotator cuff but not before he signed a five- year, $ 7 million contract with the Blue Jays, who guaranteed three of the years.

Compiled by Harry Blauvelt

Nike's print ads


SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 1B


LENGTH: 85 words


 Nike's print ads ... starring filmmaker Spike Lee and basketball star Michael Jordan were named the most popular campaign of 1990, according to a Video Storyboard Tests Inc. survey. Runner-up: fragrance maker Calvin Klein.
Nissan USA ... is slashing costs - including canceling national TV ads in July and September - to funnel $ 50 million more into buyer-incentive programs, according to 'Automotive News.' The money will pay for new incentives of $ 600 to $ 1,500 on the Maxima, 240SX and 300ZX .

May 24, 1991, Friday, FINAL EDITION


Briefly


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C


LENGTH: 96 words


Beth Daly, wife of race-car driver and ESPN racing analyst Derek Daly, is a winner on the race course herself. 

But Daly, the 1990 jet-ski world champion (novice division), won't be defending her title or moving up to the expert division this season. She's three months pregnant.

Although she is doing some exhibition jet-skiing this weekend, racing has been ruled out for the summer.

- The Nike shoe company will have the exclusive advertising rights for footwear during the French Open and Wimbledon tennis tournaments on NBC. The contract will run through 1994.
